goals.goal_example_text:
**Example sentences:** * “I went to the store and bought two apples.”
* “I can see the birds flying over the sea.”
* “Only one person won the first place prize.” **Example student responses:** * I went to the store for two apples. * Can you pick up the can? * I see birds over the sea. * One person won the prize.
goals.goal_text: By (date), when asked to transcribe a verbal sentence that contains (2) previously-learned homophones (i.e. words spelled differently but sound the same), (name) will write a close approximation of the sentence using the correct homophones, for (4 out of 5) sentences.

objectives.example_text:
**Example sentence:**

“I went <u>to</u> the store and bought <u>two</u> apples.”

**Example illustration:**

A person at the grocery store holding two apples.
objectives.text: By (date), when asked to transcribe a verbal sentence that contains (2) previously-learned homophones (i.e. words spelled differently but sound the same), given a corresponding [[visual aids|illustration]], (name) will write a close approximation of the sentence using the correct homophones, for (4 out of 5) sentences.

objectives.example_text:
**Example sentence:**

“I went <u>to</u> the store and bought <u>two</u> apples.”

**Example cloze sentence:**

I went _\_\_\_\_ the store and bought \_\_\_\_\_ apples.
objectives.text: By (date), when asked to transcribe a verbal sentence that contains (2) previously-learned homophones, given a corresponding [[visual aids|illustration]], (name) will write the correct homophones to complete a [[cloze sentences|cloze sentence]], for (4 out of 5) sentences.

objectives.example_text:
**Example phrase:**

Teacher says, “Two apples.”

**Example prompt:**

“Which word was used?” Teacher holds up one card that says, “TO” and another card that says, “TWO."

**Example student response:**

Student points to the “TWO” word card.
objectives.text: By (date), given a verbal (2-3) word phrase that contains (1) previously learned homophone and a corresponding [[visual aids|illustration]], when asked to identify the homophone in written form, (name) will select the word [[multiple choice|from (2) word cards]], for (4 out of 5) homophone discrimination activities.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Correctly Spell Homonyms Using Context Clues

udl_adaptations.text: Use familiar [[visual aids|visual images]] to support word discrimination tasks. By selecting images of things that are familiar or preferred, the task becomes more relevant and purposeful. For example, when teaching a student to discriminate between the words “sea” and “see," the teacher can present two images: one of a favorite cartoon character floating in the ocean captioned with the word “sea,” and another of that same cartoon character wearing glasses captioned with the word “see." When verbally stating each word in the context of a sentence, the teacher can hold up the corresponding visual image. With practice, students will begin to associate other words that often occur in context alongside the target words--helping them build foundations for independent auditory discrimination of similar-sounding words and phrases.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Minimize threats and distractions
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.3 Minimize threats and distractions

udl_adaptations.text: A written [[cloze sentences|cloze sentence]] can limit the auditory information the student needs to process, while still enabling him or her to show understanding of the difference between two homophones. If the teacher gives the example sentence "I see birds over the sea," the student needs to transcribe approximately six words, while simultaneously differentiating between the homophones. If the teacher accompanies the statement with the written cloze sentence I _\_\_\_\_ birds over the _\_\_\_\_, the student only needs to write down the correct homophones, and can use context to determine their position within the sentence.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.5 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Illustrate through multiple media
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.5 Illustrate through multiple media

udl_adaptations.text: After hearing a homophone spoken aloud, allow students to choose its written counterpart from two [[multiple choice|options]]. Some students have difficulty hearing individual words within a sentence. Giving a student the written variations of a homophone allows him or her to focus on the context of the sentence to determine which word is being used, versus recalling how to spell the word without a visual reference. For the example sentence “I want to buy apples for the party," present the words “for” and “four” on separate cards, and ask the student to identify which written word represents the homophone from the verbal sentence.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.2 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Use multiple tools for construction and composition
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.2 Use multiple tools for construction and composition

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example difficult hearing situations:** * Guided peer discussion
* Guest speaker
* Activity in the gymnasium **Example teacher prompt:** Teacher asks, "Do you think you should use the FM or your hearing aid when the speaker comes to class?" **Example student response:** "FM."
goals.goal_text: By (date), in difficult hearing situation at school that requires use of hearing assistive technology, given a choice between (2) devices, (name) will identify the device best suited for the situation and use it for the duration, (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations.

objectives.text:
By (date), in difficult hearing situation at school that requires use of hearing assistive technology, given a choice between (2) devices and asked (1) [[guiding questions|guiding question]], (name) will identify the device best suited for the situation and use it for the duration, (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations. *Example guiding question:*
Teacher says, “The acoustics in the gymnasium cause echoes. Which device can you use to help you hear better in the gym?”

By (date), in difficult hearing situation at school that requires use of hearing assistive technology, given a choice between (2) devices presented on a [[choice boards|choice board]], and asked (1) [[guiding questions|guiding question]], (name) will identify the device best suited for the situation and use it for the duration, (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations. *Example device options:*
• FM unit
• Personalized device (e.g. whichever device the student uses: hearing aid(s), CI(s), BAHA)

By (date), in a difficult hearing situation at school that requires use of hearing assistive technology, when the teacher names the device best suited for the situation and asks which of (2) [[choice boards|choice board]] options shows the device, (name) will [[modified assignment|identify the device]] on the board and use it for the duration, (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations. *Example teacher prompt:*
"You should use the FM unit today. Which one of these is the FM?"

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Choose the Best Device for a Situation

udl_adaptations.text:
Provide a personalized [[choice boards|choice board]] of available devices, which will help the student determine which device is best suited for a specific situation, and develop visual recognition of multiple types of devices.
Some example images might include:
• Personal FM system
• Boots for the hearing aid(s)
• Neckloop
• Soundfield system
• Noise cancelling headphones
Each image can have velcro tape on the backside, with a matching velcro portion on the board to allow for easy "push and stick," as well as easy storage.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize individual choice and autonomy
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.1 Optimize individual choice and autonomy

udl_adaptations.text: Ask students [[guiding questions|guiding questions]] to help them identify the device best suited for a given situation. For example, if a student already knows it is difficult to hear in the gym, and is aware of the device options available, the teacher can simply say, "Which device helps best when there are loud echoes and lots of people?" If the student is unaware of which device to use, a guiding question can include the device names: "Would the FM or your hearing aid be better for the assembly in the gym?"
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.3 Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation

udl_adaptations.text:
[[modified assignment|Modify]] this task to accommodate students who prefer to respond through non-verbal methods. To begin, present images of different devices on a [[choice board|choice board]]. Then, give an example of a difficult hearing situation (real or imagined), and ask the student to select the device that is best suited for the situation. Students can use a variety of response methods depending on the prompt: yes/no nodding, pointing/gesturing, or using an adaptive switch/communication device to select a response. *Implementation examples:*
Teacher says, “When you enter the classroom at the beginning of the school day, should you be using the FM?” Student nods "no." Teacher says, "Which device should you wear as you enter the classroom?" Student points to the hearing aid on the choice board.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example pre-taught strategies:** * Ask for repetition
* Close a door to minimize noise
* Adjust device setting
* Move seat closer to sound source
goals.goal_text: By (date), during school, when amongst peers in a difficult listening situation, (name) will use (1) pre-taught strategy to improve the ability to hear, in (4 out of 5) observed situations with peers.

objectives.text:
By (date), during school, when amongst peers in a difficult listening situation, after confirming with a [[peer buddies|peer buddy]] that auditory information was not heard/misheard, (name) will use (1) pre-taught strategy to improve the ability to hear, in (4 out of 5) observed situations with peers. *Example peer assistance:*
Student asks, "Did they say the class party is tomorrow?"
Peer buddy responds, "No, Friday."

By (date), during school, when amongst peers in a difficult listening situation, after the teacher gives a [[visual cue cards|visual cue card]] with (3) pre-taught repair strategies, (name) will [[multiple choice|choose]] (1) strategy and use it to improve the ability to hear, in (4 out of 5) observed situations with peers. *Example visual cue card strategies:*
• Ask to repeat
• Move your seat
• Whole body listening

By (date), during a difficult listening situation in school, after the teacher gives a [[visual cue cards|visual cue card]] with (1) repair strategy and [[verbal prompting|prompts]] to use it, (name) will use the strategy presented on the card to improve the ability to hear, with [[graduated guidance|graduated teacher guidance]], in (4 out of 5) observed situations with peers.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Adjust to Better Hear Peers

udl_adaptations.text:
Create [[visual cue cards|visual cue cards]] with repair strategies that students can reference during conversation. Depending on the individual student, the cue cards can be taped into an agenda, posted on a classroom wall, or laminated and transportable, so the teacher can place one in front of the student as needed. When the student appears to be having difficulty hearing, the teacher can point to a cue card, or give a reminder to reference them. The cards can include simple illustrations, or even photographs that depict each strategy. *Example cue card repair strategies:*
• Move seat
• Ask to repeat
• Close door
• Check with a friend
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 1.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer ways of customizing the display of information
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 1.1 Offer ways of customizing the display of information

udl_adaptations.text: If a student doesn't independently take action during a difficult hearing situation, give them a few repair strategy [[multiple choice|choices]]. As long as the teacher explicitly teaches repair strategies before asking students to use them independently, the choices will remind the students of what they already know. Teachers can present the choices on a visual cue card, a written list, or verbally. For example, if a student appears to have difficulty following a conversation with peers in the lunchroom, the teacher can take the student aside and say, "Remember, if you're having trouble hearing, you can adjust your device setting, move your seat closer, or ask your friend to repeat what he said."
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: Encourage students to check in with a [[peer buddies|peer buddy]] during a difficult listening situation. Ideally, the peer buddy will be aware of the student's hearing needs, so if the student asks the peer buddy to clarify something, the peer buddy isn't taken off-guard. Teachers can begin by asking the student if they have a dependable friend that could be potentially helpful during difficult hearing situations. If the student says yes, the teacher can give the student specific ways to approach the peer when there is a problem. For example, the student can ask the peer buddy to repeat information, clarify something that was said, or be observed as a model (e.g. if a direction is given that the student doesn't hear, the student can watch the peer buddy and follow along).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster collaboration and communication
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.3 Foster collaboration and communication

goals.goal_text: By (date), given a current personal audiogram and a speech banana template, (name) will independently plot the data points from the audiogram (i.e. decibels and frequency) onto the template with (100)% accuracy, for (1 out of 1) speech banana.

objectives.text: By (date), given a current personal audiogram, a speech banana template, and an [[exemplar|exemplar]] to reference, (name) will independently plot the data points from the audiogram (i.e. decibels and frequency) onto the template with (100)% accuracy, for (1 out of 1) speech banana.

By (date), given a current personal audiogram, a speech banana template, and an [[exemplar|exemplar]] to reference, (name) will use (2) teacher [[verbal prompting|prompts]] to plot the data points from the audiogram (i.e. decibels and frequency) onto the template with (100)% accuracy, for (1 out of 1) speech banana. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, “That one is your left ear, so use a blue X when you plot it on the template.”

By (date), given a current personal audiogram, a [[modified assignment|partially-complete]] speech banana template with data for one ear, and an [[exemplar|exemplar]] to reference, (name) will use (2) teacher [[graduated guidance|guidance prompts]] to plot the data points for the other ear (i.e. decibels and frequency) onto the template with (100)% accuracy, for (1 out of 1) speech banana.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Create a Speech Banana

udl_adaptations.text: A speech banana gives students a visual representation of hearing loss. To help students create a speech banana, the teacher must first locate current audiogram data, and then teach the students how to transfer the data from the audiogram onto the speech banana template. This task allows students to familiarize themselves with their individual hearing strengths and weaknesses. Check out this [[http://www.jtc.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Audiogram-Familiar-Sounds.jpg|example template]] from jtc.org.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.2 Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity

udl_adaptations.text:
Color-coding an [[exemplar|exemplar]] for student reference will help illuminate the meaning of each element included on the speech banana. For instance, through the exemplar, students can see that the left ear data is represented by a blue X, the right ear data is represented by a red O, the hearing loss range is represented by an orange box, and within normal limits (people who do not have a documented hearing loss hear in this range) is represented by a yellow box. As they create their own speech bananas, students can look at the exemplar to ensure they correctly record their personal audiogram data. *Example exemplar implementation:*
Teacher presents exemplar and says, “See how the yellow box (within normal limits) and orange box (hearing loss range) have lines opposite to each other? This is so that people who are looking at the speech banana can easily see the difference between the two boxes.”
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.2 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Highlight patterns, critical features, big ideas, and relationships
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.2 Highlight patterns, critical features, big ideas, and relationships

udl_adaptations.text: [[modified assignment|Modify]] this task for students who need assistance transferring data from the audiogram onto the speech banana template. Give students a partially-complete speech banana template, and help them finish it using [[graduated guidance|graduated guidance]]. The amount of assistance will vary depending on the individual student's needs. For example, if given a speech banana template with completed data for the left ear, one individual student may be able to add the right ear data with verbal guidance from the teacher. Another student may need the teacher to add most of the right ear data while modeling/thinking aloud before adding the final two data points independently.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_text: By (date), when asked to explain a personal hearing loss, using a speech banana drawn from a current personal audiogram, (name) will describe (2) sounds they can hear and (2) sounds they can't, for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss explanations.

objectives.text: By (date), when asked to explain a personal hearing loss during a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 discussion with a teacher]], using a speech banana drawn from a current personal audiogram, (name) will describe (2) sounds they can hear and (2) sounds they can't, for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss explanations.

By (date), when asked to explain a personal hearing loss during a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 discussion with a teacher]], using a speech banana drawn from a current personal audiogram, after the teacher uses an example speech banana to [[teacher modeling academic task|demonstrate]] the task, (name) will describe (2) sounds they can hear and (2) sounds they can't, for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss explanations.

By (date), during a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 discussion with a teacher]], given a speech banana drawn from a current personal [[visual aids|illustrated]] audiogram, and asked to identify (1) sound they can hear and (1) sound they can't, (name) will select each sound when prompted (e.g. by pointing, describing, using an [[adaptive switches|adaptive switch]]), for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss explanations. Example illustrated audiogram/speech banana [[https://www.hearinglink.org/your-hearing/hearing-tests-audiograms/what-is-the-speech-banana/|from Hearinglink.org]]. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, "Show me a sound you can't hear."

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Describe Personal Hearing Loss Data

udl_adaptations.text: [[Teacher modeling academic task|Demonstrate]] how the speech banana can be used to explain personal hearing loss to a layperson. For example, start with presentation basics by saying, “If I am holding the speech banana and it is facing downward, the audience can't see the data.” Then, demonstrate how to properly hold the speech banana; providing the student with understanding of how the presentation will be seen from the audience's perspective. To help the student understand how to illustrate specific elements when presenting the speech banana, say, “If I don’t use my finger to show the lines of blue Xs and red Os that represent the left and right ears, the audience won't automatically know what I'm talking about.” Then, use a pointed finger to trace the line of symbols (i.e., X’s or O’s) on the speech banana.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.3 Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation

udl_adaptations.text:
[[modified assignment|Modify]] this task to accommodate non-verbal students. To begin, ask the student to identify which sounds can or can't be heard. Some students will be able to describe specific sounds, while others will benefit if given access to an illustrated audiogram/speech banana that includes picture representations of sounds embedded into the chart. When asked, the student can point to sounds that fall within or out of personal hearing range. *Example teacher prompt to elicit a non-verbal response:*
Teacher says, “Show me a sound that you can easily hear with your right ear.” *Example student response:*
Student points to the picture of a crying baby.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: Teach students to use a speech banana as a self-advocacy tool. Exposure to a speech banana derived from personal hearing loss data allows students to familiarize themselves with their individual hearing needs, as well as develop vocabulary associated with hearing loss. This activity can be completed repeatedly, with multiple teachers and/or peers. Discussions like these prepare students to naturally advocate for themselves in the workplace and in a variety of social situations.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.2 Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example devices:** • Hearing aid (5 parts)
• Cochlear implant (4 or more parts)
• BAHA (3 or more parts) **Example student response:** Student says, "I have a cochlear implant. The processor changes sounds into a digital code that my brain can hear, the battery door holds the battery, the cord sends code to my headpiece, and the headpiece transmits the code."
goals.goal_text: By (date), when asked to explain a personal hearing device, (name) will label each part of the device and explain what it does, for (3 out of 3) device explanations.

objectives.text: By (date), when asked to explain a personal hearing device to a [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar]] person, (name) will label each part of the device and explain what it does, for (3 out of 3) device explanations.

By (date), when asked to explain a personal hearing device to a [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar]] person, given a [[visual aids|picture]] of the device (i.e. so device can still be worn to hear) and a [[word bank|bank]] of written part names, (name) will label each part of the device with options from the bank, for (3 out of 3) device explanation situations. *Example word bank for a hearing aid:*
• Microphone
• Battery compartment
• Earmold
• Tubing
• On/off switch

By (date), given a [[visual aids|picture]] of a personal hearing device (i.e. so device can still be worn to hear), when the teacher names (1) device part, (name) will indicate the device part on the picture using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]], for (3 out of 3) device explanations. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, "Can you show me the battery?" *Example student response:*
Student points to the battery on the device picture.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Explain How a Personal Device Works

udl_adaptations.text: Use a [[visual aids|diagram or picture]] of a personal hearing device so a student can see all of the device parts while explaining what each part does. During a conversation about how a device works, a student will still need to use the device to hear, and therefore probably wouldn't take it off to show each part. A diagram of a device can easily be found online, by searching for the student's specific make and model. The manufacturer's website (e.g. Phonak, Cochlear, Oticon) may have a diagram as well.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.5 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Illustrate through multiple media
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.5 Illustrate through multiple media

udl_adaptations.text:
Provide a [[word bank|bank]] of written device parts that students can use to label pictures of their personal hearing devices. Device part names can be technical and difficult to remember, especially if the device is new to the student. Giving answer options helps familiarize the student with each term. Students can either use the written choices as references and verbally label the device parts, or physically place them onto the picture. *Example word bank for a cochlear implant:*
• Processor
• Battery door
• Cord
• Headpiece
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.2 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Use multiple tools for construction and composition
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.2 Use multiple tools for construction and composition

udl_adaptations.text: Modify this task so students can respond using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]]. There are a few ways to accomplish this. One way is that the teacher can verbally state a device part and ask the student to identify it on a picture (or actual device). The student can point, gesture, use a communication device or adaptive switch to indicate the location of the part. Another way would be to ask yes or no questions about the various parts of the hearing device. For example, the teacher can point to the battery door and say, "Is this the cord?" The student would then shake her head "No," in response. This strategy is ideal for students who prefer not to use spoken language to communicate - even though they won't provide a verbal "explanation," it allows them to show understanding of how their devices work.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize individual choice and autonomy
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.1 Optimize individual choice and autonomy

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example difficult hearing situations:** • Guided peer discussion
• Guest speaker
• Activity in the gymnasium **Example student response:** Student uses the FM unit while the speaker gives a presentation.

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example scenario:**

The student needs to listen to a professor give a lecture in a very large college classroom.

**Example student response:**

Student says, "A soundfield system would be best if there is one available, because the entire class would benefit from the amplified sound."
goals.goal_text: By (date), given a post-secondary or community scenario in which hearing assistive technology is necessary, (name) will identify the device best suited for the situation, and explain how it would help, in (4 out of 5) transition discussions.

objectives.example_text:
**Example guiding question:**

Teacher asks, "What technology might be available in a college lecture hall?"
objectives.text: By (date), given a post-secondary or community scenario in which hearing assistive technology is necessary, after the teacher asks (1) [[guiding questions|guiding question]], (name) will identify the device best suited for the situation, and explain how it would help, in (4 out of 5) transition discussions.

By (date), given a post-secondary or community scenario in which hearing assistive technology is necessary, given (3) device [[picture choices|picture choices]], after the teacher asks (1) [[guiding questions|guiding question]], (name) will identify the device best suited for the situation, in (4 out of 5) transition discussions.

By (date), given a post-secondary scenario in which hearing assistive technology is necessary, and asked to identify which of (2) device [[picture choices|picture choices]] shows the device best suited to the situation, after the teacher [[preteaching|describes the benefits of each device]], (name) will choose the device that is best suited, (4 out of 5) transition discussions.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Identify Post-Secondary Device Options

udl_adaptations.text:
Create a post-secondary or community [[social narratives|scenario]] that would require the student to use hearing assistive technology. Then, ask the student to determine which personal device should be used, and to explain why. As students get older, they need to independently identify the technology that will best help them in a given situation. Hypothetical practice situations like these can prepare them. *Example scenarios:*
• Conversation with peers in a noisy environment
• Hearing the professor’s lecture in a large classroom (i.e., room with up to 100 or more students present)
• Hearing emergency signals in a dormitory
• Hearing a multi-media presentation (i.e., movie/DVD, web-based event, TV, etc.) with limited volume
• Hearing the other person’s message on a phone conversation
• Hearing a movie while at the movie theater
• Hearing social conversation during a sporting event (i.e., football game, basketball game, track meet, etc.) where a large crowd is present
• Hearing directions and/or rules for the day from your supervisor in a loud factory/restaurant/business
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.2 Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity

udl_adaptations.text:
Some students will need help understanding *why* a specific device should be used for a given scenario. Give these students fixed device options, and [[preteaching|describe]] the benefits of each device before asking the student to determine which would be best suited for a given situation. *Some benefits might include (dependent on an individual student's hearing needs):* • Hearing aid- Allows the user to hear the speaker with mild/moderate amplification.
• Classroom soundfield system- Allows the whole class to hear the speaker’s voice amplified.
• Personal FM system- Allows the individual with HA(s), BAHA(s) or CI(s) to hear the speaker directly in the ear.
• Amplified phone- Allows the user to turn up the volume on the phone, as loud as necessary to hear the speaker.
• Speech-to-text phone- Allows the user to read the speaker’s phrases in print/text format AND provides the user with the means to turn up the volume on the phone, as loud as necessary to hear the speaker.
• Closed captioning decoder- Allows the user to translate the oral message into text/print format for multi-media presentations (i.e., movies/DVD, TV or web-based programs).
• Vibrating alarm clock- Allows the user to wake up from sleep through vibrations that “shake” the bed.
• Vibrating wrist watch- Allows the user to be notified of scheduled events and/or time(s) via. vibrations on the wrist.
• Flashing light fire alarm- A visual alert system that flashes a bright light in case of a fire and/or emergency.
• Recorder- Allows the user to record a speaker, giving them the means to “play back” the message multiple times for re-exposure.
• Video Relay Service (VRS)- Allows the DHH population to communicate via phone using Sign Language with the assistance of an interpreter.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Clarify vocabulary and symbols
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.1 Clarify vocabulary and symbols

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Picture choices|Pictures]] of hearing assistive technology devices will give students visual reference points, and help familiarize them with devices they might not see on a daily basis (but could still find useful). In relation to this learning target, pictures of the following devices can be used: • Hearing aids (HA)
• Cochlear implants (CI)
• Bone Anchored Hearing Aids (BAHA)
• Classroom soundfield system
• Personal FM system
• Amplified phone
• Speech-to-text phone
• Closed captioning decoder
• Vibrating alarm clock
• Vibrating wrist watch
• Flashing light fire alarm
• Recorder
• Video relay service (VRS)
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example difficult hearing situations due to seating arrangement:** * Near the projector
* Near a loud group of students
* Too close to a speaker
* Near a fan
* Near the heater
goals.goal_text: By (date), after recognizing a current seating arrangement is causing a difficult hearing situation during a school activity, (name) will ask to change seats to a placement that improves the ability to hear, for (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations.

objectives.text:
By (date), after using the teacher's [[guiding questions|guiding question]] to recognize a current seating arrangement is causing a difficult hearing situation during a school activity, (name) will ask to change seats to a placement that improves the ability to hear, for (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations. *Example guiding question:*
Teacher asks, "What can we do to help you better hear the discussion?"

By (date), after using the teacher's [[guiding questions|guiding question]] to recognize a current seating arrangement is causing a difficult hearing situation during a school activity, when the teacher gives (2) alternate seating [[multiple choice|choices]], (name) will choose the placement that most improves the ability to hear, for (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations. *Example optimal locations:*
• Near the teacher or presenter
• In a designated quiet space
• Away from the classroom door

By (date), when a current seating arrangement is causing a difficult hearing situation during a school activity, given (2) alternate seating location [[multiple choice|choices]] that are both [[noise reduction in the classroom|optimal for hearing]],  (name) will choose (1) of the alternate locations using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]], (e.g. communication device, nodding, stating), for (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Ask to Change Seat

udl_adaptations.text: Modify this task to allow students to use a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]]. Instead of verbally asking the teacher to change seats, a student can use a nonverbal communication method, such as gesturing, nodding in response to a yes/no question, activating an adaptive switch or using a communication device. For example, to elicit a yes/no response, the teacher can ask, “Do you think sitting closer to the teacher/speaker would help you to hear better in this situation?” Similarly, if the student uses a communication device, the teacher can ask questions that elicit student answers that have already been pre-programmed into the device. For students who prefer to communicate using images, the teacher can supply picture choices of alternate seating locations and ask them to choose the seating arrangement that works best. Students can point to, pick up, or use eye gaze to indicate their selection.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Develop self-assessment and reflection
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.3 Develop self-assessment and reflection

udl_adaptations.text: If a student doesn’t independently recognize that a seating assignment is causing a difficult hearing situation, ask a few [[guiding questions|guiding questions]]. For example, if a student who is seated near a fan isn’t participating in a class discussion (but usually does), the teacher do a quick check for auditory understanding by asking something such as, “(Name), can you repeat Julian's claim?” The student might immediately say “No,” and blame the fan for causing auditory disruption, but if not, follow up with another guiding question: “Is there something about your current seat that is making it difficult to hear?” If the student still has trouble, pair a guiding question with 3 alternate seating choices, and ask, “Which of these seating locations will help you to better hear the discussion?” Instead of simply telling the student to switch seats, guiding questions like these lead the student to recognize difficult hearing situations with a little more independence.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.3 Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation

udl_adaptations.text:
Give the student alternate seating [[multiple choice|choices]] that are optimal for hearing. The choices will differ depending upon the type of setting (e.g. gym, cafeteria, auditorium, classroom), and will also differ for each student. Some students don't function well “up-front” in a classroom, while others benefit from close proximity, for example. *Example alternate seating locations include:*
Gymnasium:
• Sitting/standing up front near the speaker/teacher
• Sitting on the middle of the bench
• Positioning to face the teacher
Auditorium:
• Sitting in a front row of the auditorium seating
• Sitting in a middle row of the front section of the auditorium
• Sitting in the middle section, away from the speakers
Classroom:
• Sitting near the teacher/speaker
• Moving to the back of the classroom where student distraction has been minimized
• Sitting at a table for independent work to be closer to the speaker/teacher
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example difficult hearing situations due to seating arrangement:** * Near the projector
* Near a loud group of students
* Near a fan
**Example student response:** Student says, "Could I move to the back table? It's further away from the fan."
goals.goal_text: By (date), after recognizing a current seating arrangement is causing a difficult hearing situation during a school activity, (name) will ask to change seats to a placement that improves the ability to hear, and give (1) reason why, for (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations.

objectives.text:
By (date), after using the teacher's [[guiding questions|guiding question]] to recognize a current seating arrangement is causing a difficult hearing situation during a school activity, (name) will ask to change seats to a placement that improves the ability to hear, and give (1) reason why, for (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations. *Example guiding question:*
Teacher asks, "What can we do to help you better hear the discussion?"

By (date), after using the teacher's [[guiding questions|guiding question]] to recognize a current seating arrangement is causing a difficult hearing situation during a school activity, when the teacher gives (2) alternate seating [[multiple choice|choices]], (name) will choose a placement that improves the ability to hear, for (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations. *Example alternate seating locations:*
• Near the teacher or presenter
• In a designated quiet space
• Away from the classroom door

By (date), during a school activity, when the teacher gives (2) alternate seating location [[multiple choice|choices]] that are both [[noise reduction in the classroom|optimal for hearing]], (name) will choose (1) of the alternate locations using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]] (e.g. communication device, nodding, stating), for (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations. *Example student use of preferred mode of expression:*
Teacher asks, "Would it be better if you sat in the quiet area?"
Student shakes head, "No."
Teacher asks, "Would you rather sit in the front?"
Student shakes head, "Yes."

goals.goal_text: By (date), during school, after recognizing that a verbal message was misheard and/or misunderstood, (name) will ask the speaker to repeat what was said, for (4 out of 5) misheard/misunderstood verbal messages.

objectives.text:
By (date), during school, when a verbal message was misheard and/or misunderstood, given (1) [[verbal prompting|teacher prompt]], (name) will ask the speaker to repeat what was said, for (4 out of 5) misheard/misunderstood verbal messages. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, "I'm not sure you heard that, (name)."

By (date), during school, when a verbal message was misheard and/or misunderstood, given (1) [[verbal prompting|teacher prompt]] and a [[anchor charts|listening steps chart]], (name) will ask the speaker to repeat what was said after referencing the chart, for (4 out of 5) misheard/misunderstood verbal messages. *Example listening chart steps:*
Step 1: Ask a peer buddy to repeat what was said (picture of two friends)
Step 2: Observe people nearby and look for clues (picture of eyes)
Step 3: Ask the teacher to repeat what was said (picture of teacher)

By (date), during a [[explicit instruction|practice session]], when given (2) verbal messages, (1) audible and (1) that is difficult to hear/understand, and asked to identify the message that is more difficult to hear, (name) will signal after hearing the message using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred expression mode]] (e.g. a communication device, adaptive switch, gesturing), and receive a [[reinforcers|reward]] upon completion, in (4 out of 5) practice sessions. *Example audible message:*
Teacher says, “It's going to rain today." *Example difficult to hear message:*
Teacher mumbles, “It's going to rain today.”

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Ask to Hear it Again

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Reinforcers|Reward]] students who need a little motivation to successfully complete this task. A small reward will signal that self-advocacy is important and should be celebrated. *Example rewards for this age group:*
• 5 minutes of iPad exploration
• Permission to watch a clip from a favorite TV show, movie
• Permission to listen to a favorite song
• Access to a sensory bin
• Sticker on a reward chart
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

udl_adaptations.text:
Use a [[anchor charts|listening chart]] to show students the steps to take if a verbal message is misheard/misunderstood. The chart can include at least 3 different steps that the student should take prior to asking for teacher assistance. Depending on the student's age and reading abilities, the chart can include written steps, illustrated steps, or both. Before asking students to use the chart independently, the teacher should thoroughly explain its purpose (i.e. to help the student become more independent).
*Example listening chart steps:*
Step 1: Ask a peer buddy to repeat what was said (picture of two friends)
Step 2: Observe people nearby and look for clues (picture of eyes)
Step 3: Ask the teacher to repeat what was said (picture of teacher)
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.2 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Highlight patterns, critical features, big ideas, and relationships
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.2 Highlight patterns, critical features, big ideas, and relationships

udl_adaptations.text: Modify this task so students can respond with a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]]. Instead of verbally asking for repetition of misheard auditory information, students can use a gesture, communication device, adaptive switch, or picture choices to indicate that something needs to be repeated. For example, if the student is instructed to signal when a verbal message is difficult to hear, he or she can raise a hand, point to a visual icon (e.g. an ear with a red line over it to designate something wasn't heard), or use a device to respond "No."
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example accommodations:** * Preferential seating
* Note taking assistance
* Access to a sound field system or personal FM system
**Example student response:** Student says, "Can I have a copy of the slides from the lesson? I don't want to miss anything that's on the test."
goals.goal_text: By (date), when presented with a difficult listening situation during school, (name) will ask for (1) accommodation that improves the ability to hear, and give (1) reason why it will help, in (4 out of 5) observed difficult listening situations.

objectives.example_text:
**Example teacher prompt:**

Teacher says, "Tell me what you need to hear better."
objectives.text: By (date), when presented with a difficult listening situation during school, given a [[verbal prompting|teacher prompt]], (name) will ask for (1) accommodation that improves the ability to hear, and give (1) reason why it will help, in (4 out of 5) observed difficult listening situations.

By (date), when presented with a difficult listening situation during school, given a [[verbal prompting|teacher prompt]] and a [[reference materials|list]] of (3) accommodation choices, (name) will ask for (1) of the accommodations, and give (1) reason why it will help, in (4 out of 5) observed difficult listening situations.

By (date), when presented with a difficult listening situation during school, given a [[verbal prompting|teacher prompt]] and (3) accommodation [[picture choices|picture choices]], (name) will select (1) accommodation that improves the ability to hear (e.g. by pointing, stating, using a communication device), and receive a [[reinforcers|reward]] upon completion, in (4 out of 5) observed difficult listening situations.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Ask for Hearing Needs to Be Met

udl_adaptations.text:
[[reinforcers|Reward]] students who need a little motivation to successfully complete this task. A small reward will signal that self-advocacy is important and should be celebrated. *Example rewards for this age group:*
• 5 minutes of iPad exploration
• 5 minutes of free time
• Permission to listen to a favorite song, watch a favorite clip
• Working/sitting near a friend for a specific task
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

udl_adaptations.text:
Create a [[reference materials|list of accommodations]] that students can reference. The list can contain between 2 and 10 accommodations, depending on an individual student's needs. Ask the student to glue it into the front page of an agenda, or laminate it and keep it in a desk or book bag for easy transport from class to class. *Example accommodations to include:*
• Preferential Seating
• Shut classroom door
• Close classroom window
• Turn off fan/heater
• Written notes
• Peer buddy
• Repetition
• Assistive technology
• Noise cancelling headphones
• Ear protection (i.e., earplugs)
• Sign Language interpreter
• Closed-Captioning
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 6.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Facilitate managing information and resources
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 6.3 Facilitate managing information and resources

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Verbal prompting|Prompt]] students to ask for an accommodation if they don't immediately do it on their own. For example, if a student seems disengaged because of a difficult listening environment, prompt with phrases such as:
"Maybe it's tough to hear today."
"Think of something that will help you be more interested."
"Let me know if there's anything you need."
Allowing students to choose their own accommodations promotes self-advocacy, and prompting allows the teacher to nudge students along without explicitly assigning an accommodation to a student who doesn't choose one immediately on their own.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example documents:** * Medical chart
* Audiogram
* Visual chart of the middle/inner ear **Example student response:** Student picks up audiogram and says, “This is the audiogram because it has the speech banana on it.”
goals.goal_text: By (date), when asked identify an audiogram from a group of (3) documents related to hearing loss, (name) will select the audiogram and list (1) defining characteristic, for (4 out of 5) document identification tasks.

objectives.text:
By (date), when asked identify an audiogram from a group of (3) documents related to hearing loss, after the teacher asks a [[guiding questions|guiding question]], (name) will select the audiogram and list (1) defining characteristic, for (4 out of 5) document identification tasks. *Example guiding question:*
Teacher asks, “Which document is the one that shows us your left and right ear hearing levels?”

By (date), when asked identify an audiogram from a group of (3) documents related to hearing loss, after the teacher [[verbal prompting|gives]] (1) defining characteristic to look for, (name) will select the audiogram, and receive a [[reinforcers|reward]] upon completion, for (4 out of 5) document identification tasks. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, "Look for the document that has a speech banana on it."

By (date), when asked identify an audiogram from a pair of (2) documents related to hearing loss, after the teacher shows a different, [[exemplar|example audiogram]] and asks a [[guiding questions|guiding question]], (name) will select the audiogram from the original pair, using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]], and receive a [[reinforcers|reward]] upon completion, for (4 out of 5) document identification tasks. *Example guiding question:*
Teacher asks, "Which of these looks just like the audiogram I showed you?"

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Recognize an Audiogram

udl_adaptations.text:
[[reinforcers|Reward]] students who need a little motivation to successfully complete this task. A small reward will signal that being able to identify an audiogram is important and should be celebrated. *Example rewards for this age group:*
• 5 minutes of iPad exploration
• Sticker on a rewards chart
• Permission to listen to a favorite song, watch a favorite clip
• Small eraser shaped like a character
• 5 minutes of a preferred quiet activity (e.g. coloring, looking at books)
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

udl_adaptations.text: Modify this task to allow students to use a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]]. Instead of verbally selecting the audiogram and describing a defining characteristic, students can respond nonverbally by gesturing, nodding in response to a yes/no question, activating an adaptive switch or using a communication device. For example, to elicit a yes/no response, the teacher can ask, “Is *this* one the audiogram?” If the student prefers to pick up or point to the document, the teacher can simply ask, "Which one of these is the audiogram?" Similarly, if the student uses a communication device, the teacher can ask questions that elicit student answers that have already been pre-programmed into the device.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Verbal prompting|Prompt]] students with an audiogram characteristic, especially if they haven't had a lot of past exposure to audiograms. The specific prompt will depend on the other documents the audiogram is grouped with, and should focus on what makes the audiogram stand out. *Example prompts include:*
• "Which paper has something that looks like a banana?"
• "Which document has two lines that show hearing for the left *and* right ears?
• "Which one looks like a graph?"
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example student action:**

Student resets the device. Student isn't sure it fixed the problem, and raises hand to ask teacher to help check.
goals.goal_text: By (date), when a hearing device stops working during school, (name) will independently choose and complete (1) troubleshooting action before asking the teacher for help, for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions.

objectives.text: By (date), given a [[visual task schedule|visual task schedule]] to reference, when a hearing device stops working during school, (name) will independently choose and complete (1) troubleshooting action before asking the teacher for help, for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions.

By (date), given a [[visual task schedule|visual task schedule]] to reference, when a hearing device stops working during school, (name) will choose and complete (1) troubleshooting action with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical teacher assist]], for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, “Turn the device off and reset,” while placing student’s hand on the reset button.

By (date), after a hearing device stops working, after the teacher [[think aloud|thinks aloud]] while making (1) troubleshooting action, when told to repeat the action, given (1) [[verbal prompting|guidance prompt]], (name) will complete the action with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical assist]] from the teacher and receive a [[reinforcers|reward]] upon completion, for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Troubleshoot Before Asking for Help

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Reinforcers|Reward]] students who troubleshoot a malfunctioning hearing device. This will encourage students who continuously rely on adult intervention to be more independent. For students in this age group, learning to care for a personal device is a step toward effective self-advocacy. *Example rewards include:*
• A sticker chart of troubleshooting actions (written or illustrated). Award a sticker for each completed action.
• A small preferred item or toy (e.g. pencil with characters).
• 5 minutes of a preferred activity (e.g. playing a word game with a peer).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

udl_adaptations.text:
A [[think aloud|think aloud]] allows students to watch and listen to an experienced person troubleshoot a device malfunction. After the think aloud, ask the student to mimic the troubleshooting steps. With practice, the student will gradually gain independence, and be able to troubleshoot without a think aloud demonstration. *Example think aloud:*
Teacher says, “The hearing aid isn’t working. I think I'd better check the battery. First, I'll open the battery door by pulling on this tiny tab. Then, I pop the battery out...like this! Now, I need to get a new battery out of the package and place the new battery in with the small circle facing down. Now, I'll close the battery door and listen for the beeps. Your turn - now you try!"
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.2 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Highlight patterns, critical features, big ideas, and relationships
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.2 Highlight patterns, critical features, big ideas, and relationships

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Graduated guidance|Physically assist]] young students to help them gain confidence when troubleshooting. Troubleshooting can occur in the back of the room where extra supplies are stored, and the DHH teacher or another trained adult can help complete this process. *Troubleshooting actions that may be difficult for this age group include:*
• Opening the battery door with a tool.
• Cleaning the wax out of the mold with the cleaning tool.
• Removing the battery door on a cochlear implant.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example student action:**

Student resets the device and says, "It worked."
goals.goal_text: By (date), when a hearing device stops working during school, (name) will independently choose and complete (1) troubleshooting action, and identify whether or not it was successful before asking the teacher for help, for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions.

objectives.text:
By (date), when a hearing device stops working during school, given a [[verbal prompting|teacher prompt]], (name) will independently choose and complete (1) troubleshooting action, and identify whether or not it was successful before asking the teacher for help, for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, "Check that your device is working."

By (date), when a hearing device stops working during school, given a [[verbal prompting|teacher prompt]] and [[visual task schedule|visual checklist]] to reference, (name) will independently choose and complete (1) troubleshooting action, and identify whether or not it was successful before asking the teacher for help, for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions.

By (date), when a hearing device stops working during school, after the teacher [[think aloud|thinks aloud]] while making (1) troubleshooting action, when told to repeat the action, given (1) [[verbal prompting|guidance prompt]], (name) will complete the action with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical assist]] from the teacher and receive a [[reinforcers|reward]] upon completion, for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions. *Example physical teacher assistance:*
-Teacher opens battery door, hands student batteries.
-Student independently tests battery.
-Student independently puts batteries back into the device.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Independently Troubleshoot Device

udl_adaptations.text:
Give students a [[visual task schedule|visual checklist]] that serves as a basic troubleshooting “how-to." Personal hearing devices differ; therefore, the teacher should create a troubleshooting guide for each corresponding student hearing device. Teachers can access troubleshooting guides by contacting the parent/guardian and/or Educational Audiologist prior to the start of the school year, and use it to create a more student-friendly visual checklist. Visual checklists can include topics such as: • How to change the device batteries.
• How to test the device batteries to verify if they are dead or working.
• How to clean the device.
• How to turn the device on/off.
• When to alert an adult (Educational Audiologist, teacher, parent) about a device issue.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

udl_adaptations.text: [[verbal prompting|Prompt]] students to check devices when there are signs of a malfunction. Signals that warrant a device check include: flashing indicator lights, warning sounds (e.g. the student's device “beeps”) or missed auditory information. Students who wear two devices, for example, may not be able to immediately tell if one device needs attention, and a verbal prompt is a quick, easy way to alert them that there is an issue. The prompt should be brief and direct, and students should know what to do once they receive the prompt. For example, if the issue is a dead battery, once prompted by the teacher, the student should quickly move to a designated area in the classroom (e.g. a cubby/container that holds extra batteries) and/or out of the classroom (e.g., student locker, charging station in a predetermined location, etc.) to change the battery, and return to the assigned task immediately after.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 1.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer ways of customizing the display of information
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 1.1 Offer ways of customizing the display of information

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Graduated guidance|Physical teacher assistance]] can help students gain confidence when troubleshooting. Troubleshooting can occur wherever extra supplies are stored, and the DHH teacher or another trained adult can help complete this process. *Troubleshooting actions that may require physical assistance include:*
• Cleaning student earmold/earpiece to remove obstruction that may minimize sound.
• Changing and/or testing the battery life.
• Verifying if device has been set on “mute” mode.
• Restoring sound/volume on device and/or changing programs.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example prompt:**

Peer asks, "You can't hear?"

**Example student response:**

Student says, "I have unilateral hearing loss, so I hear fine with my right ear. It's just hard for me to hear when there's a lot of background noise."
goals.goal_text: By (date), when asked to describe their personal hearing loss to a familiar or unfamiliar person, (name) will identify the type of hearing loss (i.e. bilateral or unilateral), and (1) thing that is either difficult to hear or makes hearing difficult, for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss conversations.

objectives.text:
By (date), when asked to describe their personal hearing loss to a familiar or unfamiliar person, given (1) [[guiding questions|guiding question]], (name) will identify the type of hearing loss (i.e. bilateral or unilateral), and (1) thing that is either difficult to hear or makes hearing difficult, for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss conversations. *Example guiding questions:*
“What type of hearing loss do you have?”
“What makes it difficult for you to hear?”
“Which sounds are hard for you to hear?”

By (date), when asked to describe their personal hearing loss during a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 conversation]] with a [[familiar people, places, and things|teacher]], given (1) [[guiding questions|guiding question]] and a [[visual aids|speech banana]] to reference, (name) will identify the type of hearing loss (i.e. bilateral or unilateral), and (1) thing that is either difficult to hear or makes hearing difficult, for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss conversations.

Firstyears.org's example of an [[http://www.firstyears.org/lib/banfamily.gif|illustrated speech banana.]]

By (date), after a teacher [[explicit instruction|explains]] (name)’s hearing loss data using a personalized, illustrated [[visual aids|speech banana]], given (4) [[picture choices|picture choices]] of sounds included on the speech banana, and asked to identify (1) that is difficult to hear, (name) will use a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]] to select the answer, for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss conversations.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Identify Type of Hearing Loss

udl_adaptations.text:
If a student isn't able to immediately respond when asked to describe their personal hearing loss, ask a [[guiding questions|guiding questions]]. A student/teacher conversation with guiding questions could look something like this:
Teacher asks, “What type of hearing loss do you have?”
Student says, “I have hearing loss in both of my ears."
Teacher asks, “What makes it difficult for you to hear?”
Student says, "I have a hard time hearing people talk when they cover their mouths."
Teacher asks, “What sound is hard for you to hear?”
Student says, "I have a difficult time hearing low sounding noises, like bass in music or someone with a low voice.”
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Develop self-assessment and reflection
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.3 Develop self-assessment and reflection

udl_adaptations.text: Allow students to use a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]] when answering questions about personal hearing loss. To start, ask students to identify a sound that is difficult to hear from a group of picture choices. Students can nod, point, signal with a thumbs up/down, use a communication device, eye gaze, and/or activate an [[adaptive switches|adaptive switch]] to respond. For example, after asking which of 4 sounds depicted on an illustrated speech banana is difficult to hear, a student who has difficulty hearing high-frequency sounds points to the bird.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: If students have difficulty answering direct questions about their personal hearing loss, or would prefer to respond nonverbally, provide a personalized [[visual aids|speech banana]] so they have a visual representation of their hearing loss to reference. After ensuring the student understands how to read the speech banana, ask a guiding question to accompany the information presented, such as, "What do you notice about the line that represents your right ear?" With prior knowledge of how to interpret data on a speech banana, the student can answer with a statement such as, "It shows that the hearing in my right ear is normal." If a student prefers to respond nonverbally, ask questions that can elicit a nonverbal response, such as, “Which of these 4 sounds on the speech banana do you have difficulty hearing?" Then, the student can select a response by gesturing to the answer.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.5 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Illustrate through multiple media
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.5 Illustrate through multiple media

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example prompt:**

Peer asks, "You need hearing aids?"

**Example student response:**

Student says, "Yes, I have moderate bilateral hearing loss. It's congenital."
goals.goal_text: By (date), when asked to describe their personal hearing loss to a familiar or unfamiliar person, (name) will identify the type (i.e. bilateral or unilateral), degree (i.e. normal, mild, moderate, moderately-severe, severe or profound) and cause (e.g. TBI, chronic otitis media, congenital), using the correct terminology, for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss conversations.

objectives.text: By (date), when asked to describe their personal hearing loss in a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 conversation with a teacher]], (name) will identify the type (i.e. bilateral or unilateral), degree (i.e. normal, mild, moderate, moderately-severe, severe or profound) and cause (e.g. TBI, chronic otitis media, congenital), using the correct terminology, for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss conversations.

By (date), when asked to describe their personal hearing loss in a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 conversation with a teacher]], given a [[glossary|list]] of hearing loss terminology, (name) will identify the type (i.e. bilateral or unilateral), degree (i.e. normal, mild, moderate, moderately-severe, severe or profound) and cause (e.g. TBI, chronic otitis media, congenital), using the correct terminology, for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss conversations. *Example hearing loss terminology:*
• Bilateral- hearing loss in both right and left ears.
• Unilateral- hearing loss in only 1 ear.
• Congenital- hearing loss was present at birth.
• Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI)- something happened to the head/brain that resulted in hearing loss.
• Chronic Otitis Media- a severe ear infection that happened once or multiple times that resulted in hearing loss.

By (date), when asked to describe their personal hearing loss in a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 conversation with a teacher]], given a personalized [[visual aids|speech banana]] to reference, after the teacher [[modeling routines, skills, and procedures|demonstrates]] the task, (name) will identify the type (i.e. bilateral or unilateral) and degree (i.e. normal, mild, moderate, moderately-severe, severe or profound) using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]], for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss conversations. *Example preferred mode of expression:*
Student points to right ear data, then the word "moderate" on the speech banana.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Explain Hearing Loss Using Terminology

udl_adaptations.text: Provide a personalized [[glossary|list]] of hearing loss terminology, and if needed, include definitions for each term. It is essential that students utilize the correct hearing loss terminology when describing personal hearing loss. To convey this idea to the student, the teacher can say something such as,“It’s better to use correct terminology, because when we misuse vocabulary, people may make an assumption that we don’t know what we are talking about. If you use the correct hearing loss terminology, then people will view you as knowledgeable about your hearing loss and take your words more seriously.”
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 1.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer ways of customizing the display of information
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 1.1 Offer ways of customizing the display of information

udl_adaptations.text: Have a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 conversation]] with a student to discuss their hearing loss. High school students often are self-conscious about their hearing loss and choose not to associate with it. Therefore, to decrease their anxiety and foster collaboration, have the conversation during a class period when students are doing independent work and/or whenever they will not be singled out from their peers. To begin the conversation, state, “(Name), I was wondering if you could tell me more about your hearing loss, like the type, kind and etiology? I want to be able to better serve you as your teacher.” If the student requires additional support, provide a personalized [[visual aids|speech banana]] for him or her to reference during the conversation.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster collaboration and communication
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.3 Foster collaboration and communication

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of verbally recognizing a personal hearing loss, a student can use a [[preferred modes of expression|nonverbal communication method]], such as gesturing, nodding in response to a yes/no question, activating an adaptive switch, or signaling with a thumbs up/down. For example, to elicit a yes/no response, the teacher can ask, “Do you hear better with your right ear?” Similarly, if the student uses a communication device, the teacher can ask questions that elicit student answers that have already been pre-programmed into the device. For students who prefer to communicate using written words or images, the teacher can supply an illustrated speech banana (here is Hearinglink.org's [[https://www.hearinglink.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/speech-banana-800.jpg|example]]). Students can point to, pick up, or use eye gaze to indicate their selection.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example:**

Tell me what you heard in the story, be sure to include one specific detail.
goals.goal_text: By (date), after listening to (1) minute of a grade-level passage without access to the written text, when asked to paraphrase what was heard, (name) will respond with an answer that includes at least (1) specific detail heard in the passage, for (4 out of 5) passages.

objectives.text: By (date), after listening to (1) minute of an [[modified text|instructional-level]] passage without access to the written text, when shown a passage-related [[visual aids|picture]] and asked to paraphrase what was heard, (name) will respond with an answer that includes at least (1) specific detail heard in the passage, for (4 out of 5) passages.

By (date), after listening to (30) seconds of a [[modified text|instructional-level]] passage without access to the written text and paired with a passage-related [[visual aids|picture]] with (1) [[verbal prompting|verbal cue]] to listen for a specific detail, when asked an explicit comprehension question (i.e. answer is stated directly in the text), (name) will state the correct answer, for (4 out of 5) comprehension questions.

objectives.example_text:
**Example Verbal Cue:**

Teacher says, "After I read the passage, I'm going to ask you a question about what the character is baking."

**Example Explicit Comprehension Question:**

"In the passage, [[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-zPd837yVcwOFFtLXdWYmtuSVk/view|"Star of the Week"]], what snack is the narrator baking with their mom?"
objectives.text: By (date), after listening to (1) sentence of a [[social narratives|personal-interest story]] without access to the written text and paired with a related [[visual aids|picture]], when asked an explicit comprehension question (i.e. the answer is directly stated in the sentence), (name) will select the answer from (2) [[picture choices|picture choices]] using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]] (e.g. pointing, eye-gaze), for (4 out of 5) explicit comprehension questions.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Paraphrase Auditory Information

udl_adaptations.text:
Show a passage-related [[visual aids|picture]] to help students fill in any gaps that they didn’t hear or understand when the teacher read the passage aloud. The picture can be an illustration, photograph, or image found on the internet and can be displayed on a card, paper, projected on the classroom whiteboard, or displayed on a computer or tablet screen. For example, read aloud the following excerpt from "Lord of the Flies" by William Golding:
*“The space under the palm trees was full of noise and movement. Ralph was on his feet too, shouting for quiet, but no one heard him. All at once the crowd swayed toward the island and was gone—following Jack. Even the tiny children went and did their best among the leaves and broken branches. Ralph was left, holding the conch, with no one but Piggy.”
* Before asking about why Ralph has difficulty keeping the attention of the group, display an image of Ralph yelling (here's an [[https://wondersinthedark.files.wordpress.com/2015/09/lord-6.jpg|example]]).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.5 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Illustrate through multiple media
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.5 Illustrate through multiple media

udl_adaptations.text:
Use a [[social narratives|personal-interest]] story that uses the student as the main character and incorporates [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar details]]. When the focus of a skill is understanding auditory language, removing barriers related to familiarity or preference will increase the student's ability to focus on the task at hand. These stories can include events that have happened in the past and everyday routines. To further increase engagement, take pictures of the student doing these activities, and use the photos to accompany the read-aloud. *Example Sentence:
• Tomás went to the zoo yesterday.
• Chun rode the bus to school.
• Val ate a sandwich for lunch.*
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.2 Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity

udl_adaptations.text:
Have students use [[preferred modes of expression|nonverbal modes of communication]] to answer questions. Many times students with hearing loss and other delays need nonverbal ways to communicate. Students can indicate understanding of a story and answer questions about the story by pointing to a picture, using a communication device or nodding yes or no.
