Pictures should match the story content and only one picture presented should be the correct answer to the question. Pictures from a book, clipart, actual photographs or drawings can all be used a a visual response option. *Example Story: Life in the Desert
Pictures: desert plants (cactus, shrubs), jungle plants (trees, bushes, vines)
Question: What grows in a desert?
Student: point to desert plants picture* *Teacher: reads story about a farm.
Shows student a picture of a cow and a picture of a monkey.
Teacher: Holds up monkey picture “Does this animal live at the farm?”
Student: Nods head NO or uses communication device to say NO.
Teacher: Holds up picture of the cow, :Does this animal live at the farm?”
Student: Nods YES or uses communication device to answer YES.*
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example Teacher Prompt:** “Tell me the word in this sentence that is a homonym: ‘I have two dogs.’”.
**Example Student Response:** “Two”
**Example Follow-up Teacher Prompt:** “Yes, two. What does ‘two’ mean in the sentence, ‘I have two dogs’?”.
**Example Student Response:** “It means the number two.”
goals.goal_text: By (date), after a sentence using a [[familiar text|familiar homonym]] is said aloud, when asked to identify and define the homonym, (name) will [[preferred modes of expression|verbally]] state the word and explain its meaning within the given sentence, for (4 out of 5) sentences.

objectives.text:
By (date), when a sentence using a [[familiar text|familiar homonym]] is said aloud and given a corresponding [[visual aids|illustration]], when asked to identify and define the homonym, (name) will [[preferred modes of expression|verbally]] state the word and explain its meaning within the given sentence, for (4 out of 5) sentences. *Example Sentence:*
“I have two dogs.” *Example Illustration:*
A person standing next to two dogs.

By (date), after a sentence using a [[familiar text|familiar homonym]] is said aloud and given a corresponding [[visual aids|illustration]], when asked to define the homonym, (name) will [[preferred modes of expression|verbally]] explain the homonym's meaning within the given sentence, for (4 out of 5) sentences. *Example Sentence:*
“I have two dogs.” *Example Prompt:*
“Tell me the meaning of the homonym ‘two’ that was used in the sentence.”
*Example Illustration:* A person standing next to two dogs.

By (date), given a [[verbal prompting|verbal cue]] to attend to a specific, [[familiar text|familiar homonym]] and after a 2-3 word phrase using the word is read aloud, when asked to define the homonym, (name) will select the [[visual aids|illustration]] that best represents the meaning of the word, within the context of the sentence, from a set of (2) [[multiple choice|choices]], for (4 out of 5) sentences. *Example Verbal Cue:*
Which picture shows what “two” means in the following phrase?” *Example Sentence:*
“Two dogs.” *Example Illustration Options:*
Two dogs
One dog

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Aurally Identify and Define a Homonym

udl_adaptations.text: [[Modified assignment|Modify]] this task by giving students the familiar, target homonym before reading the sentence aloud instead of asking them to identify the homonym within the sentence on their own. For example, if the homonym is “pair,” tell the students, “Tell me the meaning of ‘pair’ in the following sentence.”. Then proceed with reading the sentence aloud (e.g. “This pair of socks is blue.”). By giving students the homonym ahead of time, the student may solely focus on figuring out its meaning within the given sentence.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Vary demands and resources to optimize challenge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.2 Vary demands and resources to optimize challenge

udl_adaptations.text: Use [[visual aids|visual images]] to support the identification and explanation of a homonym in a sentence. For example, when a student is tasked with identifying and explaining the meaning of “pair” in the sentence, “This pair of socks is blue.”, the teacher can present a generic image of a [[http://content.mycutegraphics.com/graphics/clothing/blue-pair-of-socks-clip-art.png |pair of blue socks]]. When verbally stating the homonym in the context of the sentence, hold up the corresponding visual image. With practice, students will build foundations for independent auditory discrimination of similar-sounding words and phrases.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.5 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Illustrate through multiple media
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.5 Illustrate through multiple media

udl_adaptations.text: After hearing a homonym read aloud within a 2-3 word phrase, allow students to choose the image that represents its meaning from 2 [[multiple choice|options]]. Some students have difficulty hearing individual words within a sentence. By giving them the illustrated variations of a homonym, students can focus on the context of the sentence to determine which word is being used. For example, for the phrase, “Pair of socks", present images of a [[http://content.mycutegraphics.com/graphics/clothing/blue-pair-of-socks-clip-art.png |pair of socks]] and a [[https://www.organicfacts.net/wp-content/uploads/pear.jpg |pear]]. Then ask students to select which image shows what a "pair of socks" means.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

goals.goal_example_text:
**Sample Discussion:** Teacher: What did you do this weekend?
Student: I went to the beach and made a sand castle.
T: That sounds like fun!
S: I put seashells on my castle too!
T: That is a great idea. I like to use sticks on my sandcastles for towers.
S: I used sticks to dig a hole for the water around my castle.
goals.goal_text: By (date), during a 1:1 conversation with a teacher, in a whole-class setting, when it is their turn to speak (e.g. asked a question, a natural pause in discussion), (name) will contribute a (1)-sentence, on-topic response or question, for (4 of 5) turns in the conversation.

objectives.text: By (date), in a [[ auditory preferential seating | quiet setting ]], during a 1:1 conversation with a teacher about a [[ familiar people, places, and things | familiar topic ]], when given a [[visual cueing|non-verbal cue]] to speak (e.g. teacher turns entire body toward student), (name) will contribute a (1)-sentence, on-topic response or questions, for (4 out 5) turns in the conversation.

By (date), in a [[ auditory preferential seating | quiet setting ]], during a 1:1 conversation with a teacher about a [[ familiar people, places, and things | familiar topic]], when presented with a [[visual cue cards|picture prompt]] to speak (e.g. [[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-zPd837yVcwaFg5QjZiQ0tMSkk/view|your turn]]), (name) will contribute a (3)-word, on-topic response when holding the turn-taking object (e.g. vocally, signing), for (4 out 5) turns in the conversation.

By (date), when playing a [[ language-based games | conversation building game ]] with a teacher (e.g. [[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-zPd837yVcwLTVLc2hlMHVtSTA/view|Guess Who?]], [[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-zPd837yVcweWc2RHVFN001UjQ/view|Go Fish!]]) in a [[ auditory preferential seating | quiet setting ]], using a [[talking chips|conversation turn-taking object]] (i.e. student speaks when holding the object, listens when object is held by another person), (name) will contribute by pressing a button on an [[adaptive switches|AAC Device]] with a [[modified assignment|pre-recorded]] response, for (4 out of 5) turns in the conversation.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Take Turns in a 1:1 Discussion

udl_adaptations.text: Allow a student to [[ modified assignment | take just two turns]], rather than three, during a conversation when learning to identify the need to respond to a question or comment in a conversational setting. Students may have learned to identify that a question was asked in a structured learning environment and be able to answer a direct question, but social conversation settings require different skills to be used (e.g. identify that a conversation is starting, take turns, ask questions to keep a conversation going, respond to the conversation promptly and correctly). As students improve at identifying that a social conversation is taking place, allow them to respond only once until responses are accurate and they are able to take another turn in the conversation. If the student doesn’t provide an on-topic response, use a supporting visual with follow-up questions (e.g. a calendar if you are asking what the student did yesterday), or alter the question to make it more concrete (e.g. “You painted apples this morning in art class. What color did you paint?).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.4 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Maximize transfer and generalization
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.4 Maximize transfer and generalization

udl_adaptations.text:
Use a [[ auditory preferential seating | separate quiet setting ]] to start teaching conversation skills to younger students. Social conversations require a student to use listening skills as well as visual skills to understand the entire message (e.g. words said, voice tone, body language, facial expressions). A separate quiet location allows a student to have auditory access to all of the information as well as less distractions to allow them to focus on the visual cues. A quiet location also allows for direct instruction opportunities to cue students, repeat the conversation starter or give them verbal models to accurately respond to a conversation starter. *Example Quiet Locations:*
• Empty classroom
• Office
• Therapy room
• Large closet
• Corner of a room when it’s a quieter work time
*Example Teacher Cue for Conversation Mistake:*
Teacher: Tell me about your summer?
Student: It was good. We went to the water park.
T: The waterpark is fun! What did you like best at the water park?
S: The polar bears.
T: Ohh I asked: What did you like best at the water park? Did you see polar bears at the water park?
S: No I saw polar bears at the zoo. We went there too. I liked the slides best at the water park.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

udl_adaptations.text: Use [[ language-based games | games ]] such as showing the student a vocabulary card or a picture of a scene (e.g. farm, ocean, camping) and asking them to tell you about what they see. There are many times students don’t hear the complete conversational message and either don't realize it is their turn to respond, respond incorrectly due to missed information, or haven’t had enough exposure or practice time to understand and apply social conversation etiquette rules (e.g. wait for turn to talk, identify and answer a question, ask a question back to keep conversation going). Games such as Candyland or Trouble can be used to keep a student motivated to continue practice taking turns in a conversation. Have conversation starter cards printed and ready. Take a turn using the conversation starter card and when conversation is done, have the student take a turn at the selected game. Using games on top of the conversation starter cards/games can add another layer of fun to keep a student motivated to talk and practice taking conversational turns.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.2 Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example sentence:**

“She couldn’t bear the thought of living so far away.”

**Example prompt:**

“What does it mean that she couldn’t ‘bear’ the thought?”

**Example student response:**

“She can’t stand it.”
goals.goal_text: By (date), during academic instruction, when the teacher verbally states a homophone/homonym in context and asks for the meaning of the word, (name) will define the word, for (4 out of 5) new words.

objectives.example_text:
**Example sentence:**

“She couldn’t bear the thought of living so far away.”

**Example guiding question:**

"How do you think she feels about moving?"
objectives.text: By (date), during academic instruction, when the teacher verbally states a homophone/homonym in context and asks for the meaning of the word, (name) will define the word, with (1) [[guiding questions|guiding question]] from the teacher, for (4 out of 5) homophones/homonyms.

objectives.example_text:
**Example sentence:**

“She couldn’t bear the thought of living so far away.”

**Example answer choices:**

* "Bear" is a type of animal
* "Bear" means to tolerate
* "Bear" means to run
objectives.text: By (date), during academic instruction, when the teacher verbally states a homophone/homonym in context and asks which of (3) [[multiple choice|answer choices]] represents the meaning of the word, (name) will define the word by selecting the correct answer choice (e.g. verbally, pointing) with (1) [[guiding questions|guiding question]] from the teacher, for (4 out of 5) homophones/homonyms.

objectives.example_text:
**Example sentence:**

“The teacher is male.”

**Example prompt:**

“What does the word male mean, here?”

**Example illustrated answer choices:**

* A male teacher
* A mailbox
objectives.text: By (date), during a [[language-based games|language-based game]], given (2) [[picture choices|illustrated answer choices]], when the teacher verbally states a homophone in a [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar]] context and asks for the meaning of the word, (name) will identify which of the (2) illustrated definitions represents the definition, for (4 out of 5) homophones.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Use Context to Define Multi-Meaning Words

udl_adaptations.text: Make a homonym [[language-based games|game]] to keep students engaged. This can be organized with a small group, or even during individual instruction. To begin, give students a list of homonyms from a paragraph that will be read aloud. As the paragraph is read aloud, have teams of students (or an individual student, depending on the setting) use context clues to write the inferred meanings for each homonym, then share out and award point to teams for successful definitions. Repeat the process for a few rounds, and award a prize to the winning team - if a student is playing individually, award a prize if he or she reaches a previously-determined points goal.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster collaboration and communication
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.3 Foster collaboration and communication

udl_adaptations.text: Use [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar]] topics when teaching students how to use context to differentiate homonyms: especially at first, students with hearing loss need to learn to identify homonyms within familiar context. For example, if a student was given the sentence “The student is male,"  he or she would likely already have some background knowledge of what it means to be "male," and understand that the homonym,"mail," wouldn't fit within the topic. Therefore, when asked to define the word, the student would say something like: “Male means a boy."
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

udl_adaptations.text: [[Multiple choice|Multiple answer choices]] can help students with hearing loss be more successful when trying to figure out what a homonym means. The number of choices can vary based on an individual student’s needs, and the choices can include extremely diverse definitions (less difficult), or all of the chosen homonym's meanings (more difficult). For example, for the sentence “The child's bare feet kicked the sand,” with the homonym "bare," the answer choices could be: "happy," "to be naked/ without clothes," or "an animal." These choices contain two definitions that could potentially work based on the word's sound, so it forces the student to use context to determine meaning.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_text: By (date), given a resource with information on hearing assistive technology trends (e.g. a magazine, website), (name) will identify the cost and availability of (1) device that is compatible with current hearing needs, for (4 out of 5) device exploration opportunities.

objectives.text: By (date), during a [[student-teacher conference|discussion]] with a teacher, given a resource with information on hearing assistive technology trends (e.g. a magazine, website), (name) will identify the cost and availability of (1) device that is compatible with current hearing needs, for (4 out of 5) device exploration opportunities.

By (date), during a [[student-teacher conference|discussion]] with a teacher, given a resource (e.g. a magazine, website) with (3) targeted [[Picture Choices|picture choices]] of hearing assistive technology devices, (name) will identify the cost and availability of (1) device that is compatible with current hearing needs, for (4 out of 5) device exploration opportunities. *Example picture choices:*
• Personal FM System
• Bluetooth Device
• Hearing Loop *Example teacher prompt:*
"Which of these is compatible with your current device?"

By (date), during a [[student-teacher conference|discussion]] with a teacher or provider, given a resource (e.g. a magazine, website) with (3) targeted [[picture choices|picture choices]] of hearing assistive technology devices, (name) will [[modified assignment|identify the device]] that is compatible with current hearing needs (e.g. by pointing, nodding “yes” to a teacher’s question), for (4 out of 5) attempts.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Research Personal Device Options

udl_adaptations.text:
Lead a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 discussion]] about new devices on the market. To start, give the student a resource that includes images and product information about various current devices. Once the student identifies a device of interest, facilitate with questions, such as: • “Is this device compatible with your current hearing equipment (i.e. BAHA, CI or hearing aid?”
• “How much does this device cost?”
• “Why would this device be helpful to you?” Questions like these will help create awareness of the devices currently available, where and how they can be purchased, and their relative costs.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster collaboration and communication
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.3 Foster collaboration and communication

udl_adaptations.text:
[[modified assignment|Modify]] this lesson to accommodate non-verbal students. To begin, give students picture choices of different devices, and ask them to gesture or nod in response to verbal questions. The pictures can be circled or highlighted in a sales magazine, or printed from a website. When possible, include written information about each device with the picture (e.g. cost, description, specifications). In relation to this task, ask students to demonstrate understanding of their hearing needs by identifying 1 device that is compatible with their current hearing equipment from the pictures. *Implementation example:*
• Teacher says, “Show me a device from this page that is compatible with your hearing equipment (e.g. BAHA, CI or hearing aids).” Student points to a compatible device.
• Teacher says, “Show me the cost of this device.” Student points to the written cost of the identified device.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text:
Offer colorful, detailed [[picture choices|pictures]] of hearing assistive technology (HAT) devices to help students recognize what's available. Some resources could include:
• HearWI.org's [[https://hearwi.org/best-sellers/| "Shop" page]]
• Harris Communications' Annual Magazine or Harris Communications' [[http://www.harriscomm.com|website]]
• Articles like "The Complete Guide to Hearable Technology" from Everyday Hearing's [[https://www.everydayhearing.com/hearing-technology/articles/hearables/|blog]].
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.5 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Illustrate through multiple media
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.5 Illustrate through multiple media

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example teacher prompt:**

“Can you explain when it's hard to hear during Mrs. Larson’s math class?”

**Example student response:**

"During group work when my table group is talking a lot.”
goals.goal_text: By (date), when asked to identify why hearing could be difficult during an upcoming school activity (e.g. group work in math class), (name) will identify a possible situation and correctly describe why hearing could be difficult (e.g. background noise from group members), for (4 out of 5) example difficult listening situations.

objectives.text:
By (date), when asked to identify why hearing could be difficult during an upcoming school activity (e.g. group work in math class), after the teacher asks (1) [[guiding questions|guiding question]], (name) will identify a possible situation and correctly describe why hearing could be difficult (e.g. background noise from group members), for (4 out of 5) example difficult listening situations. *Example teacher prompt:*
“Can you explain when it's hard to hear during Mrs. Larson’s math class?” *Example guiding question:*
“What activity are you usually doing when it’s difficult to hear?"

By (date), when asked to identify why hearing could be difficult during an upcoming school activity (e.g. group work in math class), given (3) [[multiple choice|answer choices]] and asked (1) [[guiding questions|guiding question]], (name) will identify which of the (3) answer choices is the possible difficult situation, for (4 out of 5) example difficult listening situations. *Example activity:*
Math class *Example answer choices:*
• During Mrs. Larson’s lesson
• During station time
• When working with an elbow partner *Example student response:*
Student says, "During station time."

By (date), given a [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar]] [[visual task schedule|visual task schedule]] with (3) tasks, and asked to identify which task could present a possible difficult hearing situation, (name) will identify the possible difficult hearing situation (e.g. by pointing, stating, using an [[adaptive switches|adaptive switch]]), for (4 out of 5) example difficult listening situations.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Anticipate Difficult Hearing Situations

udl_adaptations.text: Use a student's classroom or individual daily [[visual task schedule|task schedule]] to talk about difficult listening environments. To start, show students the daily task pictures for environments like gym class, silent reading time, and independent work time. Ask the student: “During which activity do you have the most trouble hearing?”  In this example, the student would point to the gym class picture. Include one difficult hearing environment and one or two easy hearing environments. After students can identify the obvious choice, move forward with a discussion about *why* it is hard to hear in that setting.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize individual choice and autonomy
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.1 Optimize individual choice and autonomy

udl_adaptations.text:
When asking students to identify potential difficult listening environments, give [[multiple choice|multiple answer choices]] as a support. Be sure that one of the answer choices represents a difficult hearing setting, and the others do not, which will make the correct answer clear to the student. *Example answer choices:*
• Music class
• Library
• Reading time Here, the obvious answer is music class, since playing instruments and singing are all loud activities.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text:
Ask [[guiding questions|guiding questions]] to help students develop a verbal response. Guiding questions should be highly supportive at the start of the conversation, and become less supportive as the student learns how to identify and describe why it is difficult to hear in a specific environment. For example, a highly supportive guiding question will help the student initially identify which situations could present potential hearing difficulties:
*Example highly supportive guiding question:*
"When is it difficult for you to hear in math class?" *Example student response:*
"During station time." A slightly less supportive guiding question can be used if a student identifies math station time as a difficult hearing situation but can't explain why: *Example less supportive guiding question:*
"What happens during math station time?" *Example student response:*
“All the kids are in groups, working and talking to each other.”
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.3 Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example difficult hearing situations due to seating arrangement:** * Near the projector
* Near a loud group of students
* Too close to a speaker
* Near a fan
* Near the heater
**Example student response:** Student raises hand and says, "I can't hear over here."
goals.goal_text: By (date), after recognizing a current seating arrangement is causing a difficult hearing situation during a school activity, (name) will notify the teacher, for (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations.

objectives.text:
By (date), after using a teacher's [[guiding questions|guiding question]] to recognize a current seating arrangement is causing a difficult hearing situation during a school activity, (name) will notify the teacher that it is difficult to hear, for (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations. *Example guiding question:*
"Is your seat too far away?" *Example student response:*
"Yes."

By (date), after using the teacher's [[guiding questions|guiding question]] to recognize a current seating arrangement is causing a difficult hearing situation during a school activity, when the teacher gives (2) alternate seating [[multiple choice|choices]], (name) will choose the placement that most improves the ability to hear, for (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations.

By (date), when a current seating arrangement is causing a difficult hearing situation during a school activity,  given (2) alternate seating location [[multiple choice|choices]] that are both [[noise reduction in the classroom|optimal for hearing]], (name) will choose (1) of the alternate locations using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]], (e.g. communication device, nodding, stating), for (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Notify Teacher Seat Change is Needed

udl_adaptations.text: If a student doesn’t independently recognize that a seating assignment is causing a difficult hearing situation, ask a few [[guiding questions|guiding questions]]. For example, if a student who is seated near a fan isn’t participating in a class discussion (but usually does), the teacher do a quick check for auditory understanding by asking something such as, “(Name), can you repeat the answer to the problem?” The student might immediately say “No, I didn't hear,” but if not, follow up with another guiding question: “Is there something about your current seat that is making it difficult to hear?” If the student still has trouble, pair a guiding question with 2 alternate seating choices, and ask, “Which of these seating locations will help you to better hear the discussion?” Instead of simply telling the student to switch seats, guiding questions like these lead the student to recognize difficult hearing situations with a little more independence.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.3 Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation

udl_adaptations.text:
Give the student alternate seating [[multiple choice|choices]] that are optimal for hearing. The choices will differ depending upon the type of setting (e.g. gym, cafeteria, auditorium, classroom), and will also differ for each student. Some students don't function well “up-front” in a classroom, while others benefit from close proximity, for example. *Example alternate seating locations include:*
Gymnasium:
• Sitting/standing up front near the speaker/teacher
• Sitting on the middle of the bench
• Positioning to face the teacher
Auditorium:
• Sitting in a front row of the auditorium seating
• Sitting in a middle row of the front section of the auditorium
• Sitting in the middle section, away from the speakers
Classroom:
• Sitting near the teacher/speaker
• Moving to the back of the classroom where student distraction has been minimized
• Sitting at a table for independent work to be closer to the speaker/teacher
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: Modify this task to allow students to use a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]]. Instead of verbally asking the teacher to change seats, a student can use a nonverbal communication method, such as gesturing, nodding in response to a yes/no question, activating an adaptive switch or using a communication device. For example, to elicit a yes/no response, the teacher can ask, “Do you think sitting at the end of the semi-circle, near me, would help you hear the story better?” Similarly, if the student uses a communication device, the teacher can ask questions that elicit student answers that have already been pre-programmed into the device. For students who prefer to communicate using images, the teacher can supply picture choices of alternate seating locations and ask them to choose the seating arrangement that works best. Students can point to, pick up, or use eye gaze to indicate their selection.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Develop self-assessment and reflection
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.3 Develop self-assessment and reflection

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example question:**

Classmate asks, "What is that on your ear?"

**Example student explanations:**

Student says, “It's a hearing aid to help me hear.”
goals.goal_text: By (date), when a [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar]] person asks about a personal hearing device, (name) will identify the type of device (e.g. hearing aid, CI, BAHA) and why it's worn (i.e. to help hear better), for (4 out of 5) device questions.

objectives.text: By (date), during a [[student-teacher conference|student-teacher]] conference, when asked about a personal hearing device, (name) will identify the type of device (e.g. hearing aid, CI, BAHA) and why it's worn (i.e. to help hear better), for (4 out of 5) device questions.

By (date), during a [[student-teacher conference|student-teacher]] conference, when the teacher asks [[multiple choice|which of (2)]] hearing devices is the one personally worn, (name) will select the answer, for (4 out of 5) device questions. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, “Which device helps you hear: a hearing aid or cochlear implant?" *Example student response:*
Student says, "Cochlear implant."

By (date), during a [[student-teacher conference|student-teacher]] conference, given [[picture choices|pictures]] of (2) different hearing devices (e.g. hearing aid, CI) and asked to identify [[multiple choice|which is the device personally worn]], (name) will select the answer (e.g. by pointing, stating, using an [[adaptive switches|adaptive switch]]), for (4 out of 5) device questions.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Describe Personal Hearing Device

udl_adaptations.text: Provide [[picture choices|pictures]] of different hearing devices to help a student learn to identify which device he or she personally wears. Pictures can be printed from the Internet (photos can be found on the manufacturer's website), or use a photograph of a student's actual device. Verbally label the pictures, so the student learns the correct name of the different devices. To meet this goal, give the student two pictures: one of the device he or she uses and another, less familiar device. Verbally label them and ask, "Which device is the one you use?" The student can then repeat the name of the device, or simply point to the picture.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.5 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Illustrate through multiple media
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.5 Illustrate through multiple media

udl_adaptations.text:
Use [[multiple choice|multiple choice]] response options to ease student frustration. It can be difficult to remember the name of a specific device, and two verbal choices can remind a student of the answer without requiring independent recall. The terms should be communicated using language that is appropriate to the individual child's ability level. *Example multiple choice scenario:*
Teacher asks, "Do you have a hearing aid or cochlear implant?"
Student responds, "Cochlear implant."
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: A brief [[student-teacher conference|student-teacher conference]] is a great way to help the student get comfortable with fielding questions about a device in a non-threatening environment. The hearing provider is likely best equipped to hold these conferences with the student: if the student doesn't know an answer to a question about a device, the provider can help the student devise an informed response. Start by explicitly explaining *why* the conversation is taking place (e.g. "Today we are going to talk about what to say when curious people ask about your hearing device."). Then, ask questions that strangers or peers might ask the student, such as "What is that on your ear?"
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster collaboration and communication
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.3 Foster collaboration and communication

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example teacher direction:**

“Turn the device off and reset.”

**Example student response:**

Student resets the device and says, "It worked."
goals.goal_text: By (date), after a hearing device stops working, when the teacher assigns (1) troubleshooting action, (name) will complete the action and identify whether or not it was successful, for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions.

objectives.text:
By (date), after a hearing device stops working, when the teacher assigns (1) troubleshooting action and gives (1) [[verbal prompting|guidance prompt]], (name) will complete the action and identify whether or not it was successful, for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions. *Example guidance prompt:*
Teacher says, "The reset button is here."

By (date), after a hearing device stops working, when the teacher assigns (1) troubleshooting action and gives (1) [[verbal prompting|guidance prompt]], (name) will complete the action with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical assist]] from the teacher, and identify whether or not it was successful, for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions. *Example physical assist:*
Teacher takes battery out, but lets student put battery in the tester.

By (date), after a hearing device stops working, after the teacher completes (1) troubleshooting action while [[think aloud|thinking aloud]], when told to repeat the action, (name) will complete the action with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical assist]] from the teacher, and receive a [[reinforcers|reward]] upon completion, for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions. *Example rewards:*
• Sticker on rewards chart
• Shout-out
• 5 minutes of a preferred activity

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Troubleshoot Personal Hearing Device

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Reinforcers|Reward]] students who troubleshoot a malfunctioning hearing device. This will encourage students who continuously rely on adult intervention to be more independent. For students in this age group, learning to care for a personal device is a step toward effective self-advocacy. *Example rewards include:*
• A sticker chart of troubleshooting actions (written or illustrated). Award a sticker for each completed action.
• A small preferred item or toy (e.g. pencil with characters).
• 5 minutes of a preferred activity (e.g. playing a word game with a peer).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

udl_adaptations.text:
A [[think aloud|think aloud]] allows students to watch and listen to an experienced person troubleshoot a device malfunction. After the think aloud, ask the student to mimic the troubleshooting steps. With practice, the student will gradually gain independence, and be able to troubleshoot without a think aloud demonstration. *Example think aloud:*
Teacher says, “The hearing aid isn’t working. I think I'd better check the battery. First, I'll open the battery door by pulling on this tiny tab. Then, I pop the battery out...like this! Now, I need to get a new battery out of the package and place the new battery in with the small circle facing down. Now, I'll close the battery door and listen for the beeps. Your turn - now you try!"
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.2 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Highlight patterns, critical features, big ideas, and relationships
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.2 Highlight patterns, critical features, big ideas, and relationships

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Graduated guidance|Physically assist]] young students to help them gain confidence when troubleshooting. Troubleshooting can occur in the back of the room where extra supplies are stored, and the DHH teacher or another trained adult can help complete this process. *Troubleshooting actions that may be difficult for this age group include:*
• Opening the battery door with a tool.
• Cleaning the wax out of the mold with the cleaning tool.
• Removing the battery door on a cochlear implant.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example question:**

Peer points to hearing aid and asks, "Why do you have that?"

**Example student response:**

"I need help to hear."
goals.goal_text: (By date), when asked to explain a personal hearing loss to a [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar]] person, (name) will identify that a hearing loss exists, (for 4 out of 5) hearing loss explanations.

objectives.example_text:
**Example guiding question scenario:** Peer points to hearing aid and asks, "Why do you have that?"
Student doesn't respond.
Teacher asks, "What does the hearing aid do?"
Student responds, "It helps me hear."
objectives.text: (By date), when asked to explain a personal hearing loss to a [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar]] person, given (1) [[guiding questions|guiding question]], (name) will identify that a hearing loss exists, (for 4 out of 5) hearing loss explanations.

(By date), when asked to explain a personal hearing loss during a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 conversation]] with a [[familiar people, places, and things|teacher]], given (1) [[guiding questions|guiding question]], (name) will identify that a hearing loss exists, (for 4 out of 5) hearing loss explanations.

objectives.example_text:
**Example yes/no picture choices:** * The words yes/no in a bright, bold font.
* Thumbs up/thumbs down
* Checkmark/X **Example teacher prompt:** Teacher asks, "Do you hear better with your left ear?"
Student points to the "thumbs up" picture.
objectives.text: (By date), when asked to explain a personal hearing loss during a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 conversation]] with a [[familiar people, places, and things|teacher]], given (1) [[guiding questions|guiding question]], (name) will identify that a hearing loss exists using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]] (e.g. nodding, picture communication, adaptive switch), (for 4 out of 5) hearing loss explanations.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Acknowledge Personal Hearing Loss

udl_adaptations.text: Modify this task to allow students to use a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]]. Instead of verbally recognizing a personal hearing loss, a student can use a nonverbal communication method, such as gesturing, nodding in response to a yes/no question, activating an adaptive switch or using a communication device. For example, to elicit a yes/no response, the teacher can ask, “Do you hear better with your left ear?” Similarly, if the student uses a communication device, the teacher can ask questions that elicit student answers that have already been pre-programmed into the device. For students who prefer to communicate using images, the teacher can supply picture choices of different scenarios/sounds, and ask the student to select scenarios/sounds that are difficult/easy for the student in relation to the hearing loss. Students can point to, pick up, or use eye gaze to indicate their selection.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text:
Use [[guiding questions|guiding questions]] to help students acknowledge a hearing loss. Some of the vocabulary associated with hearing loss can be difficult for young students to remember or say. Guiding questions will prompt students to use appropriate terms when explaining hearing loss. *Example guiding question scenario:*
Teacher asks, "Why do you have hearing aids?"
Student says, "I have hearing loss in both ears."
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Develop self-assessment and reflection
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.3 Develop self-assessment and reflection

udl_adaptations.text:
Students with a hearing loss can benefit greatly from visual support (i.e. a picture) when responding to a question. [[Picture choices|Picture choices]] can make it easier to respond to a question about a personal hearing loss, which has the potential to make some students feel uncomfortable or different. By providing picture choices, the teacher eliminates the need for the student to speak, and reminds the student that the answer to a given question is one of the options presented. *Example prompt:*
Teacher asks, "Do you hear better with your left ear?" *Example yes/no picture choices:*
• The words yes/no in a bright, bold font.
• Thumbs up/thumbs down
• Checkmark/X *Example prompt:*
Teacher asks, "Which of these shows a situation that you would need your device to help you hear?" *Example scenario picture choices:*
• Gym class
• Silent reading at the library
• A small group discussion
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.5 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Illustrate through multiple media
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.5 Illustrate through multiple media

goals.goal_text: By (date), after recognizing a hearing device needs basic maintenance (e.g. clean mold, change battery), (name) will independently complete a (3)-step maintenance task, in (4 out of 5) situations requiring maintenance.

objectives.text: By (date), when [[verbal prompting|prompted]] to check if a device needs basic maintenance (e.g. clean mold, change battery), after recognizing maintenance is required, (name) will independently complete a (3)-step maintenance task, in (4 out of 5) basic maintenance situations.

By (date), when [[verbal prompting|prompted]] to check if a device needs basic maintenance (e.g. clean mold, change battery), after recognizing maintenance is required, (name) will complete a (3)-step maintenance task with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical teacher assist]], in (4 out of 5) basic maintenance situations.

By (date), after a teacher determines that a hearing device needs basic maintenance (e.g. clean mold, change battery), given a [[visual task schedule|visual task schedule]], (name) will complete [[modified assignment|(1) part of a (3)-step maintenance task]] with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical teacher assist]], in (4 out of 5) basic maintenance situations.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Complete Basic Device Maintenance

udl_adaptations.text:
Create a [[visual task schedule|visual task schedule]] to illustrate basic device care steps for tasks like cleaning a mold or changing a battery. As students become more independent, the visual schedule will help them complete the task without adult guidance. Place the task schedule in the area where extra batteries and mold cleaning tools are kept, so students don't have to remember to bring it along when a device needs maintenance, and can easily reference it as needed. Pictures for the task schedule can be found on device manufacturer websites, or take pictures of an adult completing each step with a student's hearing device.
*Example visual task schedule steps:*
1) Remove hearing aid (pull the mold out).
2) Take cleaning tool out of case.
3) Use cleaning tool to gently scoop wax out of the mold.
4) Use a tissue to wipe wax off of tool.
5) Place hearing aid back in ear.
6) Place cleaning tool back in the storage space.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize individual choice and autonomy
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.1 Optimize individual choice and autonomy

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Verbal prompting|Prompt]] a student to check if a hearing device needs basic maintenance, such as a battery change or a cleaning. This reminder can come first thing in the morning, after a transition, or when the normal daily routine is different. Students with hearing loss often need reminders to complete basic maintenance care. Distractions or changes in routine can lead them to forget to do it independently. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, “Device care time.” *Example student response:*
Student goes to area of the room to complete care routine.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

udl_adaptations.text:
Sometimes, it's necessary to [[graduated guidance|physically assist]] a student who needs to complete a basic device care task. For example, a student may need hand-over-hand assistance to pull out/off a hearing device, put a device back in/on, put a battery in or use a cleaning tool. If the student needs more intervention than hand-over-hand guidance, the teacher can complete one or more of steps in the process while the student watches how it is done. Putting a battery in, for example, is an action the teacher can do alone: since the battery is so small, hand-over-hand isn’t always practical.
*Example physical assistance:*
•Teacher uses hand-over-hand assistance to help the student pull a hearing aid out of the ear by the mold.
•Student pops battery door, inserts new battery, and closes battery door.
•Teacher uses hand-over-hand to assist putting hearing aid back in the ear.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example maintenance situation:** * Student turns off FM transmitter, plugs in to charge.
* Student puts receivers into storage case.
goals.goal_text: By (date), when using a hearing device or amplification accessory (e.g. personal or school-owned), (name) will independently complete a (3)-step daily maintenance task (e.g. plug in the FM at end of the day, change battery, cleaning), for (4 out of 5) daily maintenance tasks.

objectives.text:
By (date), when using a hearing device or amplification accessory (e.g. personal or school-owned), given a [[verbal prompting|prompt]] to maintain it, (name) will independently complete a (3)-step daily maintenance task (e.g. plug in the FM at end of the day, change battery, cleaning), for (4 out of 5) daily maintenance tasks. *Example prompt:*
Teacher says, "Device care."

By (date), when using a hearing device or amplification accessory (e.g. personal or school-owned), given a [[verbal prompting|prompt]] to maintain it, (name) will complete a (3)-step daily maintenance task (e.g. plug in the FM at end of the day, change battery, cleaning) with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical teacher assist]], for (4 out of 5) daily maintenance tasks.

By (date), when using a hearing device or amplification accessory (e.g. personal or school-owned), given a [[visual task schedule|visual task schedule]] and a [[verbal prompting|prompt]] to maintain it, (name) will complete [[modified assignment|(1) part of a (3)-step maintenance task]] with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical teacher assist]], for (4 out of 5) daily maintenance tasks.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Complete Daily Device Maintenance

udl_adaptations.text:
Create a [[visual task schedule|visual task schedule]] to illustrate basic device care steps for tasks like cleaning a mold or changing a battery. As students become more independent, the visual schedule will help them complete the task without adult guidance. Place the task schedule in the area where extra batteries and mold cleaning tools are kept, so students don't have to remember to bring it along when a device needs maintenance, and can easily reference it as needed. Pictures for the task schedule can be found on device manufacturer websites, or take pictures of an adult completing each step with a student's hearing device.
*Example visual task schedule steps for changing a hearing aid battery:*
1) Take hearing aid out.
2) Open battery door.
3) Take battery out.
4) Take new battery out of battery package.
5) Put new battery in hearing aid (small circle down).
6) Close battery door.
7) Put hearing aid back in ear.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize individual choice and autonomy
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.1 Optimize individual choice and autonomy

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Verbal prompting|Prompt]] a student to complete daily device maintenance tasks. This reminder can come first thing in the morning, after a transition, or when the normal daily routine is different. Students with hearing loss often need reminders to complete basic maintenance care. Distractions or changes in routine can lead them to forget to do it independently. *Example teacher prompt:*
Students come into the classroom after a week break from school. Teacher says, “Remember to check your battery and clean your ear mold during your morning routine.”

udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

udl_adaptations.text:
Sometimes, it's necessary to [[graduated guidance|physically assist]] a student who needs to complete a basic device care task. For example, a student may need hand-over-hand assistance to pull out/off a hearing device, put a device back in/on, put a battery in or use a cleaning tool. If the student needs more intervention than hand-over-hand guidance, the teacher can complete one or more of steps in the process while the student watches how it is done. Putting a battery in, for example, is an action the teacher can do alone: since the battery is so small, hand-over-hand isn’t always practical.
*Example physical assistance:*
• Teacher uses hand-over-hand guidance to help student put the battery into a cochlear implant battery compartment.
• Teacher plugs in the FM transmitter, student puts receivers into storage case.

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example device:** Hearing aid **Example features:** * Bluetooth
* 3 Programs: FM, Loud Background Noise, Normal
* Telecoil **Example student response:** Student says, "My device has the telecoil activated."
goals.goal_text: By (date), given a reference material (e.g. website, manual, audiologist report) and asked to explore advanced features of a personal hearing device, (name) will identify (1) advanced feature and determine if the device is currently programmed for it, for (3 out of 3) device exploration opportunities.

objectives.text: By (date), when asked to explore advanced features of a personal hearing device, after (3) device features are [[preteaching|explained by the teacher]], (name) will [[personal-interest problems|choose]] (1) of the features and determine if it is currently programmed on the device, for (3 out of 3) device exploration opportunities.

objectives.example_text:
**Example teacher prompt:**

Teacher says, "Press this button here to see if it is activated."
objectives.text: By (date), when asked to explore advanced features of a personal hearing device, after (2) device features are [[preteaching|explained by the teacher]], (name) will [[personal-interest problems|choose]] (1) of the features and determine if it is currently programmed on the device, with (1) [[verbal prompting|guidance prompt]] from the teacher, for (3 out of 3) device exploration opportunities.

By (date), after the teacher [[preteaching|explains]] (1) device feature and [[modeling routines, skills, and procedures|demonstrates]] how to activate it, (name) will activate the feature, with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical assist]] from the teacher, for (3 out of 3) device exploration opportunities.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Explore Advanced Device Features

udl_adaptations.text: Help students develop an [[personal-interest problems|interest]] in learning about their personal amplification systems. To start, allow students to peruse brochures, manufacturer websites, or audiological reports to find out the capabilities of the device. Tell the student that the device can do more than one thing, and that they can learn to adjust their device to meet their needs in all kinds of circumstances. If a student looks at his or her audiological report, for example, he or she might find that two programs are already activated, and can be used immediately.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.4 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Increase mastery-oriented feedback
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.4 Increase mastery-oriented feedback

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Preteaching|Explain]] advanced hearing device features in a 1:1 discussion if a student has difficulty researching independently. Advanced feature options can be found on the manufacturer website for each specific hearing device, and the student’s audiological report (which can be obtained from the audiologist, parent, student's main file or IEP/504 plan attachment) will indicate which features have been turned on. *Example teacher explanation:*
Teacher says, "Your hearing aid has two programs. The first one is for when you are using your FM in class. The second one is for when there is no FM connected, and the room is very noisy."
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Clarify vocabulary and symbols
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.1 Clarify vocabulary and symbols

udl_adaptations.text:
Instead of overwhelming students with information, [[modified assignment|teach only one advanced feature option at a time]]. Program changes and bluetooth activation are the most common advanced features students will use when in school, and are the most common features that students will already have enabled on their individual devices. Tell the student which one to use in a specific setting, and how to activate the feature. *Example scenario:*
Student needs to change the programing to utilize an FM system. *Example teacher explanation:*
Teacher says, "It’s time to use your FM system. You need to activate your FM program on your hearing aid. Here's the button."
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example hearing devices/technologies:** * Personal FM system
* Soundfield system
* BAHA
* Cochlear implant
* Hearing aids
goals.goal_text: By (date), in a difficult hearing situation at school, when told to use (1) hearing device/technology that is suited to the circumstances, (name) will use the device/technology for the duration of the situation, (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations.

objectives.text:
By (date), in a difficult hearing situation at school, when told to use (1) hearing device/technology that is suited to the circumstances, given a teacher [[verbal prompting|reminder]], (name) will use the device/technology for the duration of the situation, in (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations. *Example teacher reminder:*
Teacher points to a picture of the device, which is taped on the student's desk.

By (date), in a difficult hearing situation at school, when told to use (1) hearing device/technology that is suited to the circumstances, given a teacher [[verbal prompting|reminder]], (name) will use the device/technology for the duration of the situation, and receive a [[reinforcers|reward]] upon completion, in (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations. *Example rewards:*
• A sticker
• 5 minutes of computer time
• Coloring page

By (date), in a difficult hearing situation at school, when told to use (1) hearing device/technology that is suited to the circumstances, after the teacher sets a [[timer|timer]] for a [[modified assignment|modified duration]] (e.g. 15 minutes during the read aloud), (name) will use the device/technology for the duration of the situation, and receive a [[reinforcers|reward]] upon completion, in (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Use Device When Necessary

udl_adaptations.text:
When students successfully wear their devices, award a personalized prize to motivate them to continue on a successful path. For this age group, rewards might include:
• Technology time (i.e., 10 minutes during a pre-determined time slot)
• A sticker (for enjoyment or a classroom rewards behavior chart)
• A small eraser (shaped like a favorite character)
• A coloring page
• Small piece of candy/food (Personalized to school/district policies and/or parent/guardian requests)
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

udl_adaptations.text: [[Modified assignment|Modify]] the duration of time students are expected to use a personal hearing device. A pre-determined period of time (i.e., 5 minutes, 10 minutes, 30 minutes, etc.) will help the student build stamina. Start with short durations and slowly build toward longer ones to alleviate student frustration. Tolerance levels for wearing a personal device will vary greatly from student to student. Other factors include the student's age and how new the device is. Set a timer so the student has a concrete, visual reference, and if the student is successful, consider presenting a small reward.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Verbal prompting|Prompt]] students to use a device. Students who have a new device, or who don't like to use a device, will sometimes respond to a simple reminder. Prompts can be verbal or visual, and should be tailored to the individual student's preferences. For example, if a student is already insecure about using a device, a public, verbal prompt probably will make her even more uncomfortable. *Example prompts include:*
• Pointing to the device itself, or a picture of the device on the student's desk.
• Saying, "Device time."
• A personalized signal (e.g. The student knows that every time the teacher gives him a thumbs-up, he needs to use his device).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example difficult hearing situations due to seating arrangement:** * Near the projector
* Near a loud group of students
* Near a fan
**Example student response:** Student says, "I can't hear very well in the back, so I'm moving up here."
goals.goal_text: By (date), after recognizing that a current seating arrangement is causing a difficult hearing situation during a school activity, (name) will notify the teacher, give (1) reason why a seat change is needed, and independently change seats to a placement that improves the ability to hear, for (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations.

objectives.text:
By (date), after using the teacher's [[guiding questions|guiding question]] to recognize that a current seating arrangement is causing a difficult hearing situation during a school activity, (name) will give (1) reason why a seat change is needed, and independently change seats to a placement that improves the ability to hear, for (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations. *Example guiding question:*
Teacher asks, "Can you hear okay over there?"

By (date), after using the teacher's [[guiding questions|guiding question]] to recognize that a current seating arrangement is causing a difficult hearing situation during a school activity, given a [[multiple choice|choice]] between (2) alternate seats, (name) will move to the placement that most improves the ability to hear, for (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations. *Example optimal locations:*
• Near the teacher or presenter
• In a designated quiet space
• Away from the classroom door

By (date), after using the teacher's [[guiding questions|guiding question]] to recognize a current seating arrangement is causing a difficult hearing situation during a school activity, when the teacher gives (2) alternate seating [[multiple choice|choices]], (name) will choose the placement that most improves the ability to hear using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]] (e.g. communication device, nodding, stating), for (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations. *Example student use of preferred mode of expression:*
Teacher asks, "Would it be better if you sat in the quiet area?"
Student shakes head, "No."
Teacher asks, "Would you rather sit in the front?"
Student shakes head, "Yes."

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Move to a Preferential Seat

udl_adaptations.text: Modify this task to allow students to use a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]]. Instead of verbally notifying the teacher that a seat change is needed, a student can use a nonverbal communication method, such as gesturing, nodding in response to a yes/no question, activating an adaptive switch or using a communication device. For example, to elicit a yes/no response, the teacher can ask, “Do you think sitting closer to the teacher/speaker would help you to hear better in this situation?” Similarly, if the student uses a communication device, the teacher can ask questions that elicit student answers that have already been pre-programmed into the device. For students who prefer to communicate using images, the teacher can supply picture choices of alternate seating locations and ask them to choose the seating arrangement that works best. Students can point to, pick up, or use eye gaze to indicate their selection.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Develop self-assessment and reflection
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.3 Develop self-assessment and reflection

udl_adaptations.text: If a student doesn’t independently recognize that a seating assignment is causing a difficult hearing situation, ask a few [[guiding questions|guiding questions]]. For example, if a student who is seated near a fan isn’t participating in a class discussion (but usually does), the teacher do a quick check for auditory understanding by asking something such as, “(Name), can you repeat Julian's claim?” The student might immediately say “No,” and blame the fan for causing auditory disruption, but if not, follow up with another guiding question: “Is there something about your current seat that is making it difficult to hear?” If the student still has trouble, pair a guiding question with a few alternate seating choices, and ask, “Which of these seating locations will help you to better hear the discussion?” Instead of simply telling the student to switch seats, guiding questions like these lead the student to recognize difficult hearing situations with a little more independence.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.3 Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation

udl_adaptations.text:
Give the student alternate seating [[multiple choice|choices]] that are optimal for hearing. The choices will differ depending upon the type of setting (e.g. gym, cafeteria, auditorium, classroom), and will also differ for each student. Some students don't function well “up-front” in a classroom, while others benefit from close proximity, for example. *Example alternate seating locations include:*
Gymnasium:
• Sitting/standing up front near the speaker/teacher
• Sitting on the middle of the bench
• Positioning to face the teacher
Auditorium:
• Sitting in a front row of the auditorium seating
• Sitting in a middle row of the front section of the auditorium
• Sitting in the middle section, away from the speakers
Classroom:
• Sitting near the teacher/speaker
• Moving to the back of the classroom where student distraction has been minimized
• Sitting at a table for independent work to be closer to the speaker/teacher
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example student response:**

Student says, "Xavier, can you switch seats with me? I can't hear over here by these loud kids."
goals.goal_text: By (date), during school, when amongst peers in a difficult listening situation, (name) will give (1) reason why hearing is difficult and use (1) pre-taught strategy to improve the ability to hear, in (4 out of 5) observed situations with peers.

objectives.text:
By (date), during school, when amongst peers in a difficult listening situation, after confirming with a [[peer buddies|friend]] that auditory information was not heard/misheard, (name) will give (1) reason why hearing is difficult and use (1) pre-taught strategy to improve the ability to hear, in (4 out of 5) observed situations with peers. *Example peer assistance:*
Student asks, "Did they say the class party is tomorrow?"
Peer buddy responds, "No, Friday."
Student says, "Xavier, can you switch seats with me? I can't hear over here by these loud kids."

By (date), during school, when amongst peers in a difficult listening situation, after the teacher gives a [[visual cue cards|visual cue card]] with (3) pre-taught repair strategies, (name) will [[multiple choice|choose]] the best repair strategy for the situation and use it to improve the ability to hear, in (4 out of 5) observed situations with peers. *Example visual cue card strategies:*
• Ask to repeat
• Move your seat
• Whole body listening

By (date), during a difficult listening situation in school, after the teacher gives a [[visual cue cards|visual cue card]] with (1) repair strategy and [[verbal prompting|prompts]] to use it, (name) will use the strategy presented on the card to improve the ability to hear, with [[graduated guidance|graduated teacher guidance]], in (4 out of 5) observed situations with peers.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Explain Hearing Needs to Peers

udl_adaptations.text: Encourage students to check in with a [[peer buddies|peer]] during a difficult listening situation. Ideally, the peer will be aware of the student's hearing needs, so if the student asks the peer to clarify something, the peer isn't taken off-guard. Teachers can begin by asking the student if they have a dependable friend that could be potentially helpful during difficult hearing situations. If the student says yes, the teacher give the student specific ways to approach the peer when there is a problem. For example, the student can ask the peer to repeat information, clarify something that was said, or be observed as a model (e.g. if a direction is given that the student doesn't hear, the student can watch the peer and follow along).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster collaboration and communication
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.3 Foster collaboration and communication

udl_adaptations.text:
Create [[visual cue cards|visual cue cards]] with repair strategies that students can reference during conversation. Depending on the individual student, the cue cards can be taped into an agenda, posted on a classroom wall, or laminated and transportable, so the teacher can place one in front of the student as needed. When the student appears to be having difficulty hearing, the teacher can point to a cue card, or give a reminder to reference them. The cards can include simple illustrations, or even photographs that depict each strategy. *Example cue card repair strategies:*
• Move seat
• Ask to repeat
• Close door
• Check with a friend
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 1.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer ways of customizing the display of information
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 1.1 Offer ways of customizing the display of information

udl_adaptations.text: If a student doesn't independently take action during a difficult hearing situation, give them a few repair strategy [[multiple choice|choices]]. As long as the teacher explicitly teaches repair strategies before asking students to use them independently, the choices will remind the students of what they already know. Teachers can present the choices on a visual cue card, a written list, or verbally. For example, if a student appears to have difficulty following a conversation with peers in the lunchroom, the teacher can take the student aside and say, "Remember, if you're having trouble hearing, you can adjust your device setting, move your seat closer, or ask your friend to repeat what he said."
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example need:**

Repetition

**Example reasoning:**

Student says, “Can you repeat that? I want to make sure I know the time to be there so I'm not late."
goals.goal_text: By (date), when amongst peers during a difficult hearing situation in school, (name) will ask for (1) hearing accommodation to be met and give (1) reason why, for (4 out of 5) observed difficult hearing situations.

objectives.example_text:
**Example teacher check in:**

At the beginning of the day, the student meets with the hearing teacher, and the teacher reminds the student to self-advocate when amongst peers.
objectives.text: By (date), after a teacher [[check in/check out|check-in]], when amongst peers during a difficult hearing situation in school, (name) will ask for (1) hearing accommodation to be met and give (1) reason why, for (4 out of 5) observed difficult hearing situations.

By (date), after a teacher [[check in/check out|check-in]], given a [[reference materials|list]] of (5) accommodation choices, when amongst peers during a difficult hearing situation in school, (name) will choose (1) hearing accommodation from the list, and ask for it to be met, for (4 out of 5) observed difficult hearing situations.

objectives.example_text:
**Example scenario:**

Student is sitting in the back of the room, can't hear the teacher.

**Example picture choices:**
* Raise hand
* Move seat
* Ask a neighbor
objectives.text: By (date), during a [[explicit instruction|practice session]] with a teacher, given a difficult hearing scenario and (3) [[picture choices|accommodation picture choices]], (name) will identify the accommodation best suited for the hearing needs described in the scenario using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]], for (4 out of 5) observed difficult hearing scenarios.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Advocate for Needs with Peers

udl_adaptations.text: A teacher [[check in/check out|check in]] can serve as a reminder that the student should advocate for personal hearing needs. The check in can be with a classroom teacher, hearing specialist, or even a guidance counselor, and can be scheduled or impromptu. For example, if the classroom teacher noticed a problem in yesterday's class, they can stop the student during the classroom entry routine and give a reminder to ask for accommodations when necessary. On the other hand, the guidance counselor can review self-advocacy strategies during a scheduled weekly meet up.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster collaboration and communication
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.3 Foster collaboration and communication

udl_adaptations.text:
Give students a [[reference materials|list of accommodation options]] to reference independently. The list can be presented on a laminated card, kept in a folder, or glued into an agenda. The student isn't likely to take it out and reference it in the middle of a conversation with peers, of course, but it can be a helpful discussion tool when conferencing with a hearing teacher, classroom teacher, or counselor. It can also be useful for the student to reference independently, perhaps after a day at school when hearing was particularly difficult. *Example accommodations/strategies for better hearing:*
• Ask for a written transcript of the morning/afternoon announcements
• Request Closed Captioning for web-based content
• Switch seats
• As a teacher for a copy of the slides
• Request a Sign Language Interpreter
• Request that the teacher close the classroom door to reduce background noise from the hallway
• Asking the speaker to “face you” when they are speaking
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text:
Modify this lesson to accommodate students who prefer to respond nonverbally, or who could benefit from practicing self-advocacy skills in a controlled setting before using them independently. To start the practice session, the teacher can give the student a difficult hearing scenario, then ask the student to choose a solution from two [[picture choices|picture choices]]. Picture choices provide a visual representation of accommodations, *and* allow students to respond nonverbally, by pointing/gesturing to a selection, or using eye gaze, for example. *Example scenario:*
Student can't hear the teacher during the mini-lesson. *Example picture choices:*
• FM unit (picture of FM)
• Ask a friend (picture of a friend) *Example student response:*
Student points to FM unit picture.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.5 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Illustrate through multiple media
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.5 Illustrate through multiple media

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example teacher prompt:** “When might it be hard to hear during Mrs. Larson’s math class?”
**Example student response:** "When kids in the hallway are being loud.”
