**Example follow-up teacher prompt:** “What can you do to make it easier to hear?” **Example student response:** "Ask Mrs. Larson to shut the door."
goals.goal_text: By (date), when asked to identify why hearing could be difficult during an upcoming school activity, and offer a solution, (name) will give (1) reason why hearing could be difficult, and (1) accommodation that could improve the ability to hear, for (4 out of 5) difficult listening situations.

objectives.text:
By (date), when asked to identify why hearing could be difficult during an upcoming school activity, and offer a solution, after the teacher asks (1) [[guiding questions|guiding question]], (name) will give (1) reason why hearing could be difficult, and (1) accommodation that could improve the ability to hear, for (4 out of 5) difficult listening situations. *Example guiding question:*
Teacher asks, "If kids are being too loud in the hallway, what's the easiest thing to do to limit the noise coming from there?"

By (date), when [[verbal prompting|told]] why hearing could be difficult during an upcoming school activity, and asked to offer a solution, given (3) accommodation [[multiple choice|answer choices]], (name) will select the accommodation that would best improve the ability to hear, for (4 out of 5) difficult listening situations. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, "It could be difficult to hear when the 6th graders are transitioning in the hallway. What can you do to solve that problem if it happens?" *Example answer choices:*
• Move seat
• Turn off aids
• Ask teacher to shut the classroom door

By (date), when [[verbal prompting|told]] why hearing could be difficult during an upcoming school activity, and asked to offer a solution, given (2) accommodation [[picture choices|picture choices]], (name) will select the accommodation that would best improve the ability to hear, using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]], for (4 out of 5) difficult listening situations. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, "It could be difficult to hear the teacher in your classroom when the 6th graders are transitioning in the hallway. What can you do to solve that problem if it happens?" *Example answer choices:*
• Move seat (picture of desk)
• Ask teacher to shut the classroom door (picture of door) *Example student response:*
Student points to picture of the door.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Make a Plan for Hearing Obstacles

udl_adaptations.text: When first teaching students how to anticipate potential difficult hearing situations, discuss [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar]] situations that they've already encountered. For example, the teacher can say, "It’s difficult to hear in gym class because many students are speaking, laughing, or shouting all at the same time. It’s also noisy because students are jumping, running, and most likely kicking or hitting a ball.” Then, the teacher can ask the student: “What can you do to make it easier to hear in gym class?” and give two or three answer options. After students are able to anticipate potential difficult hearing situations within familiar contexts, ask them the same questions about new situations, such as a special assembly, field day, or an after-school club that just started to meet.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize individual choice and autonomy
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.1 Optimize individual choice and autonomy

udl_adaptations.text:
Ask [[guiding questions|guiding questions]] to help students develop a verbal response. Guiding questions can help the student anticipate potential difficult hearing situations, or help a student determine which accommodation or adjustment could solve the potential problem. *Example guiding question (anticipate a difficult hearing situation):*
"When do you notice there's a lot of background noise during math?" *Example student response:*
"During station time." *Example guiding question (determine a solution for a difficult hearing situation):*
Teacher asks, "If you can't turn off your aids because you still need to hear your group members, what other option do you have?"
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.3 Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation

udl_adaptations.text:
Give students [[multiple choice|multiple answer choices]] if they are unsure of how to "fix" an anticipated difficult listening environment. The choices can be presented verbally, or come from an accommodation list that the student is already familiar with. *Example difficult listening situation:*
The science teacher is soft-spoken. *Example alternative solutions:*
• Move seat closer
• Ask for printed notes
• Use FM unit *Example student response:*
Student says, "The FM would work best for me."
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example prompt:**

“What homonym or homophone did you hear in the paragraph and what does it mean?”

**Example student response:**

“I heard the word ‘waste’ and it means something you’re supposed to use but end up throwing away.”
goals.goal_text: By (date), after (1) grade-level paragraph is [[read aloud|read aloud]] and asked to name a homonym/homophone from the text, (name) will identify (1) homonym/homophone from the text and state the definition, for (4 of 5) grade-level paragraphs.

objectives.text: By (date), after (1) [[modified text|instructional-level]] paragraph is [[read aloud|read aloud]], reminded of a pre-taught homonym/homophone [[anchor charts|anchor chart]], and asked to name a homonym/homophone from the text, (name) will identify (1) homonym/homophone from the text and state the definition, for (4 of 5) instructional-level paragraphs.

By (date), after (1) [[modified text|instructional-level]] paragraph is [[read aloud|read aloud]], reminded of a pre-taught homonym/homophone [[anchor charts|anchor chart]], and asked to name a homonym/homophone from the text, (name) will identify (1) homonym/homophone from the text and state the definition with no more than (2) [[visual cueing|visual prompts]] to the anchor chart (e.g. teacher points to the word pair), for (4 of 5) instructional-level paragraphs.

By (date), after (1) [[modified text|instructional-level]] sentence is [[read aloud|read aloud]], shown an illustrated [[response cards|card]] with a pair of homonyms/homophones, and asked to name the homonym/homophone from the sentence, (name) will identify the homonym/homophone with no more than (1) [[visual cueing|visual prompt]] to the response card, for (4 of 5) instructional-level paragraphs.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Differentiate Between Homonyms in a Paragraph

udl_adaptations.text: Provide an illustrated [[response cards|response card]] with images depicting the pre-taught homonym/homophone pair that was used in the sentence. Use images, photographs, or illustrations that represent the words. For example, for the sentence, "Roses are my favorite flower," the first picture card can depict a [[https://image.freepik.com/free-vector/red-rose_23-2147503227.jpg|rose]] and the second picture card can depict a bag of [[https://us.123rf.com/450wm/Timmary/Timmary1508/Timmary150800093/44170960-flour-in-a-bag-and-spikelets-isolated-on-white-background.jpg?ver=6|flour]]. To increase engagement, allow students to choose the images prior to completing this task. For instance, a quick internet search can be a fun activity that facilitates conversation about the words and their meanings while familiarizing students with the images.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Minimize threats and distractions
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.3 Minimize threats and distractions

udl_adaptations.text: Create or add to an illustrated [[anchor charts|anchor chart]] during and after a lesson in which a homonym/homophone word pair is taught. Find illustrations or photographs that represent the word pairs or even let the students find or choose the images independently. Be sure to post the anchor chart in a clear and easy-to-access part of the classroom. The chart can also be photographed, printed on letter-size paper, and/or stored in a student’s folder for accessibility. Either way, [[visual cueing|visually prompt]] students to refer to the anchor chart when they are asked to identify the homonym/homophone that was used in the sentence or paragraph that was read aloud (e.g. point to the chart, point to the specific pair of words).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.2 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Highlight patterns, critical features, big ideas, and relationships
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.2 Highlight patterns, critical features, big ideas, and relationships

udl_adaptations.text: [[modified text|Modify]] the paragraph or sentence to a student’s instructional-level. Students for whom grade-level texts are too difficult to read independently need texts that they can access so they can focus on identifying the homonym/homophone. Consider writing a text from scratch that meets the student’s needs, or modify an existing one to a reading level that is appropriate for that student. Moreover, use a text about a preferred topic to engage the student in this task.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example teacher prompt:**

Teacher says, “What is this document and what's it for?”

**Example student response:**

Student says, “That’s a speech banana, and it shows the speech sounds that I can hear.”
goals.goal_text: By (date), given a completed audiogram/speech banana, and asked to explain what it is, (name) will identify the audiogram/speech banana by name and give (1) reason it is used, for (4 out of 5) document identification tasks.

objectives.text:
By (date), given a completed audiogram/speech banana, and asked to explain what it is, after the teacher asks a [[guiding questions|guiding question]], (name) will identify the audiogram/speech banana by name and give (1) reason it is used, for (4 out of 5) document identification tasks. *Example guiding question:*
Teacher asks, “What does this chart tell you about your hearing?”

By (date), given a completed audiogram/speech banana and asked to explain what it is, after the teacher asks a [[guiding questions|guiding question]] and gives (2) [[multiple choice|answer choices]], (name) will identify the audiogram/speech banana by name and select the answer choice that best explains why it is used, for (4 out of 5) document identification tasks. *Example answer choices:*
1) It shows the speech sounds that I can hear.
2) It shows that I use a hearing aid.

By (date), when asked identify an audiogram/speech banana from a group of (3) documents related to hearing loss, after the teacher [[verbal prompting|gives]] (1) defining characteristic to look for, (name) will select the audiogram/speech banana using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]], and receive a [[reinforcers|reward]] upon completion, for (4 out of 5) document identification tasks. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, "Look for the document that most looks like a banana."

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Explain What a Speech Banana is

udl_adaptations.text:
[[reinforcers|Reward]] students who need a little motivation to successfully complete this task. A small reward will signal that being able to identify an audiogram is important and should be celebrated. *Example rewards for this age group:*
• 5 minutes of iPad exploration
• Sticker on a rewards chart
• Permission to listen to a favorite song, watch a favorite clip
• 5 minutes of a preferred quiet activity (e.g. coloring, looking at books)
• Work/sit next to a friend for a specific task
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Verbal prompting|Prompt]] students with an audiogram characteristic, especially if they haven't had a lot of past exposure to audiograms. The specific prompt will depend on the other documents the audiogram is grouped with, and should focus on what makes the audiogram stand out. *Example prompts include:*
"Which paper has something that looks like a banana?"
"Which document has two lines that show hearing for the left *and* right ears?
"Which one looks like a graph?"
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

udl_adaptations.text: Modify this task to allow students to use a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]]. Instead of verbally selecting the audiogram and describing a defining characteristic, students can respond nonverbally by gesturing, nodding in response to a yes/no question, activating an adaptive switch or using a communication device. For example, to elicit a yes/no response, the teacher can ask, “Is *this* one the audiogram?” If the student prefers to pick up or point to the document, the teacher can simply ask, "Which one of these is the audiogram?" Similarly, if the student uses a communication device, the teacher can ask questions that elicit student answers that have already been pre-programmed into the device.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_text: By (date), after listening to (2) minutes of a grade-level fiction or nonfiction passage without access to the written text, when asked an inference question (i.e. the answer cannot be found directly in the passage), (name) will state an answer (e.g. verbally, in writing) that includes (2) supporting details from the passage, for (4 out of 5) verbal inference questions.

objectives.text: By (date), after listening to (2) minutes of an [[modified text|instructional-level]] passage without access to the written text paired with a passage-related [[visual aids|picture]], when asked an inference question (i.e. the answer cannot be found directly in the passage), (name) will state an answer (e.g. verbally, in writing) that includes (2) supporting details from the passage, for (4 out of 5) verbal inference questions.

objectives.example_text:
**Example Initial Prompt:**

"Listen carefully to how Pi describes the boat as a zoo."
objectives.text: By (date), after listening to (1) minute of an [[modified text|instructional-level]] passage without access to the written text paired with a passage-related [[visual aids|picture]], when given an [[verbal prompting|initial prompt]] to listen for specific details and asked an explicit comprehension question, (name) will state an answer that includes (1) supporting detail from the passage, for (4 out of 5) verbal comprehension questions.

objectives.example_text:
**Example Personal Interest Story:**

Jonah rode the bus to school. At school, Jonah ate breakfast in the cafeteria.

**Example Explicit Comprehension Question:**

Teacher asks, "How did Jonah get to school?"

**Example Images:**

* Picture of Jonah on a school bus
* Picture of Jonah eating breakfast
objectives.text: By (date), after listening to (2) sentences of a [[preferred topic or text|preferred]] [[modified text|instructional-level]] [[social narratives|personal-interest story]] without access to the written text, when shown a passage-related [[visual aids|picture]] and asked an explicit comprehension question, (name) will select the answer from (2) [[picture choices|picture choices]] using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]], for (4 out of 5) verbal comprehension questions.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Make Inferences from Auditory Information

udl_adaptations.text:
Show a passage-related [[visual aids|picture]] to help students fill in any gaps that they didn’t hear or understand when the teacher read the passage aloud.  The picture can be an illustration, photograph, or image found on the internet and can be displayed on a card, paper, projected on the classroom whiteboard, or displayed on a computer or tablet screen. For example, read the following excerpt from "The Namesake" by Jhumpa Lahiri:

*“You can always name him after yourself, or one of your ancestors,” M. Wilcox suggests, admitting that he is actually Howard Wilcox III. “It’s a fine tradition. The kings of France and England did it,” he adds. But this isn't possible. Ashima and Ashoke think to themselves. This tradition doesn’t exist for Bengalis, naming a son after a father or grandfather, a daughter after mother or grandmother. This sign of respect in America and Europe, this symbol of heritage and lineage, would be ridiculed in India. Within Bengali families, individual names are sacred, inviolable. They are not meant to be inherited or shared.*

Before asking about why Bengali families don't traditionally name a baby after a relative, show a picture of someone being [[http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2012/04/10/article-2127684-0F07ED0E00000578-39_468x286.jpg|ridiculed]] as a clue.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.5 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Illustrate through multiple media
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.5 Illustrate through multiple media

udl_adaptations.text: Allow students to use a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]] in order to select the answer to a comprehension question. Different modes include pointing, gesturing, nodding, eye gaze, alternative communication device, thumbs up/thumbs down, etc. Students will use their preferred mode of expression to select the [[picture choices|picture choice]] that answers the comprehension question. For example, after asking a student a comprehension question about the location of the story in a passage, he or she points to the picture choice depicting an island.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text:
Use a [[social narratives|personal-interest]] story that uses the student as the main character and incorporates [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar details]]. When the focus of a skill is understanding auditory language, removing barriers related to familiarity or preference will increase the student's ability to focus on the task at hand. Create stories about events that have happened in the past and everyday routines that can related to grade level curriculum. To further increase engagement, take pictures of the student doing these activities, and use the photos to accompany the read-aloud. *Example Grade Level Text: The Life of Pi* *Example Sentences:
• Tomás went to the zoo yesterday. He saw a tiger.
• Judy went to the beach for summer vacation. While she was there, she went on a boat.*
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.2 Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example Word Set:** Teacher: “take”
Student: writes “T-A-K”*
goals.goal_text: By (date), when the teacher states (1) familiar grade-level word in isolation (i.e. CVC, CCVC), (name) will write the word with letters that accurately represent the initial, middle, and final sounds in the correct order, for (8 out of 10) familiar words.

objectives.example_text:
**Example Task:** Teacher: "cat"
Student: writes "K-T"*
objectives.text: By (date), when the teacher states (1) [[Familiar Text|familiar]] grade-level word (i.e. CVC, CCVC) in isolation, (name) will write the letters that accurately represent the [[ modified assignment | initial and final sounds ]] of the word, for (8 out of 10) familiar words.

By (date), during a [[ Language-Based Games | language-based game ]], when the teacher states (1) familiar grade-level word (i.e. CVC, CCVC) in isolation with a corresponding picture of the word, (name) will write the letters that accurately represent the [[modified assignment|initial and final sounds]] of the word, for (8 out of 10) familiar words.

By (date), when the teacher states (1) familiar grade-level word (i.e. CVC) in isolation with a corresponding picture of the word, (name) will [[ preferred modes of expression | verbally state ]] the [[ modified assignment | initial sound ]] of the word, for (8 out of 10) familiar words.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Write Sounds of a Word

udl_adaptations.text: [[ Language-Based Games | Play a game ]] (e.g. Candy Land, Trouble) as you work on word sounds to keep a student engaged and motivated to listen and say the sound that is heard. In order to take a turn at the game, say a target-word and have the student tell the sound that is heard at the initial or final placement in the word. If the correct response is given, the student may take a turn. If incorrect, say the word again for a second attempt. If the student is still incorrect, write the word to show the letter that was said and talk about the sound the letter makes. Move on to another word and continue to play the game as the student tells the correct sound that is heard in the specified placement (initial or final). As students start to write the letters to spell a whole CVC word, use a game to engage the student in the task by allowing the student to take a turn after each word that is spelled correctly.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.2 Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity

udl_adaptations.text: [[ Modified Assignment | Modify the scope ]] and use CVC (Consonant-vowel-consonant) words only when a student starts writing words and word sounds. CVC words are the easiest to hear the different sound parts and the student can hear every sound in the word. There are no English language rules to remember and apply when writing CVC words (e.g. silent E, double vowel). Use CVC words to start having student write initial sounds and then work toward final sounds.  Consonant sounds are the easiest to hear for all student with a hearing loss and most can be seen on the mouth when spoken.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.4 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Maximize transfer and generalization
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.4 Maximize transfer and generalization

udl_adaptations.text: Allow a student to first use their [[ Preferred Modes of Expression | preferred method of response ]] when working with letters and letter sounds. A student might tell the sound they hear at the beginning or end of a word before writing the letter for the sound. When learning to spell phonetically, the first step is often to listen to the word and identify the sounds heard in the word. The second step is to take the sounds and determine what letter is represented by those sounds and then write the letters to spell the words. For students with hearing loss and other delays, the first step in learning to spell is to be able to verbally identify the sounds they hear in words.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example Questions and Carrier Phrases:** Teacher asks, "Why did Goldilocks eat the porridge?"
Student begins response with, "Because..." Teacher asks, "When did Cinderella leave the castle?"
Student begins response with, "At..." Teacher asks, "How did the wolf knock down the little pig's houses?"
Student begins response with, "By..."
goals.goal_text: By (date), when asked a verbal question (i.e. who, what, where, when, why, how) about a grade-level topic or text paired with an [[illustration|illustration]], (name) will answer the question by beginning the response with an appropriate carrier phrase, for (4 out 5) questions.

objectives.example_text:
**Example Acoustic Highlighting:**

Teacher asks, "<u>WHY</u>...(pause 2 seconds)... did Goldilocks eat the bear's porridge?"*
objectives.text: By (date), when asked a verbal question (i.e. who, what, where, when, why, how) with [[acoustic highlighting|acoustic highlighting]] (e.g. emphasize the question form and briefly pause) about a grade-level topic or text paired with an [[illustration|illustration]], (name) will answer the question by beginning the response an appropriate carrier phrase, for (4 out of 5) questions.

objectives.example_text:
**Example Question:**

Teacher asks, "<u>WHAT</u>... (2 second pause)... did Goldilocks <u>EAT</u> (2 second pause)...?"

**Example Answer Choices:**

Teacher says, "She ate porridge" or "She slept in their beds"

**Sample Student Response:**

"She ate porridge."
objectives.text: By (date), when asked a verbal question with the question form "who", "what", or "where" using [[acoustic highlighting|acoustic highlighting]] about a familiar grade-level [[familiar people, places, and things|topic]] or [[familiar text|text]] paired with an [[illustration|illustration]], (name) will answer the question by selecting the correct response from a set of (2) [[multiple choice|verbal answer choices]], for (4 out of 5) questions.

By (date), when asked a verbal question with the question form "who" or "what" about a [[preferred topic or text|preferred topic]] paired with an [[illustration|illustration]], (name) will answer the question by [[preferred modes of expression | choosing]] the correct answer (e.g. pointing, eye-gazing, AAC device) from a set of (2) [[picture choices|picture choices]], for (4 out of 5) questions.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Use Carrier Phrases to Respond to Questions

udl_adaptations.text: Use a [[ Preferred Topic or Text | preferred ]] and [[Familiar People, Places, and Things | familiar ]] topic or story and provide pictures of answer choices to help keep the student engaged in the story and provide visual clues. Students with hearing loss need visual supports to help them understand the entire message and to fill in any missing auditory information. The pictures can help a student remember details about the story, while the preferred topic saves the student from needing to process and recall novel information, instead focusing more solely on auditory discrimination. Picture answer choices can be made by copying parts of a preferred and familiar book picture, drawing your own or searching for appropriate picture choices on the internet. Using preferred or familiar topics keep students engaged in the listening activity and allows them to use background knowledge to understand the story as it is told.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize individual choice and autonomy
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.1 Optimize individual choice and autonomy

udl_adaptations.text:
Use concrete [[ guiding questions | wh- questions ]] (i.e. who, what, where) about a story when asking a young student with hearing loss to listen and remember story details. Students with hearing loss have a hard time understanding abstract ideas and are able to answer questions that are about a concrete topic much better. Students with hearing loss depend more on sight and touch to help them understand concepts. Abstract ideas cannot be touched or seen and are therefore more difficult to understand. "Who", "what", and "where" questions will all have a specific, concrete answer to them. These do not require high level abstract thinking such as why or how questions might need. Students needs to learn to listen, remember and apply what was heard to answer easier type "who", "what", "where" questions before they will be able to answer more difficult how and why questions. *Example: Story about Charlie the dog who live on a farm.
* *Teacher: “What was Charlie’s job on the farm?”
Student: “To herd the sheep back to the barn.”* *Teacher: “Where did Charlie live?”
Student: “At the Circle K farm.”* *Teacher: “Who took care of Charlie?”
Student: “Farmer Joe.”* All of these answers could be seen in the pictures of the book and these questions show the student’s understanding of the story and ability to answer a question about a story.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.3 Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation

udl_adaptations.text:
Have students use preferred, perhaps nonverbal modes of communication to answer questions. Many times students with hearing loss and other delays need nonverbal ways to communicate, and certainly benefit from avoiding ways of communicating that are difficult or frustrating. Students can indicate understanding of a story and answer questions about the story by [[ Preferred Modes of Expression | pointing to a picture, using a communication device or nodding yes or no ]]. Pictures should match the story content and only one picture presented should be the correct answer to the question. Pictures from a book, clipart, actual photographs or drawings can all be used a a visual response option.

*Example Story: "Life on the Farm"
* *Example Illustrations: A farmer plowing a field with a tractor. A cow eating grass in a field.* *Teacher asks, "Who takes care of the corn in the field?" while holding up illustration.
Student: Points to farmer on the tractor.* *Teacher asks, “Who rounds up the sheep?” and presents two picture choices: Charlie the dog and a cow
Student: Points to picture of Charlie the Dog or uses communication device to select the correct picture.*
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example Setting for Conversation:** While waiting for class to start, the student is engaged in a discussion with their peers. Peer 1: We went snowboarding this weekend.
Peer 2: I've never snowboarded before.
Target Student: I like skiing more than snowboarding. I think it's easier to learn. Have you skied?
goals.goal_text: By (date), during a small-group, social conversation in the classroom about a [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar topic]], when it is their turn to speak (e.g. asked a question, a natural pause in discussion), (name) will contribute a (3)-sentence, on-topic response or question, for (4 out of 5) turns in the conversation.

objectives.example_text:
**Example Teacher Prompts:** “It’s your turn.”
“What do you think?”
“What are your thoughts?”
objectives.text: By (date), during a small-group, social conversation in the classroom about a [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar topic]], when it is their turn to speak (e.g. asked a question, a natural pause in discussion) and given (1) [[ verbal prompting | verbal ]] teacher prompt, (name) will contribute a (3)-sentence, on-topic response or question, for (4 out of 5) turns in the conversation.

objectives.example_text:
**Example Visual Cue:**

Teacher holds up a signal card "Your Turn"
objectives.text: By (date), during a small-group conversation in a [[ auditory preferential seating | separate setting ]] (e.g. therapy room, office, back of classroom during silent reading time), about a [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar topic]], and given (1) [[ visual cueing | visual cue]] to speak by the teacher, (name) will contribute a [[modified assignment | (1)-sentence]], on-topic response or question, for (4 out of 5) turns in the conversations.

objectives.example_text:
**Example Verbal Prompt Paired With a Visual Cue:**

Teacher holds up a signal card "Your Turn" and says, "Vanessa, it's your turn. What is one thing you enjoy doing outside of school?"
objectives.text: By (date), during a small-group, teacher-directed [[ language-based games | conversation starter game ]] in a [[ auditory preferential seating | separate setting]], and given (1) [[ verbal prompting | verbal prompt]] paired with (1) [[ visual cueing | visual cue]] to speak by the teacher, (name) will contribute a [[ modified assignment |(1)-sentence]], on-topic response or question to the conversation game prompt, for (4 out of 5) turns in the conversation.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Take Turns in a Social Conversation

udl_adaptations.text: Use a [[ verbal prompting | verbal ]] or [[ visual cueing | visual ]] prompt to remind students that they need to respond in a social situation. Many times, a DHH student will sit in a group setting and let the other members of the group carry the conversation. This is easier, requires less listening, and is an easy way to mask the fact that they are missing information and not able to keep up with the conversation. A teacher can use a verbal prompt (e.g. What do you think?) that reminds the student that it is time to participate in the conversation. A visual prompt can also be taught and agreed upon with the target student, particularly if the student is averse to the spotlight that a verbal prompt can place upon her. A colored index card held up by the teacher, barely noticeable to anyone else, could cue the student that it is time to contribute. The teacher can also repeat the question, or repeat what another student said to ensure that the DHH student heard the message and can then be more successful in responding appropriately. If the response is not on topic, the teacher needs to repeat the message again, have the student respond again, and then model an on-topic response if still not successful. Have the group sit in the back of the classroom or move to the hall or another quiet area if the DHH student is continually not able to keep up with the group discussion. The background noise may be too much for the student to hear and follow along.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

udl_adaptations.text:
Allow a student to start small by contributing a [[ modified assignment | single response ]] to the small group conversation. DHH students have to work very hard at listening to others and following along in a group conversation. Many times they become lost very quickly because of too many people talking at one time, not hearing parts of a message and becoming confused, and too much background noise or distractions. Encourage the student to respond early in the group conversation to limit the chance of becoming lost and increasing the chance of a successful on-topic contribution to the conversation. When the student successfully contributes once, then prompt the student to contribute a response again shortly after the first one. A teacher may need to repeat auditory information and guide the student’s answers with questions or comments to help fill in the gaps. *Example of Abbreviated Response:*
(Students working in a group to make an information poster about the President.)
Student 1: What do we need to know about the President?
Student 2: Name, family, job before Presidency?
DHH student: Where he is from.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

udl_adaptations.text:
Use a social [[ language-based games | conversation game ]] topic starter to get students interested in talking to each other. Topics can be found by searching online for “conversation starter games”. The teacher reads the prompt and then each child takes a turn answering the questions by commenting on the topic. As each student takes their turn in the conversation task, have a game (e.g. Monopoly, UNO, Trouble) that each student can take a turn at playing once they have contributed their on-topic response to the conversation. After every correct on-topic contribution to a conversation starter, the student could take a turn at the motivating game. If the student answers incorrectly, repeat the conversation starter prompt and have him try it again. If still wrong, model a correct on-topic response and have the student try one more time. After three attempts, allow the student to take a turn at the motivation game (monopoly). The extra motivation of playing a fun game will help students continue to want to converse with each other and the teacher. *Example Conversation Topic Starter:*
• If you could go anywhere on vacation, where would you go and why?
• DHH student: I would go to Europe and visit the Queen’s Palace.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.2 Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity

goals.goal_text: By (date), during a whole-group, academic discussion in the classroom about a grade-level topic (e.g. Debate, [[socratic seminar|Socratic Seminar]], [[fishbowl|Fishbowl]]), when it is their turn to speak (e.g. asked a question, a natural pause in discussion), (name) will contribute a (3)-sentence, on-topic response or question (e.g. debate another student’s response, ask a clarifying question), for (4 out of 5) turns in the academic discussion.

objectives.text: By (date), during a whole-group, academic discussion in the classroom about a grade-level topic (e.g. Debate, [[socratic seminar|Socratic Seminar]], [[fishbowl|Fishbowl]]), when given (1) [[ verbal prompting | verbal prompt]] to speak, (name) will contribute a (3)-sentence, on-topic response or question (e.g. debate another student’s response, ask a clarifying question), for (4 out of 5) turns in the academic discussion.

By (date), during a small-group, academic discussion in the classroom about a grade-level topic (e.g. [[think-pair-share|Think-Pair-Share]], [[turn and talk|Turn and Talk]], when given (1) [[ visual cue cards | visual cue]] to speak (e.g. student holds up "Your Turn" card), (name) will contribute a [[ modified assignment | (1)-sentence]], on-topic response or question (e.g. debate another student’s response, ask a clarifying question), for (4 out of 5) turns in the academic discussion.

By (date), during a 1:1 academic discussion in a [[ auditory preferential seating | separate location ]] (e.g. [[student-teacher conference|student-teacher conference]]), given (1) [[ verbal prompting | verbal prompt ]] paired with (1) [[visual cue cards|visual cue]] to speak, (name) will contribute a [[ modified assignment | (3)-word]], on-topic response or question (e.g. debate another student’s response, ask a clarifying question), for (4 out of 5) turns in the academic discussion.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Take Turns in an Academic Discussion

udl_adaptations.text: Take a small group of students to a [[ auditory preferential seating | separate quiet location ]] (e.g. back of the room during silent reading/work time, office, therapy room, unused classroom) to work on social conversation tasks. A quiet setting allows the DHH student access to all of the auditory information being presented as well as the visual cues given. A quiet location minimizes the background noise and visual distractions that are present in the classroom setting. Have the students sit in a circle so that they can see each other to enable lip reading and so that all facial expressions/body language can be seen. If the teacher needs to direct the conversation, have the teacher sit in the circle as well so that all students can see the teacher’s face when speaking. If the DHH student is asked to respond to a conversation task and is not able to respond on topic, the teacher should repeat the message (either given by the teacher or a peer) to allow the DHH student a second chance to listen, hear and understand the message.  If the student still isn’t able to give an on-topic response, ask a peer to answer as a model and then the teacher needs to repeat what the peer said so that the DHH student can hear the model twice.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.3 Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation

udl_adaptations.text:
Allow a student to start small by [[ modified assignment | contributing a single response ]] to the small group conversation. DHH students have to work very hard at listening to others and following along in a group conversation. Many times, they become lost very quickly because of too many people talking at one time, not hearing parts of a message and becoming confused, and too much background noise or distractions. Encourage the student to respond early in the group conversation to limit the chance of becoming lost and increasing the chance of a successful on-topic contribution to the conversation. Once the student is able to contribute successfully, prompt the student to contribute a second response shortly after the first. A teacher may need to repeat auditory information and guide the students answers by questions or comments to help them fill in the gaps. *Example Abbreviated Response:*
(Students working on science experiment.)
Student 1: What materials do we need?
Student 2: Bunsen burner, samples of material, goggles and data sheet.
DHH student: How many samples of materials? Which ones do we need?
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

udl_adaptations.text: Use discussion structures that would typically occur in the classroom setting to engage students in a turn-taking conversation task. For instance, goal-setting and [[student-teacher conference|student-teacher conferences]] are often conducted with older students, and is a natural conversation turn-taking opportunity. Minimize the student's need to focus on too many skills at once by giving them a graphic organizer with the questions that will be asked of them during the 1:1 session. By previewing the questions and allowing the student to formulate responses prior to the discussion, they can better focus on the subtle cues for turn-taking.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.2 Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity

goals.goal_text: By (date), after recognizing that a personal hearing device is not working during school, (name) will notify the teacher (e.g. verbally, by pointing to the device), for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions.

objectives.example_text:
**Example prompt:**

Teacher asks, “Is your device working ok?”
objectives.text: By (date), given (1) [[verbal prompting|teacher prompt]], after recognizing that a personal hearing device is not working during school, (name) will notify the teacher (e.g. verbally, by pointing to the device), for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions.

By (date), during a daily routine hearing device [[check in/check out|check]] (e.g. after every two classroom activities, before a transition), when the teacher [[ verbal prompting|asks ]] if the device is working, (name) will correctly indicate yes or no (e.g. verbally, nodding, by gesturing), for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions.

By (date), during a daily routine hearing device [[check in/check out|check]] (e.g. after every two classroom activities, before a transition), given yes/no [[picture choices|picture response cards]], and when [[ verbal prompting | asked ]] if a personal hearing device is working, (name) will correctly indicate yes or no (e.g. by picking up a card, nodding, stating), for (4 out of 5) daily routine hearing checks.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Alert Adult When Device Isn't Working

udl_adaptations.text: Schedule device [[check in/check out|check times]] throughout the day to help a student move toward independently reporting device malfunctions. Check times should be consistent: at the start of school day, mid-morning, and mid-afternoon, for example, and can also be incorporated into a student’s written or picture schedule. Check the device in the area of the classroom where extra batteries and a battery tester are located, to allow for easy troubleshooting and repair of the device if the student reports a problem.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster collaboration and communication
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.3 Foster collaboration and communication

udl_adaptations.text: [[verbal prompting|Prompt]] students to check their devices. A student might hear the device beeping when the battery is failing, but become sidetracked before reporting it to a teacher. To prompt the student to report on the device, the teacher can simply say something like “Device check!” or “Check your aids,” or “Listening check." Utilize prompts like these after a significant amount of time has passed since the last device check, during transition times when a student has been out of the classroom a while, or when the teacher suspects a problem (no flashing indicator light on device, student not responding or participating as normal).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

udl_adaptations.text: Allow a student to use gestures, [[picture choices|pictures]] or other non-verbal responses to indicate a hearing device is not working properly. For example, a student can simply point to the device to let a teacher know that something is wrong. This allows the student to report a problem during instruction without interrupting. Picture cards can also be used to report device problems when paired with a teacher prompt (e.g. teacher asks, "Is your device working?"). Picture cards can be a red frown face (not working) and a green smiley face (working), or a picture of the hearing device (photo taken of actual device or picture from computer) with a thumbs up (working) or thumbs down (not working).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example teacher direction:**

“Remember to plug the FM in while you're playing outside at recess.”
goals.goal_text: By (date), given directions to care for a hearing device that is not in use during the school day, (name) will independently charge, clean, and stow (i.e. in the proper place and manner) the hearing device, for (4 out of 5) school days.

objectives.text:
By (date), given directions to care for a hearing device that is not in use during the school day, after a [[modeling behaviors|teacher demonstration]], (name) will independently charge, clean, and stow (i.e. in the proper place and manner) the hearing device, for (4 out of 5) school days. *Example teacher demonstrations:*
• How to coil the cord of a Personal FM System when not in use.
• How to turn the device “off,” prior to storing/charging the device.
• How to properly clean the earpiece/earmold of the device.

By (date), given directions to care for a hearing device that is not in use during the school day, after a [[modeling behaviors|teacher demonstration]], given an illustrated device care [[visual task schedule|checklist]], (name) will independently charge, clean, and stow (i.e. in the proper place and manner) the hearing device, for (4 out of 5) school days.

By (date), given directions to care for a hearing device that is not in use during the school day, after a [[modeling behaviors|teacher demonstration]], given an illustrated device care [[visual task schedule|checklist]], (name) will receive [[graduated guidance|graduated teacher guidance]] to charge, clean, and stow (i.e. in the proper place and manner) the hearing device, for (4 out of 5) school days.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Care for Device When Not In Use

udl_adaptations.text:
Give students who require intensive supports [[graduated guidance|graduated teacher guidance]] to help them learn how to properly maintain and care for a personal hearing device. The guidance can range from physical assistance (e.g. hand-over-hand) to verbal prompts, depending on the need of individual students. *Example scenario:*
Grace uses a personal FM system and has fine motor difficulties. After Grace reviews the checklist on how to properly coil/wrap the personal FM system cords, the teacher uses over-hand guidance to help her wrap the cord correctly.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.3 Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation

udl_adaptations.text:
Give students a [[visual task schedule|visual checklist]] that serves as a basic device care “how-to." Personal hearing devices differ; therefore, the teacher should create a device care guide for each corresponding student hearing device. Teachers can access guides by contacting the parent/guardian and/or Educational Audiologist prior to the start of the school year, and use it to create a more student-friendly visual checklist. Visual checklists can include topics such as: • How to store the device when not in use.
• How to keep the device batteries charged/in working condition.
• How to clean the device.
• When to alert an adult (Educational Audiologist, teacher, parent) about a device issue.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 6.4 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Enhance capacity for monitoring progress
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 6.4 Enhance capacity for monitoring progress

udl_adaptations.text: [[Modeling behaviors|Demonstrate]] the correct way to utilize, maintain, and care for personal hearing devices (e.g. hearing aid, cochlear implant, classroom sound field system). Briefly and concisely model how to turn the device on/off correctly, how to properly charge the device at the end of the school day and/or when not in use, and how to store the device. For example, if a device has a rechargeable battery, state, “This device has rechargeable batteries in it. Make sure the device is turned on/off to allow it to charge when not in use.” For students who need more intense support, provide repetitive over-hand teacher-student demonstrations until the student has learned specific device maintenance and care steps.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example question:**

“The narrator of the story talked about needing to seal off the room off with plastic; why was that so important?”

**Example student response:**

“They were getting rid of insects with some chemical, and they had to seal the room to make sure the gas didn’t go anywhere else.”
goals.goal_text: By (date), after a [[read aloud|read aloud]] of a grade-level passage that contains (1) homophone/homonym and asked (1) question that requires comprehension of the homophone/homonym, (name) will answer the question, for (4 out of 5) grade-level passages.

objectives.text: By (date), after a [[read aloud|read aloud]] of an [[modified text|instructional-level]] passage that contains (1) homophone/homonym and asked (1) question that requires comprehension of the homophone/homonym, (name) will answer the question, for (4 out of 5) grade-level passages.

By (date), after a [[read aloud|read aloud]] of an [[modified text|instructional-level]] passage that contains (1) homophone/homonym, reminded of a pre-taught context clues [[poster summary|poster]], and asked (1) question that requires comprehension of the homophone/homonym, (name) will use [[context clues|context clues]] to answer the question, for (4 out of 5) grade-level passages.

By (date), after a [[read aloud|read aloud]] of an [[modified text|instructional-level]] sentence, shown an illustrated [[response cards|card]] with a pair of homonyms/homophones, and asked to name the homonym/homophone from the sentence, (name) will identify the homonym/homophone on the card, for (4 out of 5) instructional-level paragraphs.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Demonstrate Understanding of Multi-Meaning Words

udl_adaptations.text: Explicitly teach how to use [[context clues|context clues]] to figure out how to discern between two homophones/homonyms. Once students are familiar with the concept, refer to a familiar [[poster summary|poster summary]], and if needed, explicitly remind students of the thinking involved. For example, after reading aloud the sentence, “They have to seal up the house so that they can spray the fumes to kill the bugs," refer students to the previously-taught [[https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/originals/d1/80/85/d180853bc190183c7bef66dd3483a05a.jpg|"Context Clues Strategies Poster"]]. Go through the checklist on the poster with the student to help them figure out the meaning of "seal" as it is used in the sentence.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Clarify vocabulary and symbols
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.1 Clarify vocabulary and symbols

udl_adaptations.text: Provide an illustrated [[response cards|response card]] with images depicting the pre-taught homonym/homophone pair that was used in the sentence. Use images, photographs, or illustrations that represent the words. For example, for the sentence, "Roses are my favorite flower," the first picture card can depict a [[https://image.freepik.com/free-vector/red-rose_23-2147503227.jpg|rose]] and the second picture card can depict a bag of [[https://us.123rf.com/450wm/Timmary/Timmary1508/Timmary150800093/44170960-flour-in-a-bag-and-spikelets-isolated-on-white-background.jpg?ver=6|flour]]. To increase engagement, allow students to choose the images prior to completing this task. For instance, a quick internet search can be a fun activity that facilitates conversation about the words and their meanings while familiarizing students with the images.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Minimize threats and distractions
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.3 Minimize threats and distractions

udl_adaptations.text: [[modified text|Modify]] the paragraph or sentence to a student’s instructional-level. Students for whom grade-level texts are too difficult to read independently need texts that they can access so they can focus on identifying the homonym/homophone. Consider writing a text from scratch that meets the student’s needs, or modify an existing one to a reading level that is appropriate for that student. Moreover, use a text about a preferred topic to engage the student in this task.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example prompt:**

Peer asks, "You have hearing loss?"

**Example student response:**

Student says, "Yes, I have mild bilateral hearing loss."
goals.goal_text: By (date), when asked to describe their personal hearing loss to a familiar or unfamiliar person, (name) will identify the type (i.e. bilateral or unilateral), and degree (i.e. normal, mild, moderate, moderately severe, severe, or profound) using the correct terminology, for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss conversations.

objectives.text: By (date), when asked to describe their personal hearing loss in a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 conversation with a teacher]], (name) will identify the type (i.e. bilateral or unilateral), and degree (i.e. normal, mild, moderate, moderately severe, severe, or profound) using the correct terminology, for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss conversations.

By (date), when asked to describe their personal hearing loss in a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 conversation with a teacher]], given a personalized [[visual aids|speech banana]] to reference, (name) will identify the type (i.e. bilateral or unilateral), and degree (i.e. normal, mild, moderate, moderately severe, severe, or profound) using the correct terminology, for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss conversations.

Hearinglink.org's example of an [[https://www.hearinglink.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/speech-banana-800.jpg|illustrated speech banana.]]

(By date), when asked (1) [[guiding questions|guiding question]] about their personal hearing loss during a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 conversation]] with a [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar teacher]], (name) will confirm that a hearing loss exists using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]] (e.g. nodding, picture communication, adaptive switch), (for 4 out of 5) personal hearing loss conversations. *Example guiding question:*
"Do you hear better with your left ear?"
*Example student response:*
Student points to a "thumbs up" picture.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Identify Hearing Loss Type and Degree

udl_adaptations.text: A teacher-led practice conversation that references personal hearing loss data on a [[visual aids|speech banana]] can help students improve communication in relation to their hearing needs. The speech banana offers visuals for the degrees of hearing loss, which is located on the right side of the chart, as well as the type of hearing loss (i.e. bilateral or unilateral). The speech banana will help make a discussion about personal hearing loss more concrete, especially when paired with a guiding question. For example, the teacher can ask, "Does the speech banana show that you have similar hearing in both ears?" With background knowledge of how to interpret a speech banana, the student can say, "No, see, it shows here that the hearing loss in my left ear is moderately-severe."
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.5 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Illustrate through multiple media
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.5 Illustrate through multiple media

udl_adaptations.text: Instead of verbally recognizing a personal hearing loss, a student can use a [[preferred modes of expression|nonverbal communication method]], such as gesturing, nodding in response to a yes/no question, activating an adaptive switch, or signaling with a thumbs up/down. For example, to elicit a yes/no response, the teacher can ask, “Do you hear better with your right ear?” Similarly, if the student uses a communication device, the teacher can ask questions that elicit student answers that have already been pre-programmed into the device. For students who prefer to communicate using images, the teacher can supply picture choices of different scenarios or sounds, and ask the student to select which are easy or difficult for the student in relation to the hearing loss. Students can point to, pick up, or use eye gaze to indicate their selection.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: Middle schoolers are often self-conscious about their hearing loss and choose not to talk about it, sometimes out of a fear of "being different." Therefore, having a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 student-teacher conversation]] will decrease student anxiety and welcome collaboration from both parties. To begin the conversation, the teacher can say, “(Name), I was wondering if you could tell me more about your hearing loss. I want to be able to better serve you as your teacher. Can you tell me what type of hearing loss you have?” The teacher should make a statement about how the student's feedback will help better support the student’s needs, to give the student incentive to continue the conversation. As the discussion continues, the teacher should encourage the student to continue to be candid about their hearing loss when asked, and to use correct terminology (e.g. bilateral, moderately-severe), whenever possible, in order to be taken seriously by the listener.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster collaboration and communication
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.3 Foster collaboration and communication

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example troubleshooting:** Student tests battery, realizes it’s dead, then independently changes battery. **If device can't be troubleshooted:** * If device is school-owned, the student informs hearing teacher the device needs repairs.
* If device is personal, the student informs parent/guardian or personal audiologist.
goals.goal_text: By (date), when a hearing device stops working during school, (name) will independently troubleshoot the device with success (i.e. device turns on and works), or identify how it can be repaired or replaced, for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions.

objectives.text:
By (date), when a hearing device stops working during school, given a [[verbal prompting|teacher prompt]], (name) will independently troubleshoot the device with success (i.e. device turns on and works), or identify how it can be repaired or replaced, for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, "Check that your device is working."

By (date), when a hearing device stops working during school, given a [[verbal prompting|teacher prompt]] and [[visual task schedule|visual checklist]] to reference, (name) will independently troubleshoot the device with success (i.e. device turns on and works), or identify how it can be repaired or replaced, for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions. *Example visual checklist topics:*
• How to change the device batteries.
• How to test the device batteries to verify if they are dead or working.
• How to clean the device.
• How to turn the device on/off.
• When to alert an adult (Educational Audiologist, teacher, parent) about a device issue.

By (date), when a hearing device stops working during school, given a [[verbal prompting|teacher prompt]] and [[visual task schedule|visual checklist]] to reference, (name) will troubleshoot the device with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical teacher assist]], for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions. *Example physical teacher assistance:*
-Teacher opens battery door, hands student batteries.
-Student independently tests battery.
-Student independently puts batteries back into the device.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Fix Device Independently

udl_adaptations.text:
Give students a [[visual task schedule|visual checklist]] that serves as a basic troubleshooting “how-to." Personal hearing devices differ; therefore, the teacher should create a troubleshooting guide for each corresponding student hearing device. Teachers can access troubleshooting guides by contacting the parent/guardian and/or Educational Audiologist prior to the start of the school year, and use it to create a more student-friendly visual checklist. Visual checklists can include topics such as: • How to change the device batteries.
• How to test the device batteries to verify if they are dead or working.
• How to clean the device.
• How to turn the device on/off.
• When to alert an adult (Educational Audiologist, teacher, parent) about a device issue.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

udl_adaptations.text: [[verbal prompting|Prompt]] students to check devices when there are signs of a malfunction. Signals that warrant a device check include: flashing indicator lights, warning sounds (e.g. the student's device “beeps”) or missed auditory information. Students who wear two devices, for example, may not be able to immediately tell if one device needs attention, and a verbal prompt is a quick, easy way to alert them that there is an issue. The prompt should be brief and direct, and students should know what to do once they receive the prompt. For example, if the issue is a dead battery, once prompted by the teacher, the student should quickly move to a designated area in the classroom (e.g. a cubby/container that holds extra batteries) and/or out of the classroom (e.g., student locker, charging station in a predetermined location, etc.) to change the battery, and return to the assigned task immediately after.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 1.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer ways of customizing the display of information
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 1.1 Offer ways of customizing the display of information

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Graduated guidance|Physical teacher assistance]] can help students gain confidence when troubleshooting. Troubleshooting can occur wherever extra supplies are stored, and the DHH teacher or another trained adult can help complete this process. *Troubleshooting actions that may require physical assistance include:*
• Cleaning student earmold/earpiece to remove obstruction that may minimize sound.
• Changing and/or testing the battery life.
• Verifying if device has been set on “mute” mode.
• Restoring sound/volume on device and/or changing programs.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example teacher prompt:**

“Remember to plug the FM in when you’re not using it.”
goals.goal_text: By (date), when told to take care of a hearing device that is not in use during the school day, (name) will independently charge, clean, and stow (i.e. in the proper place and manner) the hearing device, for (4 out of 5) school days.

objectives.text:
By (date), after a [[modeling behaviors|teacher demonstration]], when told to take care of a hearing device that is not in use during the school day, (name) will independently charge, clean, and stow (i.e. in the proper place and manner) the hearing device, for (4 out of 5) school days. *Example teacher demonstrations:*
• How to coil the cord of a Personal FM System when not in use.
• How to turn the device “off,” prior to storing/charging the device.
• How to properly clean the earpiece/earmold of the device.

By (date), after a [[modeling behaviors|teacher demonstration]], given an illustrated device care [[student to-do lists|checklist]], when told to take care of a hearing device that is not in use during the school day, (name) will independently charge, clean, and stow (i.e. in the proper place and manner) the hearing device, for (4 out of 5) school days.

By (date), after a [[modeling behaviors|teacher demonstration]], given an illustrated device care [[student to-do lists|checklist]], when told to take care of a hearing device that is not in use during the school day, (name) will receive [[graduated guidance|graduated teacher guidance]] to charge, clean, and stow (i.e. in the proper place and manner) the hearing device with, for (4 out of 5) school days.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Take Care of Devices When Not in Use

udl_adaptations.text:
Give students who require intensive supports [[graduated guidance|graduated teacher guidance]] to help them learn how to properly maintain and care for a personal hearing device. The guidance can range from physical assistance (e.g. hand-over-hand) to verbal prompts, depending on the need of individual students. *Example scenario:*
Grace uses a personal FM system and has fine motor difficulties. After Grace reviews the checklist on how to properly coil/wrap the personal FM system cord, the teacher uses over-hand guidance to help her wrap the cord correctly.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.3 Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation

udl_adaptations.text:
Give students a [[student to-do lists|visual checklist]] that serves as a basic device care “how-to." Personal hearing devices differ; therefore, the teacher should create a device care guide for each corresponding student hearing device. Teachers can access guides by contacting the parent/guardian and/or Educational Audiologist prior to the start of the school year, and use it to create a more student-friendly visual checklist. Visual checklists can include topics such as: • How to store the device when not in use.
• How to keep the device batteries charged/in working condition.
• How to clean the device.
• When to alert an adult (Educational Audiologist, teacher, parent) about a device issue.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

udl_adaptations.text: [[Modeling behaviors|Demonstrate]] the correct way to utilize, maintain, and care for personal hearing devices (e.g. hearing aid, cochlear implant, classroom sound field system). Model how to turn the device on/off correctly, how to properly charge the device at the end of the school day and/or when not in use, and how to store the device. For example, if a device has a rechargeable battery, state, “This device has rechargeable batteries in it. Make sure the device is turned on/off to allow it to charge when not in use.” For students who need more intense support, provide repetitive over-hand teacher-student demonstrations until the student has learned specific device maintenance and care steps.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

goals.goal_example_text: **Example scenario:** Teacher says, “It is time for recess. Please put your pencils down and clean up your tables.” Student independently takes off hearing aid and gives it to the teacher to leaving the classroom.
goals.goal_text: By (date), when a hearing device doesn't need to be used, (name) will independently take off the hearing device and give it to a teacher to stow, for (4 out of 5) school days.

objectives.text:
By (date), when a hearing device doesn't need to be used, given a [[verbal prompting|teacher prompt]], (name) will independently take off the hearing device and give it to a teacher to stow, for (4 out of 5) school days. *Example teacher prompt:*
"Turn off your FM system and give it to me before you go outside for recess, please."

By (date), when a hearing device doesn't need to be used, given a [[modeling behaviors|teacher demonstration]] and [[verbal prompting|prompted]] to refer to a [[visual task schedule|visual device care checklist]], (name) will independently take off the hearing device and give it to a teacher to stow, for (4 out of 5) school days. *Example teacher demonstration:*
Teacher models how to coil an FM cord before taking it to be charged.

By (date), when a hearing device doesn't need to be used, given a [[verbal prompting|teacher prompt]] to refer to a [[visual task schedule|visual device care checklist]], (name) will receive [[graduated guidance|(1) physical teacher assist]] to take off the hearing device and give it to the teacher to stow, for (4 out of 5) school days. *Example physical teacher assist:*
Teacher uses hand-over-hand to help student remove a hearing device from their ear.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Give Device to Teacher When Not in Use

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Graduated guidance|Physically assist]] students who need intense support to remove a hearing device. Pair the physical assistance with a think aloud, so the steps required to complete the action become familiar to the student over time. With each new trial, gradually decrease the intensity of the physical assistance, comfortably pushing the student toward independence. *Example scenario:*
Grace uses a personal FM system and has fine motor difficulties. After a teacher demonstrates the task using a visual checklist to show how to properly coil/wrap the personal FM system cords, the teacher uses over-hand guidance to help her wrap the cord correctly. The teacher then stows the FM system for Grace until the next time she needs the device.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.3 Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation

udl_adaptations.text: Give students a [[visual task schedule|visual checklist]] that serves as a basic device care “how-to." Personal hearing devices differ; therefore, the teacher should create a device guide for each corresponding student hearing device. Teachers can access guides by contacting the parent/guardian and/or Educational Audiologist prior to the start of the school year, and use it to create a more student-friendly visual checklist. Visual checklists can include topics such as how to remove a hearing aid from the ear or how to turn off a device before handing it to the teacher to stow.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 6.4 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Enhance capacity for monitoring progress
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 6.4 Enhance capacity for monitoring progress

udl_adaptations.text: [[Modeling behaviors|Demonstrate]] the correct way to stop using a personal hearing device (e.g. hearing aid, cochlear implant, classroom sound field system), such as how to turn the device off correctly before giving it to the teacher to stow. For example, if a device has a rechargeable battery, state, “This device has rechargeable batteries in it. Make sure the device is turned off before you give it to me so I can charge it for you.” For students who need more intense support, provide repetitive over-hand teacher-student demonstrations until the student has learned specific device steps to take it off.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example Question:**

Teacher asks, "<u>Why</u> does Hagrid think Harry should know about his parents?"

**Sample Student Response:**

"Harry should know about his parents because..."
goals.goal_text: By (date), when asked a verbal "wh-" question (i.e. who, what, where, when, how, why) about a familiar, grade-level [[familiar people, places, and things|topic]] or [[familiar text|text]], (name) will demonstrate the question was heard correctly by rephrasing the question in the response to address the "wh-" word used, for (4 out of 5) questions.

objectives.example_text:
**Example topic preview:**

"Today we are going to have a conversation about soccer."
objectives.text: By (date), after a topic [[vocabulary preview|preview]], when asked a verbal "wh-" question  (i.e. who, what, where, when, how, why) about a familiar, grade-level [[familiar people, places, and things|topic]] or [[familiar text|text]], (name) will demonstrate the question was heard correctly by rephrasing the question in the response to address the "wh-" word used, for (4 out of 5) questions.

objectives.example_text:
**Example Question Using Verbal Prompt & Repeating:** Teacher asks, "I'm going to ask you a where question. Listen carefully. (2 second pause) Where did Harry go to school? (2 second pause) Where did Harry go to school?" **Example Picture Choices:** * Picture of Hogwarts
* Picture of a Wand
* Picture of Harry Potter
objectives.text: By (date), after a [[acoustic highlighting|verbal cue]] to listen and when asked a verbal "wh-" question (i.e. who, what, where) about a familiar, grade-level [[familiar people, places, and things|topic]] (2) [[repeat the directions|times]] (i.e. ask the question, pause, repeat), (name) will select the answer that addresses the "wh-" word presented in the question from (3) [[picture choices|picture choices]], for (4 out of 5) questions.

objectives.example_text:
**Example Question Paired with Illustration:**

Teacher asks, "Who told Harry about his parents?" and holds up picture of Harry.
objectives.text:
By (date), when asked a verbal "wh-" question (i.e. who, what) about a [[familiar text|familiar]], grade-level topic (2)
