 [[repeat the directions|times]] and paired with a corresponding [[visual aids|illustration]], (name) will select the answer that addresses the "wh-" word presented in the question from (2) [[picture choices|picture choices]] and earn a [[reinforcers|preferred reward/activity]] upon completion, for (4 out of 5) questions.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Rephrase Questions to Respond

udl_adaptations.text: [[Repeat the directions|Repeat]] the "wh-" question to allow a student with a hearing loss a second opportunity to listen, understand and reply to the question. Many times a student will hear the beginning or the end of a question but miss the rest.  When repeating the question, use the same natural voice tone while facing the student. Loud, exaggerated voices can be distorted by a hearing device, making it more difficult to hear the question.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.3 Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation

udl_adaptations.text: Use a [[ Preferred Topic or Text | preferred ]] and [[Familiar People, Places, and Things | familiar ]] topic or story and provide pictures of answer choices to help keep the student engaged in the story and provide visual clues. Students with hearing loss need visual supports to help them understand the entire message and to fill in any missing auditory information. The pictures can help a student remember details about the story, while the preferred topic saves the student from needing to process and recall novel information, instead focusing more solely on auditory discrimination. Picture answer choices can be made by copying parts of a preferred and familiar book picture, drawing your own or searching for appropriate picture choices on the internet. Using preferred or familiar topics keep students engaged in the listening activity and allows them to use background knowledge to understand the story as it is told.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.2 Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity

udl_adaptations.text: Have students use preferred, perhaps nonverbal modes of communication to answer questions. Many times students with hearing loss and other delays need nonverbal ways to communicate, and certainly benefit from avoiding ways of communicating that are difficult or frustrating. Students can indicate understanding of a story and answer questions about the story by [[ Preferred Modes of Expression | pointing to a picture, using a communication device or nodding yes or no ]]. When assessing language skills rather than comprehension (i.e. Is the student correctly hearing the "wh-" word?), use pictures that match the story content, with only one picture correctly addressing the "wh-" question. For example, when asking a "where" question, rather than use three pictures of places described in the text, one picture should be the correct answer to the question, while the other two pictures should be of things (what), times (when), or people (who) from the story. Pictures from a book, clipart, actual photographs or drawings can all be used a a visual response option.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example Task:** Teacher: "promotion"
Student sounds out, "/pro/" then writes "P-R-O". Student sounds out, "/mo/" the writes, "M-O". Student sounds out "/shun/" then writes, "T-I-O-N".
goals.goal_text: By (date), when verbally given a (3)-syllable, unfamiliar word that uses only previously-learned spelling patterns (e.g. the sound /shun/ at the end of a word is usually spelled "-tion"), (name) will spell the word correctly using phoneme segmentation (i.e. break down a word into individual sounds), for (4 out of 5) unfamiliar words.

objectives.text:
By (date), given a (3)-syllable, unfamiliar word that only uses previously-learned spelling patterns, after [[chunking|each segment]] of the word is [[verbal prompting|verbally stated]] by the teacher, (name) will correctly spell the word by writing the letters that correspond with each segment, for (8 out of 10) unfamiliar words. *Example Task:
Teacher says, "Spell promotion. /pro/...", student writes, "P-R-O..."
Teacher says, "/mo/...", student writes, "M-O..."
Teacher says, "/shun/...", student writes, "T-I-O-N"*

By (date), when verbally given a (2)-syllable, [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar word]] (i.e. student has previously heard and used the word), (name) will spell the word [[modified assignment|phonetically]] using phoneme segmentation, [[checks for auditory understanding|checking]] with the teacher no more than (1) time (e.g. "Is the letter for the sound /p/ the letter "P"?), for (4 out of 5) familiar words. *Example Task:
Teacher says, "Spell 'special'."
Student writes, "S-P-E-S-H-U-L"*

By (date), when verbally given (1) [[ Familiar People, Places, and Things | familiar word]] and offered (2) illustrated  [[ response cards | word cards ]], (name) will select the correct word card, [[ Checks for Auditory Understanding | checking ]] with the teacher no more than (2) times (e.g. "Did you say ____?", "Can you repeat the word?"), for (4 out of 5) familiar words.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Spell an Unfamiliar Word

udl_adaptations.text: Give the student [[picture choices|pictures]] of [[ Familiar People, Places, and Things | familiar words ]] while also verbally reading them.  The student should look at the picture while the word is said, and  then look at the speaker as the word is repeated.  The student can point to the picture of the word that was said. This shows the student’s ability to auditorily discriminate between word sounds without having to be able to read or write. Pictures can vary from words that sound similar (e.g. cat, hat, bat) to words that sound very dissimilar (e.g. cat, bed, dog), depending on the student's ability to discriminate sounds in words. The number of pictures should depend upon student ability level, but perhaps be limited to 2-4 options. Using familiar words/pictures will help keep the student engaged in the activity and allow more focus  on the word being said vs the new vocabulary of unfamiliar words.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.2 Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity

udl_adaptations.text:
Provide a [[ word bank | word bank ]] of choices that the student can use to help determine what word was said. The word bank limits the amount of words that could have been spoken and allows the student better success at determining the word that was said. The written word also gives the student a visual clue as to what sounds to be listening for or looking to see on the mouth of the speaker. Give the student a list of 2-5 words, say the word while the student watches the speaker's mouth, say the word again while the student looks at the word list. Repeat once more while the student looks at speaker, if needed, and then have the student point to or say the word that was said. Words can be similar (e.g. cat, fat, rat, mat) or dissimilar (e.g. dog, cat, bed, sit) depending upon the student's discrimination ability level. Start with dissimilar words and move to lists of similar words as the student is able to discriminate between word sound successfully.

*Example Bank: Sit, Fit, Bit, Mitt

Teacher says: “Fit”
Student says or points to fit. This list shows the ability to discriminate between initial word sounds.*
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.4 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Promote understanding across languages
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.4 Promote understanding across languages

udl_adaptations.text:
Allow a student to write a word by spelling it phonetically instead of correctly. Students with a hearing loss need to listen to all sounds in a word and write what is heard. Many times they will miss a sound in a word and need to learn to listen, watch for visual cues (lipread), and say the word themselves to be [[ Checks for Auditory Understanding | sure they are writing all sounds that can be heard in a word ]]. Writing phonetically is the first step in the writing process and should be acceptable practice for students with a hearing loss until they are cognitively aware enough to learn all of the unwritten rules of spelling. Students with a hearing loss may not have access to all sounds that can be heard in a word so they need extra practice using visual cues to be sure that all sounds that can be heard are used to spell a word.

*Ex: teacher says: special
Student: writes speshul*
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 6.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Facilitate managing information and resources
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 6.3 Facilitate managing information and resources

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example Discussion:** Teacher: "Discuss what you did this weekend with your group."
Peer 1: "I went to the zoo on Sunday and saw a movie!"
Student: "I saw a movie, too! What movie did you see?"
goals.goal_text: By (date), during a small-group discussion in the classroom, with [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar]] peers and/or adults, when it is their turn to speak (e.g. asked a question, a natural pause in discussion), (name) will contribute a (2)-sentence, on-topic response or question, for (4 of 5) turns in the discussion.

objectives.text:
By (date), during a small group discussion in the classroom, with [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar]] peers and/or adults, given no more than (2) teacher [[ verbal prompting | verbal ]] or [[ visual cueing | visual ]] prompts, (name) will contribute a (2)-sentence. on-topic response or question, for (4 of 5) turns in the discussion. *Example Teacher Prompts:*
Teacher says, “Did you hear what your classmate said?”
Teacher holds up a card that is a signal for “Your turn, ask for clarification if you didn’t hear.”

By (date), when asked a [[verbal prompting|direct question]] (i.e. student's name is used) paired with a [[visual cueing|visual cue]] (e.g. turns body toward student) during a small-group discussion in the classroom, with [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar]] peers and/or adults, (name) will contribute a [[modified assignment | (3)-word]], on-topic response or question, for (4 of 5) teacher-directed conversations. *Example Direct Question:*
“Anika, what's something you saw on our field trip to the farm yesterday?”

By (date), while playing a turn-taking game (e.g. [[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-zPd837yVcwNThMY0RQbzlsZnc/view|Topple]], [[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B-zPd837yVcwZm1iWlBPR3Q4Y0k/view|Trouble]]) in a quiet setting with [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar]] peers and/or adults, before taking their turn in the game, when asked a direct question (i.e. student's name is used) paired with a [[visual cueing|visual cue]] (e.g. turns body toward student), (name) will contribute to the discussion by pressing a button on an [[adaptive switches|AAC Device]] with a pre-recorded response, for (4 out of 5) turns in the discussion. *Example Game with Built-In Conversation:*
1. Teacher gives student the dice, and says, "It's your turn. Before you throw the dice, tell me--what did you eat for dinner yesterday?" 2. Student presses AAC Device with the pre-recorded response, "I ate spaghetti," and throws the dice for their turn on the board game.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Take Turns in a Small-Group Discussion

udl_adaptations.text: Use a [[ verbal prompting | verbal ]] or [[ visual cueing | visual ]] prompt to remind students that they need to respond in a social situation. Many times, a DHH student will sit in a group setting and let the other members of the group carry the conversation. This is easier, requires less listening, and is an easy way to mask the fact that they are missing information and not able to keep up with the conversation. A teacher can use a verbal prompt (e.g. What do you think?) that reminds the student that it is time to participate in the conversation. A visual prompt can also be taught and agreed upon with the target student, particularly if the student is averse to the spotlight that a verbal prompt can place upon her. A colored index card held up by the teacher, barely noticeable to anyone else, could cue the student that it is time to contribute. The teacher can also repeat the question, or repeat what another student said to ensure that the DHH student heard the message and can then be more successful in responding appropriately. If the response is not on topic, the teacher needs to repeat the message again, have the student respond again, and then model an on-topic response if still not successful. Have the group sit in the back of the classroom or move to the hall or another quiet area if the DHH student is continually not able to keep up with the group discussion. The background noise may be too much for the student to hear and follow along.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

udl_adaptations.text:
Have students respond with a [[ modified assignment | short sentence ]] (can be incomplete) when they are first learning to respond in a social setting. Children with hearing loss will leave out small words in a sentence (e.g. articles, pronouns) but give the big words and get the concept across (e.g. nouns, verbs). When asking a child to engage in a social conversation, let him get the concept of the answer across as he learns to expand social conversation skills. Repeat the student’s answer—using the correct word order—as a model, and wait to build the response into a complete sentence at a later time. Students leave out the small words because they miss them when a sentence is said aurally. When students are just starting to learn to respond in a social setting, allow them to respond once with an appropriate on-topic response. After they are able to respond successfully with one sentence, next continue the conversation, guiding the student to a second on-topic response. If the student does not respond on-topic, repeat the original message, and prompt the student to respond. If still not on-topic, use a visual (picture) of the message topic to help the student follow along better.
*Example Visual Support:*
Teacher: “Tell me one thing you did at the science museum on your field trip yesterday. (Show a picture of the child doing an activity at the museum.)
Student: I played with the planet models. (Play with planets) also an acceptable response.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

udl_adaptations.text: Use a social [[ language-based games | conversation game ]] topic starter to get students interested in talking to each other. Topics can be found by searching online for “conversation starter games”. The teacher reads the prompt and then each child takes a turn answering the questions by commenting on the topic. As each student takes their turn in the conversation task, have a game (e.g. Monopoly, UNO, Trouble) that each student can take a turn at playing once they have contributed their on-topic response to the conversation. After every correct on-topic contribution to a conversation starter, the student could take a turn at the motivating game. If the student answers incorrectly, repeat the conversation starter prompt and have him try it again. If still wrong, model a correct on-topic response and have the student try one more time. After three attempts, allow the student to take a turn at the motivation game. The extra motivation of playing a fun game will help students continue to want to converse with each other and the teacher.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.2 Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity

goals.goal_text: By (date), in a controlled environment (e.g. quiet space, teacher turns off the device), after recognizing that a personal hearing device is not working, (name) will notify the teacher (e.g. verbally, by pointing to the device), for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions.

objectives.example_text:
**Example prompt:**

Teacher says, “Is your device working ok?”
objectives.text: By (date), in a controlled environment (e.g. quiet space, teacher turns off the device), given no more than (1) teacher [[ verbal prompting|prompt]], after recognizing that a personal hearing device is not working, (name) will notify the teacher (e.g. verbally, by pointing to the device), for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions.

By (date), during a daily routine hearing device [[check in/check out|check]] (e.g. after every two classroom activities, before a transition), when the teacher [[ verbal prompting|asks ]] if the device is working, (name) will notify the teacher (e.g. verbally, by pointing to the device), for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions.

By (date), during a daily routine hearing device [[check in/check out|check]] (e.g. after every two classroom activities, before a transition), given yes/no [[picture choices|picture response cards]], when [[ verbal prompting | asked ]] if a personal hearing device is working, (name) will correctly indicate yes or no (e.g. by picking up a card, nodding, stating), for (4 out of 5) daily routine hearing checks.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Recognize Device Isn't Working

udl_adaptations.text: Schedule device [[check in/check out|check times]] throughout the day to help a student move toward independently reporting device malfunctions. Check times should be consistent: at the start of school day, mid-morning, and mid-afternoon, for example, and can also be incorporated into a student’s written or picture schedule. Check the device in the area of the classroom where extra batteries and a battery tester are located, to allow for easy troubleshooting and repair of the device if the student reports a problem.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster collaboration and communication
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.3 Foster collaboration and communication

udl_adaptations.text: [[verbal prompting|Prompt]] students to check their devices. A student might hear the device beeping when the battery is failing, but become sidetracked before reporting it to a teacher. To prompt the student to report on the device, the teacher can simply say something like “Device check!” or “Check your aids,” or “Listening check." Utilize prompts like these after a significant amount of time has passed since the last device check, during transition times when a student has been out of the classroom a while, or when the teacher suspects a problem (no flashing indicator light on device, student not responding or participating as normal).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

udl_adaptations.text: Allow a student to use gestures, [[picture choices|pictures]] or other non-verbal responses to indicate a hearing device is not working properly. For example, a student can simply point to the device to let a teacher know that something is wrong. This allows the student to report a problem during instruction without interrupting. Picture cards can also be used to report device problems when paired with a teacher prompt (e.g. teacher asks, "Is your device working?"). Picture cards can be a red frown face (not working) and a green smiley face (working), or a picture of the hearing device (photo taken of actual device or picture from computer) with a thumbs up (working) or thumbs down (not working).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_text: By (date), when asked to explain a personal hearing loss, using a speech banana drawn from a current personal audiogram, (name) will describe all sounds that they can and can't hear, for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss explanations.

objectives.text: By (date), when asked to explain a personal hearing loss during a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 discussion with a teacher]], using a speech banana drawn from a current personal audiogram, (name) will describe all sounds that they can and can't hear, for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss explanations.

By (date), when asked to explain a personal hearing loss during a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 discussion with a teacher]], using a speech banana drawn from a current personal audiogram, after the teacher uses an example speech banana to [[teacher modeling academic task|demonstrate]] the task, (name) will describe all sounds that they can and can't hear, for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss explanations.

By (date), during a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 discussion with a teacher]], given a speech banana drawn from a current personal [[visual aids|illustrated]] audiogram, and asked to identify (2) sounds that they can hear and (2) sounds they can't, (name) will select each sound when prompted (e.g. by pointing, describing, using an [[adaptive switches|adaptive switch]]), for (4 out of 5) personal hearing loss explanations. Example [[https://www.hearinglink.org/your-hearing/hearing-tests-audiograms/what-is-the-speech-banana/|illustrated speech banana]] from Hearinglink.org. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, "Show me a sound you can't hear."

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Use Speech Banana to Explain Hearing Loss

udl_adaptations.text: [[Teacher modeling academic task|Demonstrate]] how the speech banana can be used to explain personal hearing loss to a layperson. For example, start with presentation basics by saying, “If I am holding the speech banana and it is facing downward, the audience can't see the data.” Then, demonstrate how to properly hold the speech banana; providing the student with understanding of how the presentation will be seen from the audience's perspective. To help the student understand how to illustrate specific elements when presenting the speech banana, say, “If I don’t use my finger to show the lines of blue Xs and red Os that represent the left and right ears, the audience won't automatically know what I'm talking about.” Then, use a pointed finger to trace the line of symbols (i.e., X’s or O’s) on the speech banana.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.3 Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation

udl_adaptations.text:
[[modified assignment|Modify]] this task to accommodate non-verbal students. To begin, ask the student to identify which sounds can or can't be heard. Some students will be able to describe specific sounds, while others will benefit if given access to an illustrated audiogram/speech banana that includes picture representations of sounds embedded into the chart. When asked, the student can point to sounds that fall within or out of personal hearing range. *Example teacher prompt to elicit a non-verbal response:*
Teacher says, “Show me a sound that you can easily hear with your right ear.” *Example student response:*
Student points to the picture of a crying baby.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: Teach students to use a speech banana as a self-advocacy tool. Exposure to a speech banana derived from personal hearing loss data allows students to familiarize themselves with their individual hearing needs, as well as develop vocabulary associated with hearing loss. This activity can be completed repeatedly, with multiple teachers and/or peers. Discussions like these prepare students to naturally advocate for themselves in the workplace and in a variety of social situations.

udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.2 Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example:** Teacher: “Is your right hearing device on?”
Student: “Yes.”
Teacher: “Is your left hearing device on?”
Student: “No.”
goals.goal_text: By (date), before beginning a classroom activity, when asked to identify if a personal hearing device is on or off, (name) will state the answer, for (4 out of 5) classroom activities.

objectives.text:
By (date), before beginning a classroom activity, when taken to a [[noise reduction in the classroom|quiet]] space and asked to identify if a personal hearing device is on or off, (name) will state the answer, for (4 out of 5) classroom activities. *Example quiet spaces:*
• A hallway when class is in session
• A corner of the room during silent reading
• A separate classroom

By (date), during a [[warm-up|practice session]] in a [[noise reduction in the classroom|quiet]] space, when the teacher turns a personal hearing device on or off and asks the student to identify whether the device is on or off, (name) will state the answer, for (4 out of 5) practice sessions. *Example practice session:*
Teacher switches right hearing device on, then off.
Teacher asks the student: "Is your right device on or off?"
Student replies: "Off."

By (date), given yes/no [[picture choices|picture response options]], during a [[warm-up|practice session]] in a [[noise reduction in the classroom|quiet]] space, when the teacher turns a personal hearing device on or off and asks the student to identify whether the device is on or off, (name) will select the corresponding picture, for (4 out of 5) practice sessions. *Example yes/no picture choices:*
• Red card for "no," green card for "yes."
• "X" for "no," checkmark for "yes."
• Sad face for "no," happy face for "yes."

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Recognize if Hearing Device is On/Off

udl_adaptations.text: Present this task in a [[noise reduction in the classroom|quiet]] setting. This helps students focus on the sound made by the amplification device as they learn to differentiate between on and off amplification. A hearing device can amplify every sound, not only speech, and it can be very difficult for newly amplified students to learn specific hearing skills in a loud setting. After students master the skill in a quiet setting, move to the classroom environment and practice again. Example quiet settings include: a hallway when class is in session, a corner of the room during silent reading, or a separate classroom.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize individual choice and autonomy
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.1 Optimize individual choice and autonomy

udl_adaptations.text: Use [[warm-up|practice]] sessions to help the student recognize when a hearing device is on or off in a controlled setting. To begin the practice session, turn the device off, then ask the student to identify if it’s on or off. Then, turn the device on and ask again if it’s on or off. It's also an option to pretend to turn a device on or off and ask the student to report. This strategy will check the student’s recognition of the device being on or off versus simply feeling the teacher touch the hearing device for a cue. The practice sessions should take place in a quiet environment, and then moved into the classroom setting once the student masters the skill.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

udl_adaptations.text: Create yes/no [[picture choices|picture]] cards to elicit nonverbal responses from students. Use simple, symbolic pictures to indicate "on" (e.g. green smiley face) and "off" (red frown face), and make sure the student knows what each picture represents before starting the task. To start the assessment, point to one amplification device on a student's ear and ask either, “On?” or "Off?"  The student can then pick up or point to the card that represents the answer (yes or no). First introduce the picture response cards in a quiet environment. Once students begin to show mastery, they can be used in the classroom for daily reporting.

udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

objectives.text: By (date), when a personal hearing device is not working, after the teacher [[verbal prompting|asks]] about the status of the device, (name) will notify the teacher that the device malfunctioned (e.g. verbally, by pointing to the device, nodding), for (4 out of 5) device malfunctions.

By (date), during a daily routine hearing device [[check in/check out|check]] (e.g. after every two classroom activities, before a transition), when [[verbal prompting|asked]] if a personal hearing device is working, (name) will correctly indicate yes or no (e.g. by nodding, stating, gesturing), for (4 out of 5) daily routine hearing checks.

By (date), during a daily routine hearing device [[check in/check out|check]] (e.g. after every two classroom activities, before a transition), given yes/no [[picture choices|picture response cards]], when asked if a personal hearing device is working, (name) will correctly indicate yes or no (e.g. by picking up a card, nodding, stating), for (4 out of 5) daily routine hearing checks.

Check times should be consistent: at the start of school day, mid-morning, and mid-afternoon, for example, and can also be incorporated into a student’s written or picture schedule. Check the device in the area of the classroom where extra batteries and a battery tester are located, to allow for easy troubleshooting and repair of the device if the student reports a problem.

For example, a student can simply point to the device to let a teacher know that something is wrong. This allows the student to report a problem during instruction without interrupting. Picture cards can also be used to report device problems when paired with a teacher prompt (e.g. teacher asks, "Is your device working?"). goals.goal_text: By (date), after recognizing that a personal hearing device battery died during a school activity, (name) will independently change the battery with success (i.e. the hearing device is on), for (4 out of 5) battery failures.

objectives.example_text:
**Example prompt:**

Teacher sees that hearing device indicator light is off and says, "Device check."

**Example student response:**

Student realizes right ear device isn't on, moves to the back of the room to change the battery.
objectives.text: By (date), when a personal hearing device battery dies during a school activity, given a [[verbal prompting|teacher prompt]] (e.g. teacher tells student to check battery), (name) will independently change the battery with success (i.e. the hearing device is on), for (4 out of 5) battery failures.

objectives.example_text:
**Example physical teacher assistance:** Student independently takes device off.
Teacher opens battery door, inserts new batteries.
Student closes battery door.
objectives.text: By (date), when a personal hearing device battery dies during a school activity, given a [[verbal prompting|teacher prompt]] (e.g. teacher tells student to check battery), (name) will change the battery successfully (i.e. the hearing device is on) with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical teacher assist]], for (4 out of 5) battery failures.

objectives.example_text:
**Example rewards:**

* Sticker on rewards chart
* Pencil with image of favorite character
* 5 minutes of preferred activity time
objectives.text: By (date), during a school activity, given a teacher [[verbal prompting|prompt]] to change a personal hearing device battery, after the teacher [[modeling routines, skills, and procedures|demonstrates]] how to change it, (name) will change the battery successfully (i.e. the hearing device is on) with (2) [[graduated guidance|physical teacher assists]], and receive a [[reinforcers|reward]] upon completion, for (4 out of 5) battery failures.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Independently Change Device Battery

udl_adaptations.text: [[Verbal prompting|Prompt]] students to check devices if there are signs of dead batteries. Signals that warrant a device check include flashing indicator lights or missed auditory information. Young students who wear two devices, for example, may not be able to immediately tell if one device needs attention, and a verbal prompt is a quick, easy way to alert them that there is an issue. The prompt should be brief and direct, and students should know what to do once they receive the prompt. For example, if the teacher taps his ear and says, "Battery check," students should know that he is telling them replace to a dead battery. Protocol for battery replacement should also be discussed prior to using a verbal prompt. For example, once prompted by the teacher, students will quickly move to a designated area in the classroom (e.g. a cubby that holds extra batteries) to change the battery, and return to the assigned task immediately after.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

udl_adaptations.text:
[[graduated guidance|Physically assist]] students who need help changing device batteries independently. To start, the teacher can demonstrate the entire process from start to finish while the student watches. Then, the student can complete individual steps of the process with physical teacher support. Intense physical teacher assistance can look something like this:
-The teacher takes the hearing device off of the student, opens battery door, changes battery out.
-The student closes the battery door.
-The teacher puts hearing device back on. Slightly less intense physical teacher assistance can look something like this:
-The teacher helps the student hold the correct part of the hearing device and assists with taking it off.
-The student opens the battery door.
-The teacher changes the battery.
-The student closes battery door.
-The teacher puts the hearing device back on.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

udl_adaptations.text: [[Reinforcers|Reward]] students who change device batteries successfully within a specified time frame. Young students might push back when asked to independently change a device battery, especially if they are used to having adults do it for them. Whether or not a student changes a battery alone or with physical teacher assistance, positive reinforcement will help them move further toward independent device care. Example rewards for this age group include a sticker on a rewards chart, small prizes like colorful erasers or pencils, shout-outs, or 5 minutes of a preferred activity.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example question:**

Classmate asks, "Why do you wear that on your ear?"

**Example student explanations:**

Student says, “It's a cochlear implant and it turns sounds into a code that my brain understands.”
goals.goal_text: By (date), when a [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar]] person asks about a personal hearing device, (name) will identify the type of device (e.g. hearing aid, CI, BAHA) and correctly describe how it allows for better hearing (e.g. makes sounds louder, turns sounds into a code for the brain to hear), for (4 out of 5) device questions.

objectives.text: By (date), during a [[student-teacher conference|student-teacher]] conference, when asked about a personal hearing device, (name) will identify the type of device (e.g. hearing aid, CI, BAHA) and correctly describe how it allows for better hearing (e.g. makes sounds louder, turns sounds into a code for the brain to hear), for (4 out of 5) device questions.

By (date), during a [[student-teacher conference|student-teacher]] conference, when the teacher asks [[multiple choice|which of (2) answer choices]] describes how a personal hearing device works (e.g. makes sounds louder; turns sounds into a code for the brain to hear), (name) will select the answer, for (4 out of 5) device questions. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, “How does your hearing aid help you hear?" *Example answer choices:*
• Makes everything louder
• Turns sounds into a code my brain understands *Example student response:*
Student says, "My hearing aid makes everything louder."

By (date), during a [[student-teacher conference|student-teacher]] conference, given [[picture choices|pictures]] of (2) different hearing devices (e.g. hearing aid, CI) and asked to identify [[multiple choice|which is the device worn personally]], (name) will select the answer (e.g. by pointing, stating, using an [[adaptive switches|adaptive switch]]), for (4 out of 5) device questions.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Describe Hearing Device

udl_adaptations.text: Provide [[picture choices|pictures]] of different hearing devices to help a student learn to identify which device he or she personally wears. Pictures can be printed from the Internet (photos can be found on the manufacturer's website), or use a photograph of a student's actual device. Verbally label the pictures, so the student learns the correct name of the different devices. To meet this goal, give the student two pictures: one of the device he or she uses and another, less familiar device. Verbally label them and ask, "Which device is the one you use?" The student can then repeat the name of the device, or simply point to the picture.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.5 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Illustrate through multiple media
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.5 Illustrate through multiple media

udl_adaptations.text:
Use [[multiple choice|multiple choice]] response options to ease student frustration. It can be difficult to remember the necessary words to explain how a hearing device works, and two verbal choices can remind a student of the answer without requiring independent recall. The terms should be communicated using language that is appropriate to the individual child's ability level. *Example multiple choice scenario:*
Teacher asks, "Does your hearing aid make everything louder or turn sounds into a code?"
Student responds, "It makes everything louder."
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: A brief [[student-teacher conference|student-teacher conference]] is a great way to help the student get comfortable with fielding questions about a device in a non-threatening environment. The hearing provider is likely best equipped to hold these conferences with the student: if the student doesn't know an answer to a question about a device, the provider can help the student devise an informed response. Start by explicitly explaining *why* the conversation is taking place (e.g. "Today we are going to talk about what to say when curious people ask about your hearing device."). Then, ask questions that strangers or peers might ask the student, such as "What is that on your ear?" or "How does it work?"
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster collaboration and communication
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.3 Foster collaboration and communication

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example maintenance situation:** FM transmitter battery low during art class. **Example student response:** * Step 1: Student raises hand to alert teacher, asks to go to homeroom class to plug in FM system to charge.
* Step 2: Student plugs in FM.
* Step 3: After FM system charges for one hour, student goes back to retrieve it to use the rest of the day.
goals.goal_text: By (date), after recognizing a hearing device or amplification accessory needs basic maintenance (e.g. battery change, cleaning), (name) will independently complete a (3)-step maintenance task, in (4 out of 5) situations requiring maintenance.

objectives.text: By (date), when [[verbal prompting|prompted]] to check if a hearing device or amplification accessory needs basic maintenance (e.g. battery change, cleaning), after recognizing maintenance is required, (name) will independently complete a (3)-step maintenance task, in (4 out of 5) situations requiring maintenance.

By (date), when [[verbal prompting|prompted]] to check if a hearing device or amplification accessory needs basic maintenance (e.g. battery change, cleaning), after recognizing maintenance is required, (name) will complete a (3)-step maintenance task with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical teacher assist]], in (4 out of 5) basic maintenance situations.

By (date), after a teacher determines that a hearing device or amplification accessory needs basic maintenance (e.g. battery change, cleaning), given a [[visual task schedule|visual task schedule]], (name) will complete [[modified assignment|(1) part of a (3)-step maintenance task]] with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical teacher assist]], in (4 out of 5) basic maintenance situations.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Complete Device Maintenance

udl_adaptations.text:
Create a [[visual task schedule|visual task schedule]] to illustrate basic device care steps for tasks like cleaning a mold or changing a battery. As students become more independent, the visual schedule will help them complete the task without adult guidance. Place the task schedule in the area where extra batteries and mold cleaning tools are kept, so students don't have to remember to bring it along when a device needs maintenance, and can easily reference it as needed. Pictures for the task schedule can be found on device manufacturer websites, or take pictures of an adult completing each step with a student's hearing device.
*Example visual task schedule steps for morning FM hookup routine:*
1) Unplug FM transmitter.
2) Put FM receivers on hearing device.
3) Turn FM transmitter on.
4) Sync FM transmitter to receivers.
5) Listen for indicator beeps that transmitter is connected to receivers.
6) Give transmitter to teacher to complete listening check (to be sure FM and hearing device are working properly).
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize individual choice and autonomy
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.1 Optimize individual choice and autonomy

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Verbal prompting|Prompt]] a student to check if a hearing device needs basic maintenance, such as a battery change or a cleaning. This reminder can come first thing in the morning, after a transition, or when the normal daily routine is different. Students with hearing loss often need reminders to complete basic maintenance care. Distractions or changes in routine can lead them to forget to do it independently. *Example teacher prompt:*
At the end of the PM homeroom, teacher says, “FM care.” *Example student response:*
Student turns transmitter off and plugs in to charge; puts receivers in storage case.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

udl_adaptations.text:
Sometimes, it's necessary to [[graduated guidance|physically assist]] a student who needs to complete a basic device care task. For example, a student may need hand-over-hand assistance to pull out/off a hearing device, put a device back in/on, put a battery in or use a cleaning tool. If the student needs more intervention than hand-over-hand guidance, the teacher can complete one or more of steps in the process while the student watches how it is done. Putting a battery in, for example, is an action the teacher can do alone: since the battery is so small, hand-over-hand isn’t always practical.
*Example physical assistance:*
• Teacher puts FM receivers on the hearing device to ensure they are secure.
• Student unplugs transmitter, turns it on and hands to teacher to sync and complete listening check.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example devices:** * Hearing aid (5 parts)
* Cochlear implant (4 or more parts)
* BAHA (3 or more parts) **Example student response:** Student says, “This is a hearing aid. The battery door holds the battery, the hearing aid amplifies sound so I can hear better, the ear hook keeps the aid on my ear, the tubing attaches to the mold, and the mold goes in my ear to deliver the sound directly to my ear.”
goals.goal_text: By (date), when asked to explain a personal hearing device to a familiar person, (name) will label each part of the device and explain what it does, for (3 out of 3) device explanations.

objectives.text: By (date), when asked to explain a personal hearing device to a familiar person, given a [[visual aids|picture]] of the device to reference (i.e. so device can still be worn to hear), (name) will label each part of the device, and explain what it does, for (3 out of 3) device explanations.

By (date), when asked to explain a personal hearing device to a familiar person, given a [[visual aids|picture]] of the device (i.e. so device can still be worn to hear) and a [[word bank|bank]] of written part names, (name) will label each part of the device with options from the bank, for (3 out of 3) device explanation situations. *Example word bank for a hearing aid:*
• Microphone
• Battery compartment
• Earmold
• Tubing
• On/off switch

By (date), given a [[visual aids|picture]] of a personal hearing device (i.e. so device can still be worn to hear), when the teacher names (1) device part, (name) will indicate the device part on the picture using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]], for (3 out of 3) device explanations. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, "Can you show me the battery?" *Example student response:*
Student points to the battery on the device picture.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Explain All Parts of Personal Device

udl_adaptations.text: Use a [[visual aids|diagram or picture]] of a personal hearing device so a student can see all of the device parts while explaining what each part does. During a conversation about how a device works, a student will still need to use the device to hear, and therefore probably wouldn't take it off to show each part. A diagram of a device can easily be found online, by searching for the student's specific make and model. The manufacturer's website (e.g. Phonak, Cochlear, Oticon) may have a diagram as well. As an extension activity, students can color each device part a different color, to help further differentiate between the parts.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.5 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Illustrate through multiple media
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.5 Illustrate through multiple media

udl_adaptations.text:
Provide a [[word bank|bank]] of written device parts that students can use to label pictures of their personal hearing devices. Device part names can be technical and difficult to remember, especially if the device is new to the student. Giving answer options helps familiarize the student with each term. Students can either use the written choices as references and verbally label the device parts, or physically place them onto the picture. *Example word bank for a cochlear implant:*
• Processor
• Battery door
• Cord
• Headpiece
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.2 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Use multiple tools for construction and composition
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.2 Use multiple tools for construction and composition

udl_adaptations.text: Modify this task so students can respond using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]]. There are a few ways to accomplish this. One way is that the teacher can verbally state a device part and ask the student to identify it on a picture (or actual device). The student can point, gesture, use a communication device or adaptive switch to indicate the location of the part. Another way would be to ask yes or no questions about the various parts of the hearing device. For example, the teacher can point to the battery door and say, "Is this the cord?" The student would then shake her head "No," in response. This strategy is ideal for students who prefer not to use spoken language to communicate - even though they won't provide a verbal "explanation," it allows them to show understanding of how their devices work.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize individual choice and autonomy
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.1 Optimize individual choice and autonomy

goals.goal_text:
By (date), given a resource with information on hearing assistive technology trends (e.g. a magazine, website),
(name) will identify at least (1) available device that is compatible with current hearing needs, for (4 out of 5) device exploration opportunities.

objectives.text: By (date), during a [[student-teacher conference|discussion]] with a teacher, given a resource with information on hearing assistive technology trends (e.g. a magazine, website), (name) will identify at least (1) available device that is compatible with current hearing needs, for (4 out of 5) device exploration opportunities.

objectives.example_text:
**Example picture choices:** * Personal FM
* Bluetooth Device
* Hearing Loop
**Example teacher prompt:** Teacher asks, "Which of these is compatible with your current device?"
objectives.text: By (date), during a [[student-teacher conference|discussion]] with a teacher, given a resource with information on hearing assistive technology trends (e.g. a magazine, website) with (3) targeted [[picture choices|picture choices]] of hearing assistive technology devices, (name) will identify at least (1) available device that is compatible with current hearing needs, for (4 out of 5) device exploration opportunities.

objectives.example_text:
**Example preferred modes of expression:**

* Pointing
* Nodding to answer “yes” to a teacher’s question
* Eye gaze
objectives.text: By (date), during a [[student-teacher conference|discussion]] with a teacher, given a resource with information on hearing assistive technology trends (e.g. a magazine, website) with (3) targeted [[picture choices|picture choices]] of hearing assistive technology devices, (name) will use a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]] to identify at least (1) available device that is compatible with current hearing needs, for (4 out of 5) device exploration opportunities.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Research Compatible Personal Devices

udl_adaptations.text:
Allow non-verbal students to complete this goal using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]]. To begin, give students picture choices of different devices and ask them to gesture or nod in response to verbal questions. The pictures can be circled or highlighted in a sales magazine, or printed from a website. When possible, include written information about each device with the picture (e.g. description, specifications). In relation to this task, ask students to demonstrate understanding of their hearing needs by identifying one device that is compatible with their current hearing equipment from the pictures. *Implementation example:*
• Teacher says, “Show me a device from this page that is compatible with your hearing equipment (e.g. BAHA, CI or hearing aids).”
• Student points to a compatible device.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text:
Offer colorful, detailed [[picture choices|pictures]] of hearing assistive technology (HAT) devices to help students recognize what's available. The pictures can be presented on paper or digitally on a computer or tablet screen. *Some resources include:*
• HearWI.org's [[https://hearwi.org/best-sellers/ |"Shop" page]]
• Harris Communications' Annual Magazine or Harris Communications' [[http://www.harriscomm.com |website]]
• Articles such as "The Complete Guide to Hearable Technology" from Everyday Hearing's [[https://www.everydayhearing.com/hearing-technology/articles/hearables/ |blog]].
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.5 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Illustrate through multiple media
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.5 Illustrate through multiple media

udl_adaptations.text:
Lead a [[student-teacher conference|1:1 discussion]] about new devices on the market. To start, give the student a resource that includes images and product information about various current devices, like [[http://www.hearingloss.org/sites/default/files/styles/mag_cover/public/HLM_MarApr2016_large.jpg?itok=s3E9ok84 |"Hearing Loss Magazine”]], for example, or the website [[https://hearwi.org|HearWI.org]]. Once the student identifies a device of interest, facilitate the discussion with questions such as:
• “Is this device compatible with your current hearing equipment (i.e. BAHA, CI or hearing aid)?”
• “Why would this device be helpful to you?”
Questions like these create awareness of the devices that are currently available.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster collaboration and communication
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.3 Foster collaboration and communication

goals.goal_text: By (date), during school, after recognizing a basic hearing device function needs to be adjusted (e.g. on/off, volume), (name) will independently adjust the function with success (i.e. adjustment allows clear/accurate hearing), for (4 out of 5) device adjustments.

objectives.text:
By (date), during school, given a [[verbal prompting|prompt]] to check a personal hearing device, after recognizing a basic function needs to be adjusted (e.g. on/off, volume), (name) will independently adjust the function with success (i.e. adjustment allows clear/accurate hearing), for (4 out of 5) device adjustments. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, "Check that your hearing aid is on."

By (date), during school, given a [[verbal prompting|prompt]] to check a personal hearing device, after recognizing a basic function needs to be adjusted (e.g. on/off, volume), (name) will successfully adjust the function (i.e. adjustment allows clear/accurate hearing) with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical teacher assist]], for (4 out of 5) device adjustments.

By (date), during school, when a teacher determines a hearing device needs to be [[modified assignment|turned on or off]], (name) will successfully turn the device on or off with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical teacher assist]] and a [[shout outs|shout out]] upon completion, for (4 out of 5) device adjustments.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Use Basic Device Features

udl_adaptations.text:
Use a [[shout outs|shout out]] to motivate students to independently adjust their hearing devices. Students need reinforcements to encourage independence: some will assume the teacher or a parent can always adjust device functions for them. When giving the shout out, be specific and tell the student exactly what he or she did right. For example, when a student adjusts the volume, say, "Great job turning up the volume on your own!" *For this age group, give shout-outs when:*
• Students turn the volume dial up by themselves.
• Students pop battery door open themselves.
• Students turn CI on independently.
• Students turn BAHA off before putting it in a storage case.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.4 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Increase mastery-oriented feedback
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.4 Increase mastery-oriented feedback

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Verbal prompting|Prompt]] students to adjust hearing device functions to allow for better hearing. Young students in elementary school often need a reminder to turn the device on or off, or to adjust the volume level for a specific situation. *Example situation:* Device needs to be turned off and put in the case before going to recess. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher says, “Remember to turn your hearing off before you store it in your case for recess.” *Example student response:*
Student takes aid out, pops battery door to turn aid off, and places aid in storage case.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

udl_adaptations.text:
Sometimes, students may need [[graduated guidance|physical assistance]] to adjust basic functions on a hearing device. Using a volume dial or turning a hearing device on/off can be difficult: the buttons and dials are very tiny, and are hard to find by touch. *Example scenario:*
Hearing aid volume needs to be turned up for math class. *Example physical assistance:*
Teacher helps student locate the volume dial on the back of hearing aid by placing student's finger on the dial; student pushes dial up to turn the volume up on the device.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example scenario:**

Student needs to listen to a recording on a tablet.

**Example student response:**

Student switches to bluetooth mode and connects to tablet via bluetooth to listen to the recording.
goals.goal_text: By (date), after recognizing a situation in school requires an advanced hearing device feature (e.g. bluetooth, different program), (name) will determine which feature best suits the situation and independently activate it, for (4 out of 5) listening situations.

objectives.text: By (date), when [[verbal prompting|prompted]] to use an advanced hearing device feature (e.g. bluetooth, different program) in school, (name) will determine which feature best suits the situation and independently activate it, for (4 out of 5) listening situations.

By (date), when [[verbal prompting|prompted]] to use an advanced hearing device feature (e.g. bluetooth, different program) in school, given a [[multiple choice|choice]] between (2) features, (name) will choose the feature best suited to the situation and independently activate it, for (4 out of 5) listening situations.

By (date), when [[verbal prompting|told]] to use a specific advanced hearing device feature (e.g. bluetooth, different program) in school, (name) will activate it with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical teacher assist]], and receive a [[shout outs|shout out]] upon completion, for (4 out of 5) listening situations.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Use Advanced Device Features

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Verbal prompting|Prompt]] students who don't immediately activate a device feature when they need to. As students learn to use various advanced features on a personal hearing device, they may also need to be told *which* feature to use for a given situation. *Example scenario:*
The classroom has an increase in background noise during small group work. *Example teacher prompt:*
Teacher asks, "The background noise has increased. Should you change something on your hearing device?" *Example student response:*
Student says, “Oh yeah...I should use my program 2,” then pushes the program button on the hearing device.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

udl_adaptations.text:
Some students will need [[graduated guidance|physical assistance]] to use advanced features on a hearing device: determining which button or switch to use while wearing the device can be difficult, especially if the device is new to the student. Use hand-over-hand assistance to help students find the correct advanced feature button or switch. Over time, with practice, they will be encouraged to learn to use the features independently. *Example scenario:*
Student needs to change the programming on a hearing aid. *Example physical assist:*
Teacher uses hand-over-hand guidance to help the student find the programming button on the back of the hearing aid. The student pushes button once to change the program.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

udl_adaptations.text: Use [[shout outs|shout outs]] to motivate students to independently adjust their hearing devices. Students need reinforcements to encourage independence; some will assume the teacher can always remind them to use a specific feature or even physically help adjust a device setting. When giving the shout out, be specific and tell the student exactly what he or she did right. For example, when a student switches programming without being prompted, say, "Love how you took initiative and changed your program already!"
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.4 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Increase mastery-oriented feedback
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.4 Increase mastery-oriented feedback

goals.goal_text: By (date), during school, when told to adjust a basic hearing device function (e.g. on/off, volume), (name) will independently adjust the function with success (i.e. adjustment allows clear/accurate hearing), for (4 out of 5) device adjustments.

objectives.text:
By (date), during school, when told to adjust a basic hearing device function (e.g. on/off, volume), (name) will adjust the function with success (i.e. adjustment allows clear/accurate hearing), with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical teacher assist]], for (4 out of 5) device adjustments. *Example teacher physical assistance:*
Teacher guides the student's finger to the device volume button.

By (date), during school, when told to adjust a basic hearing device function (e.g. on/off, volume), (name) will adjust the function with success (i.e. adjustment allows clear/accurate hearing), with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical teacher assist]], and a [[shout outs|shout out]] upon completion, for (4 out of 5) device adjustments.

By (date), during school, when a teacher determines a hearing device needs to be [[modified assignment|turned on or off]], (name) will successfully turn the device on or off with (1) [[graduated guidance|physical teacher assist]] and a [[shout outs|shout out]] upon completion, for (4 out of 5) device adjustments.

goals.title: Adjust Device for Better Hearing

udl_adaptations.text:
Use a [[shout outs|shout out]] to motivate students to independently adjust their hearing devices.
