goals.goal_example_text:
**Example teacher prompt:**

“When is it most difficult for you to hear during school?"

**Example student response:**

"When we're doing group-work in Mr. M's class.”
goals.goal_text: By (date), when asked to identify a difficult hearing environment in school, (name) will name (1) environment that negatively impacts access to auditory information (e.g. when group members are loud, gym class, when seated near the fan), for (4 out of 5) example difficult hearing situations.

objectives.example_text:
**Example teacher prompt:**

“When is it most difficult for you to hear during school?"

**Example guiding question:**

“Do you hear better in Mr. M's class or Ms. B's?"
objectives.text: By (date), when asked to describe a difficult hearing environment in school, after the teacher asks (1) [[guiding questions|guiding question]], (name) will name (1) environment that negatively impacts access to auditory information (e.g. when group members are loud, gym class, when seated near the fan), for (4 out of 5) example hearing situations.

objectives.example_text:
**Example answer choices:** * During Mr. McMichael's lesson
* During station time
* When working with an elbow partner **Example student response:** Student says, "During station time."
objectives.text: By (date), when asked to describe a difficult hearing environment in school (e.g. group work in math class), given (3) [[multiple choice|answer choices]] and asked (1) [[guiding questions|guiding question]], (name) will identify which of the (3) answer choices is the difficult environment, for (4 out of 5) example difficult hearing situations.

By (date), given a [[familiar people, places, and things|familiar]] [[visual task schedule|visual task schedule]] with (3) tasks, and asked to identify which item on the schedule represents a difficult hearing environment, (name) will identify the difficult environment (e.g. by pointing, stating, using an [[adaptive switches|adaptive switch]]), for (4 out of 5) example difficult hearing situations.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Identify Difficult Hearing Situations

udl_adaptations.text: Use a student's classroom or individual daily [[visual task schedule|task schedule]] to talk about difficult listening environments. To start, point out one difficult hearing environment and one or two easy hearing environments on the task schedule. For example, show students the daily task pictures for environments like gym class, silent reading time, and independent work time. Ask the student: “During which activity do you have the most trouble hearing?” In this example, the student would point to the gym class picture, because gym acoustics often impact hearing, and students also don't always wear personal hearing devices during gym class. After students can identify the obvious choice, move forward with a discussion about *why* it is hard to hear in that setting.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 7.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize individual choice and autonomy
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 7.1 Optimize individual choice and autonomy

udl_adaptations.text:
When asking students to identify potential difficult listening environments, give [[multiple choice|multiple answer choices]] as a support. Be sure that one of the answer choices represents a difficult hearing setting, and the others do not, which will make the correct answer clear to the student. *Example answer choices:*
• Music class
• Library
• Reading time Here, the obvious answer is music class, since playing instruments and singing are all loud activities.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

udl_adaptations.text: If a student can't immediately name a possible difficult hearing situation, ask a [[guiding questions|guiding question]] to give a little nudge in the right direction. In relation to this task, students may have difficulty narrowing down the exact source of a potential difficult hearing situation. For example, a student might say that it is often difficult to hear in math class, but doesn't know exactly which routine activities most negatively affect the listening environment. To help the student narrow it down, ask questions that already acknowledge the overall setting, such as "When it's hard to hear in math, what are you usually doing?" If the student still responds with a very general answer (e.g. "I'm sitting at my desk."), ask a follow up guiding question such as, "Who or what are you sitting next to?"
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.3 Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example homophone/homonym:**

maid, made

**Example sentence:**

“The maid finished cleaning the room after one hour.”

**Example prompt:**

“There is a word we talked about that has a matching word that sounds the same but means something else. What is the word and what does it mean in this sentence?”

**Example student response:**

“The word is ‘maid’, and here it means someone who cleans.”
goals.goal_text: By (date), after listening to a [[read aloud|read aloud]] of a text that includes one [[vocabulary preview|previously-taught]] homonym/homophone (e.g. words that sound the same but have different meanings), when asked to identify and define the homonym/homophone that was used, (name) will verbally state and define the word, for (4 out of 5) homophone pairs.

objectives.text: By (date), during [[explicit instruction|one-on-one or small-group instruction]] that includes an explicit [[vocabulary preview|preview]] of (2) homonyms/homophones and listening to a [[read aloud|read aloud]] of a [[familiar text|familiar text]] that includes (1) of the homonyms/homophones, (name) will state and verbally define the previewed word, for (4 of 5) homonym/homophone pairs.

By (date), during [[explicit instruction|one-on-one or small-group instruction]] that includes an explicit [[vocabulary preview|preview]] of (2) homonyms/homophones, given an illustrated [[response cards|card ]] for each word and after listening to a [[read aloud|read aloud]] of a [[familiar text|familiar text]] that includes (1) of the homonyms/homophones, (name) will state and verbally define the previewed word, for (4 of 5) homonym/homophone pairs.

By (date), during [[explicit instruction|one-on-one or small-group instruction]] that includes an explicit [[vocabulary preview|preview]] of (2) homonyms/homophones, given an illustrated [[response cards|card ]] for each word and after listening to (1) sentence that includes (1) of the homonyms/homophones, (name) will [[modified assignment|choose ]] (e.g. state the word and/or point to the illustrated response card) the correct word, for (4 of 5) homonym/homophone pairs. *Example prompt:*
“The maid cleaned up the room. Point to the card that shows the word ‘maid’ that is used in that sentence.”

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Define Multi-Meaning Words

udl_adaptations.text: Give two picture cards from which students can [[modified assignment|choose]] the answer rather than asking for a verbal statement or definition of the homonym/homophone that has been used in the given sentence. Use an illustration, photo, or a generic Google image for each picture card. For example, for the sentence, "Roses are my favorite flower," the first picture card can depict a [[https://image.freepik.com/free-vector/red-rose_23-2147503227.jpg|rose]] and the second picture card can depict a bag of [[https://us.123rf.com/450wm/Timmary/Timmary1508/Timmary150800093/44170960-flour-in-a-bag-and-spikelets-isolated-on-white-background.jpg?ver=6|flour]].
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 8.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Vary demands and resources to optimize challenge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 8.2 Vary demands and resources to optimize challenge

udl_adaptations.text: Read a [[familiar text|familiar]] text or sentence to ensure that there is no unknown vocabulary when assessing students' understanding of a homonym or homophone. If a previously read text does not contain the target homonyms/homophones, write and use a sentence ahead of this lesson; be sure that the student understands all of the other words within the target sentence. It is important to be careful about this to ensure that students are only being assessed on the homonym/homophone and not confused by any other content within the given text.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 2.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Support decoding text, mathematical notation, and symbols
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 2.3 Support decoding text, mathematical notation, and symbols

udl_adaptations.text: Present illustrated [[response cards|response cards]] that show each homonym/homophone and a colorful illustration or photograph that clearly connects the written word with its meaning. Discuss the cards with the students before using them as an assessment tool to ensure they understand the word and its connection with the visual support. For example, for the cards that visually depict "flower" and "flour," ask questions such as, "What is this a picture of? What types of flowers do you know of? What is flour used for?"Also, allow students to physically handle the cards ahead of time so that they are not a novel distraction during this task.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 4.1 Vary the methods for response and navigation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example scenario:**

During gym class, the student removes a hearing aid, puts it in case, stores the case in a locker.
goals.goal_text: By (date), when a hearing device is not in use during the school day, (name) will independently charge, clean, and stow (i.e. in the proper place and manner) the hearing device, for (4 out of 5) school days.

objectives.text: By (date), after a [[modeling behaviors|teacher demonstration]], when a hearing device is not in use during the school day, (name) will independently charge, clean, and stow (i.e. in the proper place and manner) the hearing device, for (4 out of 5) school days.

By (date), after a [[modeling behaviors|teacher demonstration]], given an illustrated device care [[student to-do lists|checklist]], (name) will independently charge, clean, and stow (i.e. in the proper place and manner) all hearing devices not in use during the school day, for (4 out of 5) school days.

By (date), after a [[modeling behaviors|teacher demonstration]], given an illustrated device care [[student to-do lists|checklist]], (name) will receive [[graduated guidance|graduated teacher guidance]] to charge, clean, and stow (i.e. in the proper place and manner) all hearing devices not in use during the school day, for (4 out of 5) school days.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Charge, Clean and Stow Devices

udl_adaptations.text: [[Modeling behaviors|Demonstrate]] the correct way to utilize, maintain, and care for personal hearing devices (e.g. hearing aid, cochlear implant, classroom sound field system). Model how to turn the device on/off correctly, how to properly charge the device at the end of the school day and/or when not in use, and how to store the device. For example, if a device has a rechargeable battery, state, “This device has rechargeable batteries in it. Make sure the device is turned on/off to allow it to charge when not in use.” For non-verbal students, provide repetitive over-hand teacher-student demonstrations until the student has learned specific device maintenance and care steps.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.1 Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

udl_adaptations.text:
Give students a [[student to-do lists|visual checklist]] that serves as a basic device care “how-to." Personal hearing devices differ; therefore, the teacher should create a device care guide for each corresponding student hearing device. Teachers can access guides by contacting the parent/guardian and/or Educational Audiologist prior to the start of the school year, and use it to create a more student-friendly visual checklist. Visual checklists can include topics such as: • How to store the device when not in use.
• How to keep the device batteries charged/in working condition.
• How to clean the device.
• When to alert an adult (Educational Audiologist, teacher, parent) about a device issue.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

udl_adaptations.text:
Give students who require intensive supports [[graduated guidance|graduated teacher guidance]] to help them learn how to properly maintain and care for a personal hearing device. The guidance can range from physical assistance (e.g. hand-over-hand) to verbal prompts, depending on the need of individual students. *Example scenario:*
Grace uses a personal FM system and has fine motor difficulties. After Grace reviews the checklist on how to properly coil/wrap the personal FM system cord(s), the teacher uses over-hand guidance to help her wrap the cord correctly.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.3 Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation

goals.goal_example_text:
**Example Difficult Hearing Situation:** Student has trouble hearing teacher during mini-lesson. **Example Accommodation Choices:** Teacher says, "Do you want to sit next to me during the read aloud, or use the FM?"
**Example Student Response:** Student says, "Use the FM."
goals.goal_text: By (date), during a difficult hearing situation in school, given a choice between (2) hearing accommodations, (name) will ask for one of the accommodations, in (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations.

objectives.example_text:
**Example Accommodation Choices:**

* Move next to teacher during read aloud
* Use FM unit

**Example Verbal Guidance Prompt:**

Teacher says, "Choose the one that you think will help you more."
objectives.text: By (date), during a difficult hearing situation in school, given a choice between (2) hearing accommodations and a [[verbal prompting|verbal guidance prompt]], (name) will ask for one of the accommodations, in (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations.

objectives.example_text:
**Example Illustrated Accommodation Choices:** 

* Move next to teacher (picture of teacher on choice board)
* Use FM unit (picture of FM unit on choice board)
objectives.text: By (date), during a difficult hearing situation in school, given a choice between (2) [[visual aids|illustrated hearing accommodations]] and a [[verbal prompting|verbal guidance prompt]], (name) will ask for one of the accommodations, in (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations.

By (date), during a difficult hearing situation in school, given a choice between (2) [[visual aids|illustrated hearing accommodations]], after the teacher [[explicit instruction|explains]] each accommodation, (name) will select an accommodation using a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]] (e.g. pointing, using an [[adaptive switches|adaptive switch]] or communication device), in (4 out of 5) difficult hearing situations.

goals.subject: Deaf/Hard of Hearing
goals.title: Choose an Accommodation

udl_adaptations.text: [[Visual aids|Illustrated accommodation choices]] will do two things for students: provide a visual representation of the accommodation, and allow the student to use a preferred mode of expression to make a selection (i.e. nonverbal). The accommodation choices can be presented on individual flashcards, a choice board, or reference sheet that includes multiple accommodations that the student is familiar with. The images can be detailed and specific (e.g. a photo of a student implementing the accommodation), or more symbolic (e.g. a visual clip art icon to represent the accommodation). Before asking students to make a choice between two illustrated accommodations, however, teachers should make sure the student knows what each image represents.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL II 5.3 Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

udl_adaptations.text: Modify this task to allow students to use a [[preferred modes of expression|preferred mode of expression]]. Instead of verbally choosing an accommodation, a student can use a nonverbal communication method, such as gesturing, nodding in response to a yes/no question, activating an adaptive switch or using a communication device. For example, to elicit a yes/no response, the teacher can ask, “Do you think sitting at the end of the semi-circle, near me, would help you hear the story better?” Similarly, if the student uses a communication device, the teacher can ask questions that elicit student answers that have already been pre-programmed into the device. For students who prefer to communicate using images, the teacher can supply accommodation picture choices and ask them to choose what works best. Students can point to, pick up, or use eye gaze to indicate their selection.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL III 9.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Develop self-assessment and reflection
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL III 9.3 Develop self-assessment and reflection

udl_adaptations.text:
[[Verbal prompting|Prompt]] students to choose an accommodation if they don't give an immediate answer. For example, if a student shrugs after given two accommodation choices, prompt with phrases such as:
"Choose the one that will best help you hear."
"Pick the choice that worked for you last time."
"Whichever one you'd like - it's completely up to you."
Allowing students to choose their own accommodations promotes self-advocacy, and prompting allows the teacher to nudge students along without explicitly assigning an accommodation to a student who doesn't choose one immediately on their own.
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_long_ref: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations.udl_standard_short_ref: UDL I 3.1 Activate or supply background knowledge

goals.goal_example_text:

**Example Student Response:** Student says, "Use the FM because I'll hear more clearly."
